column10: Incredible story

A wise man once said, "He who leads a war for the love of his fellow men, will defeat his enemies." I led my war protecting my family and friends, protecting my home - the Metro. We had won. But to this day, I wonder: When we burned the ■■■■ from the face of the earth, was something lost as well...?

Cons: terrible English voice acting, especially children seriously wtf,  a bit boring monsters and story could be a little better considering this game is based on the novel.

I'm starting to feel like I'm a very harsh critic. I look at the scores sitting at overwhelmingly positive and I simply don't get it. There were some aspects to this game that I liked, but at every turn there's a poorly explained mechanic, odd level design, inconsistent stealth, a story that's poorly told, and an ending chapter that decides to take every awful gaming cliche and throw it in the blender. The setting is really interesting and I would have liked more freedom in exploring it, but this is a very linear shooter. Some people compare this to Fallout, but they have nothing in common other than the post apocalyptic setting. This isn't an open world rpg full of exploration, this is a nearly on rails shooter with occasional areas that open up a bit allowing you to get through either with combat, stealth, or a combo of both. It also has two endings, but since one is official and carries over into the next game I see no reason for even including the other. It's possible I'm reviewing this too much through the eyes of 2024 and not when it came out, but things like graphics and sound were fine for me. I don't think I would have liked a lot of the gameplay elements had I played it day one. I know my review won't have any effect on this game or it's legacy, but it just does too many things wrong for me to give it a thumbs up. It would be a thumbs sideways if that were an option, but sadly it still isn't so even though it might be a 49 to 51 split, I still have to downvote this. I'm going right into the second one so hopefully there are a lot of improvements because seeing a post WW3 game through the eyes of the other side is something I enjoyed.

I am going to start by saying, I fucking love this game.

I picked up Metro Exodus, the most recent game in the series at the time of writing this, at some unknown point, and with no games I really wanted to play, I checked it out. Right away, this game is very much not my usual kind of game: I like high fantasy, RPG, etc. Other nerdy shit. But after playing Exodus for some time, I came to see a lot of the same bones of a traditional fantasy RPG with a Russian coat of paint and it was... endearing. Curious about the intro that says, "based on the book", I got curious and found out there was other games in the franchise and it was, in fact a series. Stopping my playthrough dead in my tracks on Exodus, I saw that Metro 2033 Redux was not only on sale for $1.99 (fucking WHAT??) but the whole series was on sale. Deciding there was no harm, I purchased 2033, Last Light and all the DLC that comes with them. Now I wasn't expecting anything from Metro 2033. It was the first in the series and clearly this was the remastered version and it shows. So much of this game is polished up from the original, but to spare you the read, Metro 2033 Redux had an amazing world with engaging characters. It felt lived in, and borderline believable. I fell in love with the characters, and even the way it told a Man vs. Nature story that I rarely seem to find in videogames. The combat is a little silly sometimes, but with all the loot, guns, customization and secrets, you very quickly stop caring. 

Aside from the combat being kind of silly sometimes, there is a certain jankiness to the stealth that seems to be present across the Metro series. Its not bad, necessarily, but it is really forgiving and a lot of times it makes me laugh. Personally, I would also have difficulty sometimes shooting targets with weapons like the Helsing despite them being directly in my crosshairs, I'd miss completely, and that would end up getting me absolutely deleted. As I said, the game's definitely not perfect, but a lot of times the story makes up for it in spades. You can argue that there's a lot of Hollywood style coincidences where shit goes so off the rails (sometimes literally) but works out that detract from the overall value of the individual event sequences, but there's a certain point where you have to just let go and have some fun with it.

I don't normally say this, but I give this game a very solid 8.5/10. If the combat could be a little tighter, and some small things could be changed, it might even be a perfect 10.

All that said, I am achievement hunting the game atm, and replaying it shows me a lot of stuff I missed in the story on my first run. This game has layers, like an ogre, and I'm eager to finally unravel what this world has, and eagerly await the next installment in the Metro series here in 2024. 

[Side note, I also began reading the book which I HIGHLY recommend despite not being much of a book guy. It's very engrossing and helps build onto the world depicted in the game.]

The only problems I had with this game, and they are minor and shouldn't harm your enjoyment, is that the game seemed a little slow at the beginning, idk it is hard to explain. I want to say urgency or animation in general, but that doesn't seem right, either way I just had that feeling in the first mission in the metro. Second problem was the tutorial didn't teach you everything, I didn't know how to use grenades or that I could use my knife until I looked at the button layout. Once I learned about them...I still didn't use them lol.

I think this game is pretty easy despite me playing on survivor mode (less ammo and stuff compared to spartan), so don't worry about the ammo warning or anything, I didn't buy anything, not even gas filters, I even found all the guns I liked. That being said the game has a pretty good stealth system and even if you get caught, every guy you take out stealth is net positive on ammo.

If you are looking for a gun recommendation, I recommend the revolving shotgun, solved 99.9% of my problems despite the game making it sound like the reloading being an issue, it's not.

54.8 horas depois com 100% do jogo completo e com 100% das conquistas feitas.
(Aqui vale ressaltar que, por conta de uma emergência e um antigo início de gameplay, existem umas 8~10 horas que não fazem parte do 100%)

Recomendado. 

A primeira run foi survival + ranger hardcore e dificultou bastante o início do jogo, a falta de UI e dicas inicialmente fez falta, como o uso do recharger pra lanterna e night vision por exemplo. Mas assim que você entende a pegada do jogo tudo flui muito bem. Os gráficos são exatamente o que você espera e com certeza vai surpreender em algumas cenas mais "especiais".

A história, apesar de curta/simples, pode cativar e comover. É interessante, inclusive, como você pode acabar perdendo pedaços da história por simplesmente não prestar atenção por causa de toda a tensão que o jogo produz, enquanto você está paranoico olhando para cada cantinho e buraco, os npc's estão tendo o maior bate-papo. Vale ressaltar a exploração que, apesar de não ser super profunda ainda é extensa o suficiente para agradar e surpreender. Os inimigos em alguns momentos podem ser irritantes, mas nada tão pesado.

The description says " rebuilt in the latest and greatest iteration of the 4A Engine for Next Gen " but I couldn't even get to run the game at 1440p, while the original ran at 4k without issues. The AI is dumber than the original too. Areas have been changed which kinda breakes the immersion for those who played the original. Many of the assault rifles have the same generic sound. This was disappointing, especially for the ak47 which had a nice punchy and heavy sound in the original.

A good thing I noticed is that the frame rate is more stable than the first game, but I was running it at 1920x1440, so probably that's why. Another positive is that it is easier to know what kind of ammo you buy for which weapon and they also added stealth kills.

I was pleasantly surprised with this game.I have picked up the etnire metro bundle on Steam for 5 bucks so I didn't expect much. Instead I came away adrenaline pounding in my ears, thoroughly engrossed in an excellently paced and crafted experience. I say experience because the feeling of claustrophobia and confusion are palatable, and they pull you deeper into the metro. The audio adds to this experience being both tense and sorrowful interchangeably, making you experience the emotions that would accompany such an underground existence. Some week points do exist, the game never feels anything but linear, and there are some dated graphics but the redux version handles that quite well. Excellent game giving a very different look and feel to a crowded genre, worth every minute.

TL;DR: A fun, moody narrative-FPS with survival horror and stealth elements. If sneaking and/or killing your way through a post-apocalyptic hellscape to save your settlement from an existential threat sounds fun, you will likely enjoy this game more than enough to justify its purchase, even if it isn't anything new.

Take this review with a grain of salt, as I don't often play FPS games. When I do, I tend to stick to narrative driven single-player experiences like the Half-Life or Bioshock franchises. Compared to those titles, Metro 2033 feels pretty reserved in its scope and environments, but they have done a laudable job in creating a universe that feels lived in and appropriately oppressive.

Based on a Russian novel, the story starts 20 years on from a war that has destroyed life as we know it, the people of Moscow live in the titular metro system, having formed small city-states at different stations. The population is tiny, and they get by mainly through scavenging the ruins of the old world, with the surface now covered by toxic atmosphere, intense radiation, and dangerous mutated creatures. A new threat has emerged on the northern boundaries of this society, and is wiping out defenders with attacks that leave them mentally devastated. You play as Artyom, a young man who is seemingly immune to these attacks, as he sets out on a journey to rally the defenders of the metro system to strike at this new threat.

The story is fine; it's nothing wildly new or unique, but the environment feels like the real main character. In your trek you'll have to cross miles of untamed tunnels, break the frontlines of a war raging between nazis and communists, and brave the surface to achieve your goals. The maps feel appropriately cramped, but big enough to leave room for exploration, and the threats feel real without relying on too many jumpscares.

As far as the gameplay goes, Metro isn't really doing anything revolutionary. Most missions will see you killing plenty of enemies, with optional stealth mechanics that never felt unfair or frustrating. You can carry up to three weapons at a time, and there are a decent number to choose from. None of them felt terribly novel, though I did like the air pressure-powered ball bearing weapons that you have to periodically pump to maintain sufficient stopping power. It feels like they intended for the game to have survival horror ammo management challenges, but even playing on the Survival mode I never felt starved for ammunition. I played on Normal difficulty, so maybe on harder settings you'll find yourself having to switch up ammo types due to scarcity, but I felt like they were a little too generous with it.

My only real complaint with this game is with its ending and moral system. The problem is that which ending you get depends on actions you've taken during the course of the game. That sounds fine, but this system is never explained, and the "good" actions can be arbitrary. Want the "good" ending? You'd better stop what you're doing to listen to certain background NPC conversations and make sure to loot specific stashes. Basically, if you don't follow a guide the entire game you're almost guaranteed to get the "bad" ending, without even really knowing that you could have changed it. On top of that, having played the sequel (Last Light) I know that your choice doesn't ultimately impact the world, as that story assumes one specific ending and moves on. If the player doesn't have any meaningful agency, why add the illusion of it, then hide that behind an unexplained system.

Overall, this is a pretty run-of-the-mill narrative shooter with a fine story, fantastic atmosphere, and a poorly-executed morality system that you should probably ignore on your first playthrough if you don't want to ruin the experience. Just plan for a hand-holding second run if you want to see the less gloomy ending.

Metro 2033` is an absolute thrill ride through the eerie underground tunnels of post-apocalyptic Moscow. As Artyom, I found myself immersed in a world filled with danger, mystery, and heart-pounding action. Late nights and early mornings were spent exploring the depths of the Metro, uncovering its secrets and facing off against terrifying mutants and hostile factions.

What struck me most about the game was its attention to detail. From the eerie ambiance of the tunnels to the haunting beauty of the ruined surface, every location felt alive with history and atmosphere. I often found myself pausing just to admire the scenery, marveling at the intricate design and imagining the stories behind each crumbling building and darkened alleyway.

The stealth and survival mechanics kept me on the edge of my seat throughout my playthrough. Whether I was sneaking past patrolling enemies or engaging in intense firefights, every encounter felt tense and exhilarating. I spent countless hours strategizing my approach, carefully managing my resources, and adapting to the ever-changing threats lurking in the shadows.

But "Metro 2033" is more than just a thrilling shooter. It's a deep and thought-provoking journey into the human condition. Through Artyom's interactions with fellow survivors and the haunting remnants of a once-great civilization, I was forced to confront difficult moral choices and existential questions. These moments of reflection lingered with me long after I had put down the controller, adding an extra layer of depth to an already compelling narrative.

And let's not forget the game's stunning visuals and immersive sound design. The eerie echoes of distant screams and the flickering glow of my gas mask's flashlight added to the game's atmosphere, drawing me further into its dark and desolate world.

another game steam misleads people on. they claim this is COMPLETELY compatible with steam deck which is to up to one MAJOR issue. Steam cloud will NOT sync any save data across the deck and pc. someone on reddit found out that steam and the dev made separate game save file locations in the directory so the steam cloud can never find it. the work around to fix this is exhausting and frankly not worth the time and effort. oh and steam hasnt fixed this in OVER 2 YEARS!!!! if you plan on playing this on deck and want cross save then dont get this game its not worth it. really sucks because i bought this for that exact reason. just more proof that steams "verified" shouldn't be trusted anymore at all.

Metro 2033 Redux is a great remaster of a great game. The remastering of this game has definitely done its job, since i enjoyed it quite a lot, and it is much more polished than the original in all the good ways, this is the best way to play the game. This game had an amazing atmosphere, pretty acceptable graphics for a remastered old game, but stunning visuals. the story is pretty good as well as well as some engaging gameplay.

The redux edition is quite definitely the best way to play this, with obviously better graphical fidelity, better balancing option, better AI, and more gameplay elements than the original. This is how remasters should be done.

The extremely eerie post-apocalyptic atmosphere and feeling of this game is quite unmatched. it is so immersive in almost all situations, be it scary and dark underground tunnels, eerie, void of life above ground destroyed cities.

The graphical fidelity is much better than the original for sure, but don't expect next-gen models and textures, it can still look like an old game.
But this excused with the stunning visuals of the environment art and the lighting that goes with it.

The story is a nice one and complements the game greatly, there are many characters you meet along the way and most are pretty like-able.

The gameplay is pretty great, especially when you are against other humans, because sneaking around an enemy outpost, trying to sneakily take them out, and then if you get seen you go guns blazing, but still have to worry about limited ammo, is very fun, and it makes you feel like a professional special ops.

This game is pretty fun to go through, and is well worth it. I do recommend giving it a try.

H.G. Wells once wrote, "If we don't end wars, then wars will end us".

And somehow, I stopped my war.

At the time, I couldn't say what had made be spare the Dark Ones.

But, I came to realise that the strange visions that haunted my journey were their attempts to reach out to us.

I don't know if I was the first to communicate with them,

But I will not be the last.

They are among us now...

And the future - our future stretches before us like an endless Metro tunnel.


This game - this story is a masterpiece...

Metro 2033 is known for its tense survival gameplay that forces players to conserve their ammunition and pick their battles. What makes the game special though is that this gameplay is paired with a unique sci-fi/horror story and incredible world-building. There really is no other narrative-focused fps survival game like Metro 2033. 

The Redux version of Metro 2033 has a functioning chapter select system, better optimisation, more weapons, and updated graphics. What many neglect to mention or have forgotten though is that the original game had some levels just before its finale that were outright horribly unfair that the Redux version has actually fixed. There really is no reason to play the original version over this Redux version of the game.

Got this and Last Light Redux on sale not expecting much from it but it turns out I enjoyed it.

To start with, the game throws you right in the middle of a big fight where you end up being pinned down by monsters. I was really confused about what was going on. Then the actual story starts. You are Artyom, a man who wants to save his home from a new emerging threat that appeared on the surface of the Earth, the Dark Ones, after mutants have taken over. You are guiding him throughout the story, uncovering the secrets of the deadly and atmospheric post-apocalyptic world. Personally, I found the story interesting enough for me to finish the game in 3 sittings. 

Performance-wise, being an older game, I expected it to run well on my relatively decent PC (Ryzen 7 5700G, RTX 4060, 32GB RAM), so I cranked all the settings to max. To my surprise, I was getting around 50 - 60 FPS most of the time (even going down to the 30s) and my GPU usage was pinned to 100%. I did find the culprit though, SSAA, more about it [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/286690/discussions/0/34096318957879276/] here [/url].

As far as gameplay is concerned, gunplay feels good enough especially when you get to modify your weapons or find already modified weapons after defeating enemies as loot or scattered around.  The game seems to prioritize being stealthy, even recommending it in the tips, though I really suck at stealth games so I just ended up using firepower to get through the levels that involved stealth.  This proved to be a bit of a problem since some of the enemies seem to be bullet sponges so I had to make use of a lot of ammo and grenades.

Level design-wise, I sometimes found it confusing. The game gives you a compass that shows you where to go but even with that, I got lost here and there when I was following the direction that it was showing me. I did find the compass mechanic interesting but also a bit annoying since it shares the same button as the button to use the lighter, M. Also, there is a journal paper on the compass, where Artyom writes down your current objective. You can see it if you have the compass out and press the right-click.

There is also a mechanic that isn't really explained, how to charge your flashlight and night-vision battery. Hold F and the charger pops up. Press the right-click multiple times until it is fully charged (it was probably explained in the original Metro 2033 game and it assumes you already played it, I suppose).

I would like to note that I played the game on normal difficulty and the Survival Mode (which is more akin to the original Metro 2033 game). 

As a closing note, overall, I enjoyed the game. It really scratched the itch I had for the 2010s singleplayer shooters. The atmosphere was well done, even making me get jumpscared here and there by some attacking enemies. It also make me feel the fear of the unknown. 

Sorry for the wall of text, just wanted to express my whole experience with the game and the thoughts I had about it.

The prompt box here doesn't ask "is this game good" or "is this game fun". It specifically asks if you would *recommend* this game. Is it fun? Eh, I guess? Is it good? Eh, it's fine. If someone asked me "should I spend my money and time specifically on Metro 2033?" I would say "don't bother". At only 7 hours, it's insultingly short for pretty much any price. I'm sure I've got free copies of this game about 4 separate times on every launcher ,but I'/m pretty sure I did originally pay for these in a sale. I think the current price of about £1 is fair, but the usual price of almost £18 us laughable. If they really think this game is good enough to be worth over £2 per hour of content, I have some questions. I expect a full game to be maybe 25 hours at the shortest? This is like buying a """fun""" zised chocolate bar. I want the whole thing, man. The missions were fairly easy, and I felt handheld through the story with very railroad-y cutscenes. I wasn't super impressed with the gameplay balence and v easy difficulty, but matched with a runtime that doesn't even crack double digits, I don't see this having much replayability outside of trophy hunting for the sake of it. The gameplay felt second to the story, that wasn't super well developed. Maybe I've just overdosed on generic dystopias with mutants?

Spoiler territory: How would nuking the surface even help? We've seen that the tunnels are absolutely infested with mutant life, so if we are to believe that nuking the surface should kill them all, shouldn't that kill all the metro dwellers too? The whole time I was under the impression we were saving one station, but at the end, they act like the world has been saved. I guess it doesn't work as this game has sequels, but the writing there felt off.

Metro 2033 will stand the test of time as being one of the greatest story-rich, post-apocalyptic survival horror games of all time. This is a ten-year-old remaster, but with or without the newer textures, I was legitimately scared and amazed by the quality of the enemy creatures, the setting (atmosphere), and the sound. I was frightened. Playing on the highest difficulty made me so paranoid and actually fearful and invested. I'm always looking around me to see if anyone is going to suddenly ambush me. The Slavic setting and humor are perfect, and the voice acting makes all the characters memorable forever. There is definitely a cult for this franchise for a long time. 

What I appreciate the most is its simple but meaningful take on linear gameplay. There was no need to overcomplicate it with extra filler or open-world boundaries. The gunplay is excellent, too. This game and franchise manage to compete heavily against FALLOUT or STALKER with no problem. Get the bundle when it is a steal, and you won't be disappointed.

The game is labeled as a survival horror game, and honestly the "horror" it creates is more in the setting being, what I felt is, a realistic and depressing depiction of what a real post-apocalyptic setting would be like irl. The environments all are really well crafted to bring this across. 

And the other key ingredient that helps it come off so well is the characters, they’re all charmingly human in terms of their writing and behavior, and while Artyom himself is silent, his short banters during loading screens do give him enough character to be invested in his journey. That being said, the story is more about the place than the people, it’s a really good example of having well defined characters helping worldbuilding tremendously. I will say tho: Fuck. The. Turret. Section. That is the one blemish in an otherwise really well-paced and slower campaign. 

In terms of the gameplay itself, it also does put emphasis on the survival aspect, as it does limit ammo for your weapons and the enemies, while not tough, do tend to swarm you and overwhelm you and make you waste what little ammo you have; which is why stealth is highly encouraged, and honestly, stealth in this game isn’t as pace breaking as it would be in other games because all-out combat isn’t that bombastic or crazy to begin with, and it does fit with Artyom's character of being just some random guy who’s only getting a taste of the world beyond his home, going up against entire armies. 

Overall, really enjoyable and recommendable.

Currently on my 12th play-through, I love the dark gloomy atmosphere this game portrays. Combined with the old early 2000's graphics makes this game a nostalgic masterpiece. The story this game tells is serious enough to keep me engaged with all its characters and beautiful environment, even if its a dark metro tunnel. Each setting is filled with a interactive environment with plenty of little details when looking at level design. For a small shooter game, I absolutely love the clunky combat and weapon mechanics. For the gun play itself, its really enjoyable in my opinion. Upgrading and scavenging for guns and ammo is really enjoyable if that's the type of game play you're into. The game allows various play styles like Stealth and Loud approaches, stealth first then going loud or vise versa. Either way both are enjoyable options, metro also implements a "karma" system to its game play. So if you want a good ending you'll need to explore the world and play a certain way. All and all Its a very good game and it holds up very well on my low end PC. When I purchased the game I bought it in a 4.99 bundle with Metro 2033 redux and Metro Last light redux, knowing what I know now Id genuinely would buy this game for a tripple A title release price of 60 USD. I love the game, story, and game play, and I'll definitely continue replaying it in the future.

Decent shoot. The environments and atmosphere make it special. Coming up to the surface after hours in the oppressive subway tunnels to be blinded by the sun. Wiping the blood and snow off your gas mask as you hear your air filter ticking closer to empty every moment. More than worth the 3 dollars they put it on sale for.

Such an underrated game. The tension that builds while playing is remarkable, and I especially love the super unique post-apocalypse weapons (For example, a gun made of bike parts). Everything is done amazingly, especially the monsters and the human enemies. You can always choose to sneak your way around missions, or go ballistic and shoot everything that moves, which is so unique and fun to play. Especially when you hear the howl of the monsters and realized you've absolutely messed up. If you like FPS games, horror games, stealth games, apocalypse games, this is for everyone. I seriously recommend playing this and the other two games, as this one's just the beginning.

From some of the people who made the stalker games we got this game with settled on a post apocaliptic moscow in the year 2033 where the world has been destroyed due to WW 3, as a consequence of this now the world is filled with monsters and the surface is so toxic and radioactive that the people had to go underground and make their lifes in the moscow metro system.

The first thing I want to talk about its his atmosphere which oh god how I loved it, every level tells you more about the world just by how it is done, the dirty and filthy metro tunnels where monster crawl and can attack you anytime, always told to maintain your guard up cuz you never know when you're going to get attacked by one of the monsters that walk around those same tunnels. How in every station you visit you can see the state people have to live and survive in, how in many occasions throughout the games we celebrate with our friends after surviving a trip through those tunnels and the surface cuz the fact that we're alive after facing those hazards is a real miracle..

[Spoilers] And moments like the mission where the kid we're rescuing is amazed by the sky, something he has never seen and talks about how he is going to tells his friends about it.

[Not more spoilers] The game is crafted in a way that you can inmerse yourself into his world in such an easy way that you're gonna find yourself cheering everytime you come alive of a trip in the surface, smilign with your commrades everytime you come out alive with them, feeling the death of some of them and feeling your heart beat faster everytime you're in a situation close to death. Fr the game is really helpfull with the autosaves, saving everytime you enter a new zone but still you dont feel fear cuz you're gonna have to go back and do everything again, you're gonna feel pain cuz you're going to be so inmerse that you're gonna do anything to survive like if that was the only life you had..

Metro 2033 Redux is a stunning makeover of a cult classic that immerses you in a bleak and brutal world of survival. The game takes you on a journey through the dark and dangerous tunnels of the Moscow Metro, where you face mutant creatures, hostile factions, and paranormal phenomena. You play as Artyom, a young man who holds the key to humanity's salvation, and must fight your way to the heart of the Metro to deliver a message that could change the fate of the world.

The game features two modes of gameplay: Survival and Spartan. Survival mode is closer to the original Metro 2033, with scarce resources, limited ammo, and slower pacing. Spartan mode is more action-oriented, with more ammo, faster combat, and streamlined stealth. You can also choose between two difficulty levels: Normal and Hardcore. Hardcore mode removes the HUD, crosshair, and quick-time events, making the game more challenging and realistic.

The game's graphics are stunning, with improved lighting, shadows, textures, and animations. The game runs smoothly on the PS4, Xbox One, and PC, with no noticeable glitches or bugs. The sound design is also impressive, with realistic gunshots, explosions, and environmental noises. The voice acting is decent, although some of the accents are a bit exaggerated. The music is atmospheric and fitting, with a mix of orchestral and electronic tracks.

The game's story is engaging and well-written, with memorable characters, dialogue, and choices. The game has multiple endings, depending on your actions and morality throughout the game. The game also has a lot of replay value, with different modes, difficulties, and secrets to discover. The game is about 10-12 hours long, depending on how you play and explore.

Metro 2033 Redux is a must-play for fans of the original game, as well as newcomers who want to experience a unique and immersive FPS game. The game is a masterpiece of storytelling, gameplay, and visuals, and deserves a high score of 9/10.

METRO: 2033 - REDUX

Gameplay: It has a very interesting story and a very intriguing way of explaining it, as the mechanics of the game are repeated a bit. It has a variety of weapons and very good quality in details and characters. It has serious, mysterious, comic and dark characters. Including very aggressive enemies which make the game more exciting. The game includes two Combat/Item difficulties which have quite striking challenges.

Achievements: Includes 49 campaign/weapon/map achievements, including the two endings.

Soundtracks: Incredible, quite moving and of good quality, the one I liked the most is when we meet Khan which is called "Ghost Tunnels".

Maps: The scenarios are incredible and very large to collect objects and strategize how to eliminate enemies.

DLC: Does not include downloadable content but it would be nice if it had content at least from the game's soundtracks.

NOTE: Before purchasing this product on Steam, I tested the XBOX One version and I have to say that the PC version has problems with some animations that would be good to review for computer platforms.

The game unfolded rapidly, captivating with its intriguing plot, and the narrative elicited enjoyable emotions.

I'm really sorry that I can't give this game a positive rating, I would have preferred to give a neutral rating. Everything seemed beautiful to me: the atmosphere, the audio, the graphics, the lore.

But unfortunately the design of almost every level is so painful that it takes away all the fun. For the umpteenth time I find myself completely stuck, I have to look for guides on the internet, and there I find comments from other desperate people stuck in the same points, a sign that the problem exists (despite a group of fans blaming those who find it difficult , calling them "stupid" and such nonsense).

The action, when there is, is good and appreciable, in those moments I enjoyed it. The problem is that many (admittedly not short) parts of the game could be classified as "puzzle game", "walking simulator", sometimes even "quick time event", and unfortunately I can't bring myself to like these parts. They seem to me to be very poorly mixed with the action, although on a graphic level they are sometimes spectacular. The narration is too invasive, very often you are forced to sit still and watch boring animations. Yet despite the linearity of the levels, often the most pressing problem is finding the exit of the level while fighting invisible walls.

[h1]Positives[/h1]
[list]
[*]The visuals give a great sense of atmosphere, every area in the game feels real which is really immersive imho. All the buildings, metro stations, outfits, makeshift weapons etc. are cohesive and form a consistent world that's enjoyable to play in
[*]The story is very good with lots of interesting points that drive the player forward wanting to find out more and more. Some of them are resolved, some are left for your own interpretation, which in here is done well imho. I wish the nature of the Dark Ones was better explained to give a player a better understanding of the true story and the endings
[*]Interesting characters with good dialogues. A lot of them are memorable with their unique behaviors and style
[*]Great world building, I think it shows a very real side of human nature when forced into these circumstances
[*]The gunplay feels satisfying, most guns are responsive and punchy with good sounds and nice animations
[*]Really cool stealth system. Too bad the game doesn't even mention it's a feature
[*]You have the option to play with or without HUD which is neat if you're looking for a more immersive gameplay. Even the prompts can be disabled
[*]Interesting trading system with valuable bullets as currency which can also be used for extra damage during gameplay
[*]Most weapons have mags you can partially see through to check how many bullets you have left, and optionally what ammo type is currently loaded in. And I really like the rest of the interface essentially being integrated as ingame items rather than HUD elements
[/list]

[h1]Mixed[/h1]
[list]
[*]Some weapons have pretty janky reload animations
[*]Quite a few weapons feels really clunky to use and powerless against enemies. Pneumatic weapons for example feel underpowered compared to everything else. Not only I have to maintain the pressure manually (which is just a hassle), but they feel straight up worse than other weapons
[*]Speech during loading screens is way too loud compared to the rest of the game
[*]There's a really weird fog effect when using NVGs, but only in the center of the screen? I don't get what's happening here because you have clear vision around the edges of the screen, this fog only blocks sight towards the center and beyond a certain ingame distance. It's kind of annoying. Even when the given area has no fog or dust at all, you'll still see this cloud in front of you blocking a major part of your vision if objects are far enough
[*]Your watch isn't visible at all when you're using the LMG shotgun
[*]I like the ammo trading system, but I think there aren't enough traders in total so you don't get to experience the full arsenal the game has to offer
[/list]

[h1]Negatives[/h1]
[list]
[*]Silent protagonist. I don't like when NPCs talk to me and my character just says nothing, it's so dumb and awkward. Not to mention lots of situations could have been avoided if I could tell the group what I've seen, information I've heard, my thoughts etc.
[*]Terrible stuttering out of the box, it makes the game almost unplayable. The only fix I found was to disable [url=https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Metro_2033_Redux#:~:text=fix%5B16%5D-,Micro%20Stuttering,-%E2%80%A2%20Link]CPU core parking[/url]
[*]Low default FOV which imho isn't enjoyable to play. You can easily fix it but that'll mess up some animations, and the FOV in the ending sequence will go to unplayable levels. You'll have to manually dial it back for that section of the game
[*]Really weird mouse sensitivity and different speeds for vertical and horizontal movements. It's an easy fix tho, check the above link. Visual effects overlaid on the screen also break with higher FOV than default
[*]The interactions tutorial is misleading. It requires you to 'press and hold' on the very first one, but the rest of the game is just the regular 'press once' and done. This makes no sense and it's unintuitive
[*]Mutants sometimes don't die properly and continue their animation and sounds without doing any damage beyond that point. This can be funny or really annoying depending on the map
[*]When you fall into water there's a strange animation of you just floating there for a few seconds before the game teleports you out to the nearest ledge and gives you back control. It's really awkward and lasts way too long
[*]The karma system to get the good ending can be tedious and boring after the first playthrough
[*]Sprinting feels clunky, and after some interactions you can't start running instantly which can get you killed
[*]Some mutants are overtuned imho; they seem to take way too many shots to kill and/or deal too much damage to the player
[*]Fighting non-human enemies isn't fun because of the clunky running, enemy attack +movement speeds and unclear damage feedback. Lurkers are a great example of this. They're way more annoying than enjoyable
[*]The game sometimes throws an unreasonable amount of enemies at you at once which isn't fun in the slightest, especially when taking the other points into account
[*]In some weapons you can't tell how many bullets are left in the mag and what ammo type is loaded
[*]Most scopes are barely upgrades over iron sights. The red dot-style sight is probably the best, as the magnified scopes don't make it ovbious where you're aiming. The center of the reticle blends into the scope's texture and the background almost all the time
[/list]

"Metro 2033" is one of those games that I have circumstantially returned to. I have right now like a million games to play - and movies to see, and series to watch, and books to read, plus a job to sustain all of such luxuries. I haven't even played its sequels already. Time is of essence... and yet this is a game that, for its moments of clumsiness, fascinated me enough to make me play it three times. So what's up about it that made me so enamoured to it?

The gameplay would be a start. Being a single-player FPS, "2033" lays emphasis in PvE, and the different things players have to do in order to make it through the levels. There are so many commands at play here, so many things to memorise, that it can get a bit frustrating at first. In certain environments, you need to put on a gas-mask, and you have to remember to always clean it up when it starts getting grimy and dirty; it also starts cracking up when you take damage. You can see how much time you have left of air, and you have to change the filter after enough time. There's the basic flashlight, and then there's a lighter to burn through spiderwebs; there's also night vision. The C key is for throwable items, such as explosives and knifes, while the V key is for meele. If you hold R, you can change the ammo type, or "recharge" your weapon, depending of what kind of weapon you're holding. And don't forget your medkits!

All of this may feel unnecessarily bloated, as if the developers had all these cool ideas and wanted to implement them all. But I cannot help but to admire how many commands I had: it really made me fell like I'm a survivor, packing several essential things to survive. And smarter players may use all the tools at their disposal.

Despite being based on the book by Dmitry Glukhovsky (gotta love games based on books), it's clear "2033" was really meant as a spiritual successor to the "S.T.A.L.K.E.R." games, with its gloomy, post-apocalyptic Eastern European setting. The main difference is that while "S.T.A.L.K.E.R." took place in large open world environments, "2033" is mostly set in the dark undergrounds of Moscow. And taking place at tunnels means this game is fairly linear.

I don't know if I would classify it as a semi-open world, like "Dead Rising" or "Dark Souls". But scenarios are large, multi-layered and interconnected enough to hold logs (because it's video game law), dead bodies with ammo, and keys for safes. The curious thing is that sometimes you may find a key but not the safe, and vise-versa: where there is one, there is always the other. Despite the linearity, environments grew so large that I got lost on them, as the path forwards is not always very clear: it's not a very visually vibrant game, and paths of interest may blend in with environments. It was then that I discovered an "Alien: Isolation"-like compass that could guide me to the right path - yet another command. 

Of course there are levels on the outside, showing the decrepit, snowy, "12 Monkeys"-like streets of Moscow, but even those levels are mostly linear. In fact, the game is not really about solving puzzles, scouting people or any other things. It's about going from point A to point B, while facing enemies standing against your progress; sometimes with mates, sometimes on your own. There are some situations in which you have to hold your ground, and a moment when you carry a rather talkative boy to safety and movement becomes limited. But the game overall plays like this, and I guess this simplicity about it is a triumph. There are also levels with no combat at all, taking place at populated areas, where you can buy and upgrade weapons and talk to other dwellers.

Then, there's the combat. As I said, there are a bazillion commands to do, which means there are different ways of killing your enemies. Some levels were designed to support stealth and the usage of quiet weapons. You can go guns blazing if that's your thing, but the issue however is that "2033" was really designed as a survivor game: this is not "Call of Duty". To go guns blazing can be incredibly stressful, and it doesn't help that your character is not very mobile: in fact, he's rather quite slow, having this walking sound that I can only describe as "rusty".

On easy mode, the combat becomes much more pleasant and forgiving, and the game becomes less demanding, more conventional. You can focus on collecting things and better exploring the environments: some paths can lead to behind or above enemies, giving you an advantage. At some moments, you may find fuse boxes and turn the lights off, leaving your enemies in the dark.

Combat is much better when it's against humans, since creatures just jump at you in packs, and you're not the most mobile character. Particularly hateful is a flying monster that grabs you like the Wall Master, flies with you around, and then tosses you to the ground: it makes outside exploration even more annoying. There are also some moments when you have to operate machines and turrets, and I wish they were better developed, since they're not as fun as I hoped them to be.

Guns can be redesigned to your preference, but you can only carry three, and there'll be moments when you may come across interesting guns that will make you leave one of yours behind. The shotgun chain gun is one of the most satisfying shotguns I have ever seen in a video game, but it only shows at the final stretch. There are pneumatic weapons and electric charged ones, which you have to circumstantially recharge as I mentioned earlier. And then there are your traditional rifles, that can be loaded with a special kind of ammo. This brings me to one of the most interesting aspects of the game: the currency. At gun shops, you use this special incendiary ammo to buy and sell stuff. Not only it makes perfect sense in the context of the game - as this ammo is valuable in this world - it can also lead you to tough decisions when your normal ammunition runs out. Will you literally toss money away?

Following in the footsteps of "BioShock", the game presents players with a good and a bad ending, and to reach them, there are many choice moments through the game. The issue however is that these points are not best presented to players: at one moment, a comrade will casually tell you that you can hear children laugh if you put your head close to the pipes, so you have to stand next to the pipes long enough for you to hear laughter. Some points will be obvious enough, such as when you save the talkative boy and refuse payment. You're informed of the choices you made by a sound and a visual cue. It is very much a game that invites players to come back for collectibles, achievements, different play styles and alternative endings.

I've been playing this game simultaneously to "The Last of Us, Part 1", and it's curious to see how "2033" did all that the Naughty Dog classic did before it, and perhaps better. While its 2014 double-A graphics are no "Crysis" (some kids I came across felt like they had plastic hair), everything is full with detail, as the scenarios, models and art direction really sell this game: some tunnels feel claustrophobic, but the outside feels dangerous and inhospitable. At the two first times I played the game, I opted for Russian dialogues, to add to the immersion factor; now, I'm playing it in English, so I won't be so bothered with reading subtitles.

It is so clearly is a work of love from its developers, the Malta-based Ukranian 4A Games, which went through hell with this war and had to relocate its developers. By playing this game, I cannot help but to think about them, and what they've been put through.

May wars everywhere end forever. And may they only exist in movies and video games.

Snowy wasteland is the coolest setting. The characters and story are drenched in charm amidst a post-apocalyptic, radiation, and mutant infested backdrop. Well worth a play if you're into a single player fps with a fantastic story set in a world devastated by a toxic wasteland. Don't let the dated look deter you, it's not that bad and the story plus the actual gameplay is worth it. Give the journal entries a read for insight into Artyom's thoughts and more about the world/himself/his friends and fellow rangers. These games are based on books and have a lot of quotable moments. The ones from Khan are my personal favorite.

"Metro 2033 Redux" is a stunning revisitation of the dark and oppressive world of post-apocalyptic Moscow. With revamped graphics and improved gameplay, it offers an immersive experience that immerses players in an engaging narrative, based on the book by Dmitry Glukhovsky. Resource management and the dynamic between stealth and combat intensify immersion, although linearity and difficulty can pose challenges. Overall, it's a tense and thrilling journey through a dystopian universe, providing captivating moments from beginning to end.

And many more improvements.

The ending to the game is anti-climatic, you have this sort of a buildup, but then there is no big fight, honestly I wished that there would be a big fight with all of the monsters. I like all the little gameplay elements such as limited HUD, wiping blood/rain/fog from the gas mask, the lighter and map, having to charge your flashlight, and then your watch. Gunplay isn’t the best but with limited ammo and little light the fights could get intense. Also it had some interesting weapons. Story was fairly decent. What I really enjoyed too was how intense the game could be. The supernatural parts were handled pretty well too I thought. The part where you have to move through the building while keeping eye contact with those monsters was great.

I don't think I've had to play a level more than twice so far. Overall, I like the game.

Played through this half a dozen times on console. IMO, despite some jank, the Metro series is one of if not the best atmospheric single player shooters on the market. Little touches really sell the environment, like wiping off your mask, and there are some genuinely tense moments that might have you sweating (friendly advice: you should definitely be playing on the hardest difficulty). Plus, at this point 4A is practically giving the games away, so no reason not to pick it up.

Highly recommended! This is one of the few solo, first-person shooters that I really enjoyed playing (of course, the other one that I enjoyed even more was Metro Redux Enhanced version). This trilogy of the games seem to hit a sweet spot of being spooky enough, challenging, not too easy but not ridiculously hard to play, with interesting characters and story-lines. The latter Metro releases have all these elements enhanced, reworked, and made even better. You do feel, at times, alone, cold, helpless, creeped out, spooked, frightened, and so on all through the series. Again, the latter games developed all these qualities and made them a lot smoother and more immersive.

Lessons learned: You don't have to go through your Steam backlog. It doesn't matter if you didn't check all the must-plays on the list and it's ok to skip the first game of a series. 

This is another one of those games people still recommend in the 2020's and refer to as the best yadida but to me the gameplay, characters and story are SO BORING every hour progressing through the monotonous different environments (I counted three: dirty tunnels, dirty city in ruins and dirty empty buildings that are sometimes offices and not offices) felt to me like a total waste of time. 

Now that would be totally OK the gunplay wasn't so bland and unimpactful. The gist of combat is to either use stealth when possible, trigger or wait for a monster standing-like-an-idiot behavior so you can get a headshot (just spend all your ammo, that's cool too). Repeatedly for 6 hours while listening to some NPC's boring you to death. 

In fact it's only scary because the autosaves force you to hear the same childish dialogue lines over and over at the beginning of each scripted peak difficulty events (there aren't that many). 

And last, you know how those games with slow narrative full of mystery make you wonder if the end will suck, answer zero questions or redeem the whole experience, but it's just wishful thinking? Well. Guess what.

Dated and a bit awkward to play, but the atmosphere is worth it.  Setting is very interesting and is really the main point of the game.  Honestly parts of it play more like a horror game than a FPS.  Highly recommend if you're into post-apocalyptic stories or existentially depressing settings.

100% difficulty: Medium
100% time: Medium

You'll need to play the whole game at least twice to 100% it.  Luckily all the levels can be replayed individually so level-specific achievements aren't extremely annoying.  There's a hidden morality system in this game that affects your ending (which is also tied to achievements), so my recommendation would be to play the game once to experience it yourself and then use a guide to ensure you get the other ending on your following playthrough.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Metro 2033 Redux is an absolute gem in the world of gaming. This remastered version of the original Metro 2033 not only brings enhanced visuals but also delivers an immersive and gripping experience that few games can match.

The game's strength lies in its atmospheric storytelling. The post-apocalyptic world of Metro 2033 is hauntingly beautiful, with every dimly lit tunnel and desolate surface telling a story of survival and desperation. The attention to detail in the environments, coupled with the subtle narrative cues, creates a truly immersive experience that keeps you on the edge of your seat.

The dark and claustrophobic metro tunnels, infested with mutated creatures, set the stage for intense and nerve-wracking encounters. The game masterfully blends survival horror elements with a compelling narrative, making each step forward a tense and unpredictable journey. The scarcity of resources adds another layer of challenge, forcing players to carefully manage their supplies and make tough decisions.

The character development and world-building in Metro 2033 Redux are exceptional. Artyom's journey is not just about survival; it's a voyage through a society struggling to exist in the aftermath of a devastating nuclear war. The diverse cast of characters you encounter adds depth to the narrative, making you genuinely care about their fates.

The Redux version's improved graphics and optimized gameplay mechanics enhance the overall experience, bringing the game to a new level of visual and technical excellence. Whether you're a fan of first-person shooters, survival horror, or narrative-driven games, Metro 2033 Redux offers a perfect blend of these genres.

In summary, Metro 2033 Redux stands as a testament to the power of atmospheric storytelling in gaming. It's a must-play for anyone who appreciates a rich narrative, immersive world-building, and heart-pounding survival challenges. This game has rightfully earned its place among the classics in the gaming industry.

[h1] Metro 2033 Redux - A Gripping Descent into Post-Apocalyptic Darkness [/h1]

Graphics: ★★★★☆
Metro 2033 Redux features a significant visual overhaul, with improved textures, lighting effects, and character models. The atmospheric design of the Moscow Metro system is hauntingly immersive, capturing the bleakness and despair of a post-apocalyptic world. While not cutting-edge, the graphical enhancements contribute to the overall atmosphere.

Gameplay: ★★★★☆
The gameplay in Metro 2033 Redux combines first-person shooting with survival horror elements. The scarcity of resources, including ammunition and filters for your gas mask, creates a tense and immersive experience. The gunplay feels weighty, and the stealth mechanics add variety to encounters. However, some may find the controls slightly clunky compared to more modern shooters.

Story: ★★★★★
Based on Dmitry Glukhovsky's novel, Metro 2033 Redux weaves a compelling narrative set in the aftermath of a nuclear apocalypse. The story is rich in atmosphere, exploring themes of survival, morality, and the consequences of humanity's actions. The well-developed characters and the exploration of the dark tunnels of the Moscow Metro contribute to a narrative that is both captivating and thought-provoking.

Soundtrack: ★★★★★
The haunting and atmospheric soundtrack of Metro 2033 Redux enhances the game's immersive qualities. The ambient sounds of the metro, the echoes of distant screams, and the subtle musical cues all contribute to a chilling and memorable audio experience. The use of sound plays a crucial role in building tension and conveying the oppressive atmosphere of the game.

Level Design: ★★★★☆
The level design in Metro 2033 Redux is a mix of linear tunnels and more open areas on the surface. The claustrophobic metro tunnels contrast with the desolate landscapes above ground, offering a varied and visually interesting world to explore. The attention to detail in the environments adds to the overall sense of immersion.

Replayability: ★★★☆☆
While Metro 2033 Redux offers multiple endings based on player choices, the linear nature of the narrative and the scarcity of resources may limit replayability for some. However, the gripping story and the immersive atmosphere may still encourage some players to revisit the Moscow Metro for a second or third playthrough.

Overall: ★★★★☆
Metro 2033 Redux is a testament to the power of storytelling in video games. With its atmospheric graphics, engaging narrative, and chilling soundtrack, it successfully delivers an immersive post-apocalyptic experience. While the gameplay mechanics may show signs of age, the overall package makes Metro 2033 Redux a must-play for fans of atmospheric shooters and narrative-driven games.

As a fan of the original game, I find the Redux is a welcome re-polish of the original game. I was impressed with the game's ability to capture the feeling given by the novels it's based upon. There's an overwhelming feeling of gritty desperation in the art style that conveys the mental image of what living underground in subway tunnels would truly be like, especially in the older tunnels of post Soviet Russia. The game delivers a solid survival/action experience I would compare to The Last of Us in terms of depth and development.

Final words for this title? It's worth it. As the first game of a trilogy it sets the story and tone for the following titles, and it does it in a way that entertains with simple mechanics that make you feel like you're clawing your way through mutant infested tunnels.

Технічно гра непогана, був здивований, бо спершу проходив третю частину, а зараз вирішив першу. І майже все було взято з цієї першої частини, але просто кращі текстури і розвиток сюжету. 

Категорично не сподобалося сюжетне розкриття "антагоніста" і кінцівки. Просто задонать на початку кілька дорогоцінних пуль бомжам, нікого не вбивай (В ШУТЕРІ ТВОЮМАТІНКУНЕХАЙ), або просто вирубай їх ударом з локоточка, і тоді в тебе буде хороша кінцівка. При цьому, більшість ворогів - прибічники ворожих, небезпечних фракцій, і залюбки вбили б вас у спину. А стелс-механіка працює на рівні атарві і викінь. В дізоноред наприклад набагато краще продумано цей момент, і якщо наприклад нікого не вбивати - це, по-перше, дозволить головному герою прославитися і заробити хорошу репутацію, адже він був помічником королеви чи кого там, по-друге - більшість ворогів - це лише звичайні люди, які залежать від влади і її наказів. В метро у нас просто треба бути хорошим (що максимально не реалістично, і якщо це дань книзі, то це тупорила дань, бо книгу написати може кожен, наділити долею героя, прєдназначєніє і тому подібне, додали б ще поні туди чи шо). Якщо ти будеш вбивати противників, то в тебе буде погана кінцівка. 

Стосовно кінцівки - конфлікт з чорними ніяк не розкривається. Вони просто погані і повинні померти. Я не читав усіх заміток, але якщо сюжет про них був розказаний в цих замітках, то це тільки погіршує ситуацію. Давайте замість кіно читати книжки, клас! Чи дають нам вибір, якби ми через сюжет зрозуміли, що вони, наприклад, не погані? Не дають, ми просто типу зомбовані, і якщо погано себе поводили - то всьо, погана кінцівка. Чи були до цього вибори, які спричинили нашу зомбацію? Не було, хіба що вибором можна назвати стиль гри. Спершу буде реп без рим, потім п*р*о без баб, а потім - шутер без пострілів. Занадто тупо і однобоко. А шкода. 

А ще є баги. Деякі ключі не заспавнились. Ну і кривувато загалом. Напевно, для свого часу це було класно, але зараз це розчарування.

Metro 2033 Redux Edition offers a gripping and immersive experience set in a post-apocalyptic world. The game, based on Dmitry Glukhovsky's novel, has been enhanced and revamped in the Redux edition, providing players with improved graphics, gameplay mechanics, and overall polish.

From the very beginning, the game establishes a unique and atmospheric tone. The opening scenes thrust you into the desolate and dark world of the Moscow Metro, setting the stage for the challenges and horrors that lie ahead. The revamped graphics immediately catch the eye, portraying a hauntingly beautiful but dangerous environment that begs exploration.

As you progress, the game's atmospheric world-building becomes increasingly apparent. The attention to detail in the metro stations, the desolate landscapes above ground, and the mutated creatures that roam the tunnels contribute to an immersive storytelling experience. The Redux edition's enhanced visuals showcase the eerie beauty of this post-apocalyptic setting, making every moment visually striking.

The gameplay in Metro 2033 Redux seamlessly blends intense first-person shooter action with survival horror elements. From the outset, ammunition is scarce, encouraging players to think strategically about resource management. The diverse array of weapons and customization options allows for different approaches to combat, adding depth to the overall gameplay.

The narrative unfolds as a dark and compelling story, exploring themes of survival, morality, and the consequences of human actions in the face of extreme adversity. The characters you encounter are well-developed, and their stories contribute to the emotional weight of the overall narrative.

Playing Metro 2033 Redux at night elevates the experience to a new level. The carefully crafted lighting and shadow effects, coupled with the game's haunting ambient soundtrack, intensify the sense of isolation and fear. The subdued lighting and environmental details create a captivating ambiance, making nighttime gameplay a uniquely immersive and spine-chilling experience.

In essence, Metro 2033 Redux may not showcase the pinnacle of 2023 graphics, but its ability to deliver a compelling narrative, engaging gameplay, and a truly atmospheric experience sets it apart. It proves that a game's appeal goes beyond cutting-edge visuals, offering a testament to the timeless power of well-crafted storytelling and gameplay.

The Early 2010's. The Peak of first person shooters with compelling narratives with immersive worlds to dive into. Metro 2033 was a game i've seen and heard about. At first, I didn't think much about it. Back then when this game originally came out, I was over the whole zombies apocalypse stuff you'd see being pumped out year in and year out. Every company wanted to be like Call of duty black ops zombies. It got really repetitive, and saturated. Metro 2033 redux is a very compelling story were your world is infested with monsters. It's a world where you cannot breath the air since it's polluted with harmful toxins. You always have to put your safety mask on, and it makes me appreciate the fact that you can go outside and breath the air without the fear of suffocation. 

The gameplay is simple, you basically shoot the demon monsters. There are humans that will hunt you down to stop your progress to reach to Polis. On the way you'll meet up with other comrades and see how they live underground. The community, the people, kids. How they all live underground, and you feel for them. Like how did life get all sh** like this? Even though this is a fictional world, it makes you wonder. If life got so bad, could it ever turn out to be like this? Like if all computers failed, and everything went corrupt. What would life be like with limited resources? This game makes you think if there are ways to overcome an apocalypse, and thats essentially the mission in this game. 

I never read the books that this game was based off, but I really do want to now. I really like the world, although depressing. You see another side to Moscow Russia that you would have never imagined, and that vision was done perfectly for Metro 2033 redux. I'd HIGHLY recommend this game, if you want a story that will you grab your attention to the very end. You MUST Check out Metro 2033 Redux. Love this game, and I think it's VERY underrated

One of the best FPS I've played fr

Metro 2033 , where to even start

first, the game is GREAT very immersive for the most part, I say that because of the very noticeable bugs that are scattered around the game. It's nothing game breaking if you're worried, minor things like characters clipping forward while running, bricks staying in the air, so on. what also kind of breaks the immersion is the occasionally corny and poorly acted voices. Its mainly the children and some side characters, but switching the audio to the Russian dub gives it more of a authentic feeling.

I often times find myself confused during playing some FPS games of where to go, Metro's compass has fixed this issue for me buy actually being really accurate and reliable. The game plays very smoothly, with INCREDIBLE gun play, movement and mechanics. 

Metro's story is also very well written as a whole, probably since the writer of the original novel was on the writing team, some dialog felt a bit clunky and fell off some times but it really is not that bad. 

Was this game good? Yes.

[h1]Metro 2033 Redux is not a linear STALKER but instead a Call of Duty campaign with STALKER atmosphere and ideas.[/h1]

[h3]Settings:[/h3]
[list]
[*]Played on Survival + Ranger Hardcore
[*]Crosshair off
[*]Hints off
[*]Max graphics; advanced PhysX
[/list]

[h3]Expectations:[/h3]

I was expecting a linear STALKER with how major fans talk up this game and talk about its similarity to STALKER. I expected that I would be missing some information about how the game is played due to turning off hints, but I was recommended the above settings by the accompanying Metro Discord community.

[h2]Pros:[/h2]
[list]
[*]Environments are delightfully interactable and fully featured. lots of little cool details; lots of it occurs via voice acting, which can be hit or miss
[*]There's a ton of little conversations here and there between characters that you can easily miss (that are actually interesting and not pointless drivel like other games)
[*]Visuals are fantastic
[*]Actual human vs human combat is pretty solid and reminiscent of STALKER in how dangerous it can be.
[*]Silhouettes, anomalies, etc are really reminiscent of STALKER
[*]Neat details of looting, like pushing corpses over to get access to pockets 
[*]The later parts of the game where you are no longer handheld are pretty good. A bit tough to handle due to the sheer amount of enemies, but handleable and fun. Very linear though
[*]Scorpions are cool as FUCK and a super smart use of the flashlight
[/list]

[h2]Cons:[/h2]
[list]
[*]QOL/Bugs
[list]
[*]Boot up sequence takes you a full minute to get to the main menu. I'm not exaggerating.
[*]Intro/end cutscene is 30 fps
[*]There's the normal difficulty selection when you start a new game, but there's also Normal and Hardcore in the options. There is no explanation for this; I had to ask in the Discord
[*]Subtitles are extremely large for no reason
[*]In the mission where you get to the library, there is a trap that has an invisible trigger. It's debris falling from the library. There is no hint/signal anywhere that this is a trap, just kinda happens.
[*]If you shoot lurkers as they come out of the tunnel and kill them instantly, they finish the animation of exiting the tunnel and THEN die. Lurkers also have issues with frequent random clipping into the ground, making them invincible when they approach you as your bullets don't hit them.
[/list]

[*]AI & NPCs
[list]
[*]Friendly NPCs dont walk/run as fast as you
[*]NPC dialogue (so far) is tending to be on the CoD side of trying to be badass over realistic (STALKER does this too)
[*]The voice acting is really bad at times (STALKER does this too)
[*]Khan's (a friendly NPC in the game) mysterious shtick is just honestly really annoying lol
[*]Often enemies will only attack you and not friendly AI, even when said friendlies are in the way between the monster and you
[/list]

[*]Game & Enemy Design
[list]
[*]Game begins with an intro where you climb up a rusty ladder which breaks and barely get caught in time. Not a good first impression unless you're trying to set the tone for a generic linear shooter (this is 5D foreshadowing rofl)
[*]You are handheld by AI for almost every encounter in the first 3-4 hours of the game.
[*]Red flashing constantly when you are immensely hurt. It doesn't stop until you get health. WHY?
[*]This game is not immersive. Running from 15+ cops firing assault weapons at me and magically dodging them all as well as watching a friendly jump-stab a Nazi (that he could've shot) who was about to execute me is fucking Call of Duty tier shit, not an "immersive shooter". It's about as immersive as Wolfenstein.
[*]Melee hitreg is awful. Speaking of melee combat, if you sneak up on someone and try to backstab, it'll do the animation even though the regular melee is an instant kill. This can cause scenarios where the animation is screwing you over because it gives enemies too much time to potentially see you and blow your cover.
[*]STEALTH: Not Good. The stealth AI is awful, and they're terrible at clearing a room; they seem to not be able to see you if you aren't in the path of their searchlight, which is serviceable if your stealth sequences are at night, but one stealth sequence was at sunset, and they definitely should've seen me but didn't. Also, there is a three minute (at best) uninterrupted stealth sequence where you have to sneak through the Communists' side of a warzone and then the Nazis' side of the warzone. It's awful and I had to exploit dumb AI in order to do it. There is no checkpoint for a very long time (much longer than what is normal for the game). Suppressors also don't make a noticeable difference on your ability to be stealthy (hello???).
[*]The Librarians are cool in concept, but the effect it has of you having to memorize where the holes and doors are while one slowly stalks you and the other is flanking you is awful.
[/list]
[/list]

[h3]Cons Specific to My Settings[/h3]
My difficulty options, while more immersive, did actually end up affecting my experience of the game. Here are some of the various issues I encountered that I am certain or at least believe stem from my setting selection.
[list]
[*]No UI showing for QTEs. i just had to spam M1, W, and E and guess one of them will do the trick lol
[*]I've had to look up multiple times how to do basic things like how to select my throwing knives. Can't do it though cuz no weapon wheel. 
[*]You cannot aim down sights with the shotgun. This is only bad because you don't have a crosshair.
[*]Looting consists of mashing E everywhere; ammo and other resources don't stand out enough to be selective about where you press E.
[*]Friendly NPCs (whom you fight with a LOT) do not do as much damage as you (they do more like a quarter of the damage you do); it's generally a good idea to let them do most of the fighting (which isn't immersive) and stay a distance away to avoid wasting ammo, only using it to help yourself. This is most important in the end-game after you leave for the library due to there not being another ammo shop past this point. Had some pretty major close calls with ammo.
[*]Hold M and then press right click to bring up your HUD and ammo counts. I did not know this was a thing at all until the very end of the game.
[*]You can charge your flashlight by holding F and then clicking mouse 1. I didn't know this was a thing until I accidentally held F for too long.
[*]You cannot carry a third weapon. It says you can in the binds, but you can't due to the Ranger Hardcore difficulty.
[*]It appears that there's some sort of moral system in place; this is not made obvious to you if you are not familiar with the game already. I noticed it due to musical cues, but it's very easy to miss.
[/list]

[h2]Conclusion:[/h2]
Metro 2033 is not STALKER. I'd say it's not even close enough comparatively for fans of STALKER's gameplay to enjoy it. What I will say is that it fills a middle ground if someone was put off by STALKER's sheer difficulty and slower-paced gameplay, but wanted to experience the atmosphere and ideas. I don't hate Metro 2033, but I definitely don't love it. If I want COD, I'd play COD. If I want STALKER, I'm playing STALKER.
People say that Metro: Last Light is just 2033 with a new story, so I think I'll be avoiding it and just moving onto Exodus.

Finally a game that follows accurately novel, and add some extra lore to it. It's visually beautiful, atmospheric and gloomy. Lot of attention to details too, especially to the stations which were amazingly recereated from their real life counterparts and then weathered down. 
Not many downsides, apart from the "karma" system, getting a good ending is rather difficult, and even in this playtrough (first two were in regular Metro 2033) I failed to achieve it.

I played this one after Metro Exodus, and a lot of things about the game I wouldn't have been able to figure out without having played the later one first; the in-game help/tutorial systems are pretty lacking in this one.

That being said, it is a great game!  I wish there was more lore about the Dark Ones, but it's probably covered in the books (which I haven't read).  Still room for an interesting future prequel maybe.
