[h1][b]Content[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 20/20[/b]

Metro 2033 Redux typically takes 10 to 12 hours to complete the main storyline. Players who explore and immerse themselves in the game's atmosphere may spend over 15 hours, while those focusing solely on the main story can finish in around 8 to 10 hours. Overall, playtime varies based on individual preferences.

[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 13/20[/b]

Metro 2033 Redux features dynamic gameplay elements that complement its gripping narrative. Survival is paramount as players manage a gas mask and filters, emphasizing the harsh post-apocalyptic environment. A robust weapon customization system allows for personalized arsenals, and a currency system based on high-value bullets introduces a risk-reward dynamic. The adaptive enemy AI keeps encounters unpredictable, demanding varied strategies. These gameplay nuances, including the dynamic environment, survival mechanics, weapon customization, currency system, and adaptive AI, contribute to an immersive and challenging post-apocalyptic experience unlike any other. However, there are quite a few drawbacks.
 
Let's now address the flaws of the gameplay aspect of Metro 2033 Redux, which stands out as a significant weakness in this Redux package. The gameplay remains unchanged from the original release and feels outdated and clunky. While the developers didn't make notable improvements, addressing these minor issues could have significantly improved the overall experience. The input from the keyboard and mouse seem detached, especially noticeable at higher difficulty levels. The interactive elements also fall short of modern gaming standards, sometimes resembling a game from the early 2000s rather than a newer title. Although the object interaction functions correctly most of the time, there are instances where it frustratingly fails to react as intended. Managing items in close proximity becomes an annoyance, with the game often selecting the wrong thing. Navigating ladders can be problematic as well.

The game's combat mechanics, particularly mutant attacks, exhibit glitches, making it challenging to evade damage despite quick reactions. Two-thirds of all mutant attacks seem unavoidable, leading to accumulating frustration. Throwable items, like explosive grenades, suffer from their own specific issues, making precise throws impossible. However, molotovs and knives perform as expected. In close combat scenarios, the melee weapon proves useless once you run out of bullets, and attempting to escape may not always be a viable solution. A tip: conserve ammo and use your companion soldiers as shields when necessary. Unfortunately, the absence of a FOV (Field of View - TotalBiscuit's biggest nightmare) slider is notable. Attempts to adjust FOV values in the config file can lead to unsatisfactory results, pulling the camera back to the point of breaking animations. Consequently, sticking with the original FOV is recommended to maintain a visually pleasing experience.

[h1][b]Presentation[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 15/20[/b]

Regarding graphics quality, the game's atmosphere and surroundings stand out as the main positive aspects. However, outdoor environments appear somewhat flat and incomplete compared to indoor areas. Additionally, the lack of customizable graphical options is a notable drawback. It's worth mentioning occasional flashing visual glitches indoors and outdoors. The soundtrack complements the story well and is a strong point. Weapon sounds are impressive, dialogue is decent, and ambient sounds contribute to a realistic atmosphere. On the downside, Artyom's grunting sounds during actions like jumping seem mismatched, detracting from the overall experience.

Crowd and enemy dialogue, initially bearable, becomes repetitive upon closer inspection. Regarding visuals, examining the crowd reveals that a significant portion consists of identical models with minor variations in hairstyles and outfits. This lack of diversity can be immersion-breaking for those who notice such details. The game's animation system generally meets expectations for the genre and scale of the game. However, mutant animations are subpar and fall flat compared to the rest of the presentation. The inaccurate movement occasionally leads to missed melee attacks or jumps, as I discussed in the gameplay section.

[h1][b]Story[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 20/20[/b]

Metro 2033 Redux is a gripping first-person shooter set in the post-apocalyptic ruins of Moscow. Two decades after a devastating nuclear war, survivors now inhabit the underground metro tunnels, struggling to survive against mutated creatures and hostile factions. As Artyom, a young man born before the apocalypse, players embark on a dangerous journey across the desolate metro system. Artyom's quest becomes a brutal exploration of the human spirit in the face of extinction. The game combines intense combat, atmospheric storytelling, and a hauntingly immersive world to deliver a memorable experience in the haunting depths of a shattered society. The narrative stands out as a unique and exceptional experience in gaming, with no similar title coming close to its originality. The numerous small pieces contribute to a captivating storyline, seamlessly transitioning and expanding into Metro: Last Light.

However, when it comes to the replay value, unless you're one of those gamers dedicated to unlocking every achievement, there's not much to it after the initial playthrough. Worth noting is that Metro 2033 is not that type of game. While the game features collectibles, such as safes containing bullets and notes resembling journals that enhance the story's depth, the overall gameplay is relatively linear. Beyond a handful of brief side activities, the freedom of traversal is limited. The characters you interact with have depth and don't just fill the area, and every detail serves a purpose, be it in gameplay or story. The game revolves around small, dark, and narrow tunnels and does an exceptional job of creating an atmosphere that feels real and engaging. Despite some shortcomings, the strength of the narrative and the attractive metro environments compensate well for any drawbacks.

[h1][b]Technicalities[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 17/20[/b]

Even upon its initial launch, the game's system requirements were high, and that release frequently served as a benchmark. Back then, if a system could handle Metro 2033 and the original Crysis, it could play anything. All Metro games, including this one, need powerful PC hardware, a point worth noting. While the Redux version should run smoothly on modern hardware, it's advisable to bear this in mind. Upon launching the game for the first time, something will be missing. Hmmm, what could it be? Vsync! Even on high-refresh-rate monitors, Metro 2033 Redux caps itself at 60 FPS.

Despite attempting various methods to remove this FPS cap with Vsync enabled (on a 165Hz Gsync monitor), nothing appears to work. Nvidia's Fast Sync in the control panel proves ineffective, and modifications to the configuration file don't produce positive results either. Consequently, there are two ways to play the game: either tolerate the 60 FPS cap with Vsync enabled (which, frankly, feels less smooth and underutilizes the system's potential for a higher framerate) or deal with unattractive screen tearing by disabling Vsync and unlocking the framerate. The FPS cap is about the only bad thing tech-wise.

[h1][b]Final Verdict[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 85/100[/b]

Metro 2033 Redux combines an impressive narrative and improved visuals, puts them carefully into some of the most captivating and unique locations in any video game, and mixes it with unimpressive gameplay that doesn't take away from its unforgettable experience that will forever stay in your memory. Although I wish to assign a higher overall score to this game, some issues prevent it from rising to the top, as an example of what each game of a similar nature should strive to be.

Metro 2033 has an unmatched atmosphere. The dark, narrow, mysterious tunnels filled with a neverending fear of something jumping on me. The emptiness of Moscow where life ceased to exist a long time ago. The stations where people live from day to day. It's terrifying to see how people struggle to survive and how they are forced to live after a nuclear war. It's ironic how something that we humans created can very well make us live like rats one day and even then we wouldn't stop slaughtering each other. I liked the idea that if there was only 2 of us left in the whole metro, one of us would still have a knife behind their back to slit the throat of the other at any given time... that humans just can't stop war no matter what happens. Metro 2033 is truly an exceptional game.

[h1]What I liked[/h1]
The story is interesting, thanks to the novel it is based on. In the beginning of every level, there is a book-styled note that tells us main character thoughts. I thinks its great.

Graphics are very beautiful.

Music and sounds are great.

[h1]What I didn't like[/h1]
First of all, there are no manual saves, only checkpoints. It is a big problem, because checkpoints are not always placed correctly, and it's annoying to re-spawn at the middle of the level when you almost completed it, but accidentally died.

Secondly, weapons behavior is a bit questionable. It takes 1 magazine of automatic rifle, or 4 shotgun shells to kill a monster, but killing the same monster with tiny revolver takes only 2 bullets.

Thirdly, stealth is awkward. When you stand, enemies notice you even through a concrete wall. When you crouch, you can be almost in front of enemies eyes and they will not see you.

Great story and setting.

Definitely worth playing.

[h1]DO NOT SUPPORT DEEP SILVER (The Publisher)![/H1]

"Paradox of Hope", a game in which a single developer worked on for 4 years was recently DMCA'd by the publisher DEEP SILVER (a multi-billion dollar company). The sole creator of 'Paradox of Hope' owns the intellectual property rights to the game. While the game drew inspiration from certain mechanics and visuals, it did not use any assets from other games, and thus, did not infringe on anyone's copyright. 

Despite NOT providing hard evidence to support their claim, the game was de-listed from the Steam store. The developer suffered mental health trauma as a result and has no money to battle it in court (vs a mega company). 

Research Paradox of Hope. Do NOT "buy" anything published by DEEP SILVER. Don't support companies that use their money and legal teams to actively ruin other people's lives.

Be warned, this is a mediocre PC port and you will require external mods to make the controls enjoyable/playable:
Here's the mod I use: https://community.pcgamingwiki.com/files/file/966-metro-mouse-fix/

Here are the main problems this game has:
-The game doesn't use raw mouse input (fixed by mod)
-The vertical sensitivity is reduced vs horizontal (fixed by mod)
-The FOV is too low (fixed by editing config file, see steam guides)
-Aiming doesnt have a seperate lower sensitivity (unfixed)

what i enjoyed most about the first entry in the Metro series was the astonishingly beautiful post-apocalyptic environment. The storytelling has triumphant and explosive moments, and keeps you guessing what sort of nightmarish creature is around each corner. This game sets itself apart from other FPS experiences by incorporating small realistic mechanics such as charging up your manual crank-battery night vision and flashlight, as well as keeping track of gas mask and filter quality, which is of vital importance in areas that have a dangerous atmosphere. I enjoyed the combat and the designs of the creatures and especially the winged 'Demons'!

Phenomenal... personally still regarded as the best game ever made, in the days where games didn't come with 60 euros expansions and were just a seperate game series. If you want a realistic story, try this game. Below you might find spoilers so be warned.

So... I've been thinking why this game is so good, and after about a couple years of on-and-off thinking about it, I've come to the following conclusion. This game puts you in control of of a nobody. A man with a simple life, who's been thrusted into the world of the Metro, doing unspeakable things, but all the way until you meet the Rangers, you're a complete nobody just traveling through. All the struggles, all the backdraft... Everything is so realistic and it makes it so unique. Your choices are your own, and determine your faith. And every encounter feels like it could be realistic, and killing too quick might actually not get you the ending you want.

This is one of those games that gives you pleasure to play, an apocalyptic, frozen and desolate world, where there is no hope of life, you only have yourself, a survivor and a lighter, your best friend, to burn cobwebs and light up in moments of absolute darkness.
An endless war between factions, which takes you at times to be part of it, but if you want to experience terror, I am going to say one word to you, Librarians.
This is where you understand the wonder and magnitude of the game, the background music is an invitation to walk with death and you will wish (and I say this from my own experience) that none of them wake up.

I wanted to wait till I finished my first playthrough of this game but I just can't, this game is just too good. The story is amazing and thought-provoking, it respects the player and expects them to figure out what to do like a real game should (Although some sections of the game are really unfair as it's not super obvious), the atmosphere compliments the story really well, all of these elements combined makes for a game where you truly feel like you're playing as the main character that's in this world that has turned into utter madness, whers everyone keeps telling you how terrible and how bad it is, asking you if you think humanity will ever leave the metro. But on the other hand, there's also still a little bit of hope as some people still have faith that one day, things will change. Absolute masterpiece and one of my current favourite games of all time (haven't even finished the game)

Highly recommended if you like the environmental storytelling of something like Half-Life, Dishonored or Bioshock. Extra recommendation if you like shooters.
I don't really care for post apocalypse games, but the story and world in this game are truly unique and I really enjoy the mature/nuanced story that it tells. I cannot recommend this game enough to someone who likes shooters that have great stories. 9/10

TOP FUN THINGS TO DO:
⭐️ Exploring this post-apocalyptic world.
⭐️ Feeling overrun with hell beasts.
⭐️ Hardcore ranger mode will test your skills.

THE UNIQUES:
💎 Some weapons / gadgets require to be pumped.
💎 Playing things stealthily and passive will reward you moral points.
💎 Immense story.

PLAYER GAMING REQUIREMENTS:
💼 FPS.
💼 Post-apocalyptic.
💼 Story Rich.

PROS:
+ A huge upgrade from the original Metro 2033 version. (Look up the comparisons on YouTube)
+ Deep survival elements, bullets are scarce (In ranger mode) and attacks laid on you are impactful it's truly the best way to play Metro.
+ Military bullets are treated as currency.
+ Weaponry feels detailed with it's post-apocalyptic to thank for. Aka, some weapons require to be pumped.
+ Enemies attack with speed, which enhances your reactions.
+ It's atmospheric to the final detail, the fog setting once outside the tunnels all the way to wiping the blood and grime from your gas-mask to see.
+ The story is good enough to be turned into a movie, there's already books about it so a movie wouldn't be a huge stretch.

CONS:
- It's a short game. (About 9 hours to complete)
- Modding your weapons is a little lacking.
- Shooting from the hip feels most effective.... which I don't like.

VERDICT:
I'm here to say that this game deserves every positive review it receives, I never had the honour to play it's original release but the Redux version is truly a masterpiece to the Metro collection. If you have this game sitting in your library, don't hesitate any longer, you're missing out on a game of a lifetime. Same to the players who don't own this, it's cheap enough to obtain and well worth your time. If I realised this sooner, I would've played Metro 2033 many years ago.

Total Score = 93/100.

GAMEPLAY:
The story is based on Dmitry Glukhovsky's novel of the same name, where survivors of a nuclear war have taken refuge in the Metro tunnels of Moscow. Players control Artyom, a man who must save his home station from the dangers lurking within the Metro. In the game, players encounter human and mutant enemies, who can be killed with a variety of firearms. Players must also wear a gas mask to explore areas covered in fallout radiation, both underground and on the surface.

SIMILAR GAME LIKE THIS? / REVIEWER PREVIOUS EXPERIENCE:
Metro franchise, S.T.A.L.K.E.R, Fallout franchise.

■■■■■■■■■□ 9 / 10
Some call them Demons, I call them Bitches!

RECOMMEDED SPECS
OS: Windows 7 or better
Processor: Any Quad Core
Memory: 4 GB RAM
Graphics: GeForce GTX 480
Storage: 10 GB available space
Do you like atmosphere and being depressed? Me too, play the game.

You go on the surface with three air filters for the mask.

Snow, mud, water dirty your mask and obstruct your vision. You wipe the visor with your hand and encounter a mutant dog running towards you; you shoot, attracting the rest of the pack. Their howling sends shivers down your spine.

The first filter is gone; you replace it with the second.

Entering a swamp on your way to your objective, every step splashes mud on the visor. Remove the mask, and the air suffocates you. Shadows of flying things pass by; the sound of flapping wings gets closer. Your ammo deals little damage. Run or shoot? Running will wear out your air filter faster; shooting means running out of ammo later. Metro people call them Demons. "Some call them Demons. I call them bastards." - Bourbon

The second filter is gone; you put on the last one.

Your life depends on the dead. Your hope is to find something useful in the corpses of less fortunate people. A stalker who left the Metro and never returned; The skeleton of a couple with their small child who died watching nuclear bombs detonate in Moscow's sky; An advanced unit obliterated by some creature. The resources they left behind may help you avoid ending up like them.

Your third filter is gone, but you find another on the putrid corpse of an old explorer.

You could go back to the tunnels and be relieved to find some bandit group; at least they're still human. But you realize you're in an abandoned Metro station. Lurkers roam where your flashlight doesn't reach, attacking from behind and fleeing. If you run, you fall into their holes and become their meal. You pass by them and the corpses, walk deeper into the tunnels, encountering voices and shadows, remnants of people going to work before the war or soldiers defending their posts. They don't know they're dead.

Your last filter will only last one more minute.

You run through the tunnels, trying to go deeper and escape the toxic air on the surface. Nosalises attack; you have an AK magazine with 11 rounds and 3 in the revolver. They descend from tunnel walls, coming from both front and back. You have 30 seconds of air now. They leap, and you give them butt strokes. Four AK rounds left, your grenades are gone. How many kilometers to the next station? Will there be someone friendly there? Will there be anyone there?

Super fun game! Played it on my Steam Deck and it worked really well. Achievements are not hard to get but it takes a while since you need to finish it at least twice

TLDR:  Shooter/survival-horror than was more frustrating than horrifying

So, while I was perusing Steam sales one day, I came on Metro 2033 Redux on sale. I'd read a lot about Metro Exodus and the shenanigans with Steam and the Epic Game store, but I'd heard good things about this one and thought I would give it a try. While I can't say it was horrible, I didn't really care for it.

Metro 2033 takes place in Moscow, after a nuclear war has devastated the surface. Survivors have taken refuge in the tunnels of the Moscow subway, turning stations into makeshift habitats. Political factions struggle for control, individual stations struggle for survival, and mutants, bandits, and other dangers lurk in the tunnels between stations, to say nothing of what's going on above ground. The player is cast in the role of Artyom, a young man on a mission to deliver his message to a larger station-village to seek help for own settlement, and the story is off.

Control scheme is fairly standard, as is interaction with objects and individuals. On top of difficulty, there are two game modes: Spartan and Survival. The latter makes Metro 2033 more of a horror-survival game, where Spartan makes more ammo available and makes the character more durable. In theory.

The game's progression is fairly linear as Artyom makes his way through the tunnels and occasional jaunts above ground into the stormy ruin of Moscow. The underground areas are dark and dank and enemies pop out at any time (above ground isn't much better). Some areas are littered with tripwires that ignite painful or fatal traps, though the player can disarm most of these. A handful of these areas have neat and unique challenges, such as the area where the Soviet Reds and reborn Nazis are fighting it out. Both will kill Artyom, so you have to decide to sneak through, or gun them all down, or some blend of the two. There are areas, especially above ground, where Artyom's gas mask is crucial and managing his limited supply of canisters for the mask becomes challenging. At different points, you will have NPC partners, though they generally go their own way after a short period, or get pasted by enemies. The depot stations en route usually offer a place to barter for weapons, ammunition, and other supplies--though, as a side note, .44 Magnum ammunition in Russia felt like a mistake (there is a caliber called ".44 Russian" but Magnum ammo was not commonly used in the country then or now) but I admit, that's just me nitpicking.

Two small things I did like. One, currency in the metro is in the form of military-grade rounds made before the war. These rounds are exchanged for other ammo and supplies. They can also be used in some weapons and are far more powerful than ammo made after the war. This means that when faced with difficult fights, the player must choose whether or not to literally fire money away. I like that dilemma. Two, the player had a handheld charger for their flashlights and night-vision goggles. They must bring it out at times and actually click to re-power their equipment. It's a small touch but beats the items recharging on their own or having to wait for a recharge station or something.

There are beasts to fight and kill, and enemy humans who will do their best to gun down the player. I found the combat to be more frustrating than anything. Combat against humans is relatively straightforward. The mutant enemies, however, seem made of iron. They thrash you around, messing up your camera angle and making it hard to fire. The hit boxes for enemies felt quite small; I repeatedly unloaded double-shotgun blasts into ape-like mutants called nosalis ... only for them to keep attacking. I guess I was missing but seriously? At point-blank range with a shotgun, when they're filling the screen, you ought to hit more than you miss. Even in Spartan mode, ammo is never overly plentiful and you are often attacked by many enemies at a time. You can carry medkits but they are literally too slow to use in combat. Enemies continue ripping you limb from limb for the duration of the two-second healing animation, making it almost pointless, except as a "between waves" thing. Is the delay more realistic? Sure. Does it make for a better game? Debatable.

While in general I didn't mind the combat sequences in the tunnels (even some of the ones set on railcars, the style of which I normally abhor), I hated the ones outdoors, or the outdoor levels in general. Whereas the tunnels are pretty easy to navigate, the outdoor areas are nebulous and there's often no clear direction as to where to go. That would be fine, but for the fact that your rapidly dwindling mask canisters are all that stand between you and suffocating. If you run past a doorway or something, it may take you precious minutes to backtrack and find it, when every second counts. The monsters blend into the scenery even more above ground than in the tunnels. I actually preferred them bounding out of the dark because at least if I got my light on, I could see them. I died multiple times when a monster attacked from a bush and was knocking me around so much I could literally see nothing but red and shrub. Because the game works on a crappy checkpoint save system, that means starting the level over, at least partway.

None of this even mentions the bat-like demons who sweep down and toss you to the ground from high above. Fortunately, to the point I played, they only appeared outdoors.

While the story was generally interesting and the depot "cities" were well-rendered and filled with interesting ambiance (such as listening to all the side conversations of the citizens), I found the heavy Russian accents highly annoying. I mean, the player's character is Russian, all the other characters are Russian, and they won't hear their own accents. It all should have been subtitled with the original language still spoken, or just spoken in plain English. Pet peeve of mine.

I didn't experience any crashes or instability issues. The game seemed to load quickly and run pretty well, so that was nice. I also didn't get a lot of Steam achievements done in my partial run but they all seem doable, just based on reading the descriptions, though it will take at least two play-throughs to get them all (completing a full game each in Spartan and Survival modes).

I made it to Polis Station, which someone told me is about 2/3 of the way through. After dying multiple times in the following segment and exhausting supplies, I realized I just wasn't having fun. Some will say "get good, noob." That's fine. But not for something I'm really not enjoying that much in the first place. I expect players that like the challenge and the horror elements will like this but honestly, I've played survival horror like Bioshock and System Shock 2 that were simply more fun to me.

Metro 20033 wasn't quite what I was looking for. I might revisit this sometime in the future when I'm feeling the urge to try something different. If I do, I'll update this review. But for now, I'm going to give the rest of it a pass.

Pros
- Some interesting game elements and level design
- Players who like a challenge will probably enjoy it

Cons
- Crappy combat mechanics
- Outdoor areas are not fun
- Checkpoint-only save system

Final Score: 5/10

One of the best post-apocalyptic games ever. It can truly make you feel the drama of humanity stuck in subway tunnels after the nuclear war. The game takes place mostly in subway tunnels and occasionally in the ruins of Moscow. The graphics are satisfactory for its year, the game mechanics are meh, but the atmosphere of the game is truly magnificent. It definitely gives you the feeling of traveling unsafely underground, surrounded by cobwebs, ruined structures, radioactive pollution, abandoned places, corpses and all kinds of mutated creatures. But there are already other games that give you some of these, so what makes Metro different? Although Metro seems like a classic thriller - FPS game at first glance, it is actually one of the best anti-war works of art ever created. The game literally pushes you to think about the damage of wars to both humanity and the nature, thanks to its atmosphere and scenario, as well as game mechanics. Metro is not a childish FPS where you take a gun and kill anyone, it is an art that aims to make you understand and accept those who are different than you and to understand the true meaning of peace.

Take your time, explore, soak up the atmosphere. It rewards exploration and you're missing out if you don't poke around - especially in the stations.

You get "morality points" towards the good ending by exploring (and looting) out of the way spots, listening to incidental conversations all the way through (civilians and enemies both), doing good deeds and avoiding enemy casualties. If you explore well enough, you can skip the pacifist angle and still get the good ending though.

Don't worry about getting separated from your allies. They will always wait for you to finish exploring, safe and sound.

In the Redux version of the game, many stealth sections are based around advancing as far as you can without being detected to trigger a conversation that will make the enemies move on to more convenient spots. If you're playing the original version, this doesn't happen, and stealth is mostly a way to thin out the enemies before the inevitable firefight.

Throwing knives, if you score a good hit with them, will stealthily instakill most enemies and you can pick the knife back up. Don't forget about them.

The revolver is a very reliable weapon and can take you through the entire game, though not worth silencing. If you're killing people stealthily the throwing knives are a much better option anyway.

Listen to NPC chatter. Seriously: the stories they tell are absolutely beautiful at times, and really draw you in.

Early on you get a chance to spend some time with a prostitute. Don't do this unless you want to lose all your money.

Buy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of ammo at every shop (but when a dude tells you to buy gas mask filters, get those first)

The game will automatically force Artyom to switch filters when one runs out. The only reason to switch manually is to avoid the distraction in the middle of combat / if you hate listening to choking noises.

The Helsing gun is very powerful and has reusable ammo - you pretty much need it to finish the game as one part has a lot of strong enemies that simply suck up ammo (In the Redux version, you *really* want to avoid fighting these, Helsing or no).

Long-range scopes are practically useless - you never fight at a range that will require sniping.

Very atmospheric game. Basically just a standard follow the story FPS that is seen in many other games such as Bioshock Infinite, Call of Duty, Wolfenstein etc. Graphics are absolutely top-notch, and the lighting gives the game an amazing atmosphere. Music is ok, nothing exceptional, but the voice acting is good and npc's that you interact with are really well done and make the game very immersive (apart from the children's voices...omg!). The combat is great and I really enjoyed the stealth option on certain levels.

For the negatives, I felt the game didn't give you much info or tutorials on the weapons or equipment you were using and just let you figure it out for yourself. I love the idea of not being hand-held throughout games, but I did feel at times it needed to explain a little more on certain things. The compass and clipboard felt very clumsy to use, infact the whole UI was a bit arkward to use, especially for things like grenades or throwing knives. It will probably take a couple of playthroughs to fully get to grips with how everything works.

I did enjoy it though, it's atmospheric, very immersive, and looks amazing and the story kept me hooked all the way through, but for me it just lacked that extra special something to push it to the next level.

A solid atmospheric immersive story-driven FPS, and would definitely recommend it.

One of my all time favorite series storytelling and theme wise. Gameplay definetly shows it's age with the combat and movement, so if you're more used to modern games it might be jarring (especially difficulty wise the game can be unforgiving at times). However if you can get past that you'll be welcome to a post apocalyptic world full of atmosphere and intrigue. The horror is more akin to a thriller with the slow rise of anxiety as your ammo count gets lower and the enemies come closer. The protagonist is admittedly pretty one tone, becoming more interesting in the 2nd and third games so stick with him he gets better. Graphics wise it definetly doesn't look bad, the art direction and set design is very good so it makes up for the lack of fidelity. I'd say if you have a few extra bucks it'd be worth a shot picking up the bundle on sale to see if you're into metro. WARNING you might find yourself imitating a terrible slavic accent after playing... be warned

Damn, what a game. Before this, I haven't heard of the Metro franchise but holy shit I should've found it sooner. Metro 2033 Redux is a remaster of, of course, Metro 2033, which itself is a video game adaptation of Dmitry Glukhovsky's science fiction novel, Metro 2033. Set in Moscow and its' tunnels 20 years after a nuclear holocaust caused by WW3, Artyom must explore the Metro to find help in defending his home station against the next evolution of mankind. After running it thrice, finishing the game in Ranger Hardcore and achieving 100%, this game is such an amazing experience. This game's lore is stacked with mysteries, the story is well told (just like the novel), the characters are likable and the enemy variations are enough to make you not feel bored, from humans like communists and fascists to mutants such as nosalises and my God, the librarians. BEWARE OF THE LIBRARIANS. That all due to being kind of an old game, some mechanics are janky like the stealth and movement. I encountered some wall hitboxes that sent me straight through the air and sometimes enemies just instantly found out where you are. In conclusion, Metro 2033 Redux is a masterpiece of a game that planted the seed for an amazing franchise that I will play next, I would RECOMMEND this game.

An incredible game in terms of story line and despite being an aged game it defeats lots of newly released games in terms of quality, though I admit controls can be a bit weird in controller but on keyboard/mouse it is fine. A must play for fans of the fps and horror genre!

After completing the game through both game modes, and unlocking both endings and gathering all of the achievements I can say with confidence that if you're a fan of Russian post-apocalyptic games. you're going to really enjoy this one too! The story line is adequate, and the English voice acting is very well done. I would say that this games only weaknesses are that it has a tendency to crash every so often, and that there are a lot of stealth based achievements, but this being an older title, the stealth mechanics don't feel competently fleshed out. This can lead to some frustration when say, you want to knock out human enemies, or do stealth kills, or using the throwing knives, (which for me was really troublesome because it's a little janky. Especially when fighting fast moving foes.) However, if you can look past this minor inconvenience then this game is very solid. It has many S.T.A.L.K.E.R. references in it as well, so personally, I would recommend that you play S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow of Chernobyl at least once to get those little hint-hint nudge-nudge moments thrown throughout here-and-there in this game. I will give it a solid 4 out of 5 filters!

Metro 2033 Redux is an exceptional video game that promises a visually stunning and emotionally gripping experience for players. The game is set in a post-apocalyptic world that is located in the depths of the Moscow Metro. The Redux version of the game features enhanced graphics and refined gameplay, which makes it even more immersive than the original, and a must-play for anyone who loves atmospheric, story-driven shooters.

The game design is incredibly detailed, which immerses players in a world where the last remnants of humanity struggle to survive in the tunnels beneath a destroyed city. The game's attention to detail is remarkable, from the flickering lights and eerie echoes in the dark tunnels to the hauntingly beautiful surface world that has been transformed into a barren wasteland inhabited by terrifying creatures. The game world feels incredibly real and every location in the game has a story to tell, which makes the world-building exceptional and sets Metro 2033 Redux apart from other games.

The game's story is a gripping tale of survival that is filled with hope, despair, and moral dilemmas. Players take on the role of Artyom, a young man trying to save his people from an unknown threat. The game's characters are incredibly well-developed, which makes them feel real, with their own dreams and struggles. Players can't help but become emotionally invested in their fates, which makes the game a truly immersive experience.

The gameplay in Metro 2033 Redux is a well-balanced mix of stealth and intense gunfights, which offers players the freedom to choose their approach. The game's scarcity of resources adds an extra layer of tension to every encounter, forcing players to make tough decisions about how to survive. The game's revamped controls and improved AI in this Redux version make the experience smoother and more satisfying than ever.

The sound design is another area where Metro 2033 Redux excels, adding to the game's emotional impact. The game's sound effects are incredibly immersive, from the eerie whispers of the Metro to the echoing gunshots and the haunting musical score. These elements all contribute to the game's immersive world.

In conclusion, Metro 2033 Redux is a captivating and emotionally charged game that will stay with players long after they've completed the game. If you're looking for a video game that not only offers a gripping story but also an immersive world that tugs at your heartstrings, then Metro 2033 Redux is a must-play. The game's exceptional attention to detail, well-developed characters, and immersive gameplay make it a true masterpiece. Dive into the depths of the Moscow Metro, experience the desolation, fear, and hope, and emerge from the game world as a changed person.

[h1] 🕘          IMPRESSION:[/h1]
* Year 2010: Game released 
* Year 2014: Original version delist on Steam when Redux version released
* Year 2019: I grab a free copy from Steam
* 8 hours later: Nice end game, I will buy Redux when I'm finish my backlog
* Year 2023: Purchased Metro Saga Bundle :D
* 0.2 hour later: Replay again, feeling like a fresh new game :)
* 6 hours later: I think the redux lighting is much better
* 9 hours later: Really struggle to pass, I cannot believe I beat in the past
* 11 hours later: The final chapter is really exciting :D
* 15 hours later: Created a fun Guide: Take Achievements as Side Quest

[h1]  🔊         TESTER MUST KNOW:[/h1]
* The original Metro 2033 is removed sales on Steam store
* Many gamer own Metro 2033 Redux on steam but still not playing it
* Gamer can replaying this game to earn easy achievements from this
🧭 Steam Guide: Take Achievements as Side Quest ➜ [u][url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3071626526]Show Me[/url][/u]
* Game world timeline: Pre-sequel story of Metro Last Light
* No DLC is available

[h1] 💎 SAME GENRE COMPARISON:[/h1]
* Need to pump gas for weapon
* Need to self charging for flash-light & night-vision
* Realistic creature behavior
* Story ending is change-able

[h1]  ⚠️        RUMOR CHECKING:[/h1]
* Redux is the vastly upgraded and improved version ➜ Slightly different on visual as I noticed
* It is a hidden gem ➜ I agree it has good quality, but less charming character & weapon in my opinion
* The original is better than Redux➜ In my opinion, both also looks and feel good

I've come back to the original after playing the newer titles and it's still my favourite. 

There seems to be so much purpose to Artyoms' journey through the metro tunnels. Seeking help for his home station. The Dark Ones presenting an enemy against which they have no defence. The paranormal / psychological elements to Metro 2033 Redux add a lot of depth to the world.

It's a story of survival in a claustrophobic and dangerous world. The murky tunnels infested with mutants and anomalies, which Artyom would in theory be experiencing for the first time on his own. This anticipation is what I personally enjoyed so much. 

Taking a passive approach see's you act as a fly on the wall. Taking stock of the different factions and ideologies held by groups found in the Metro. Grounded in humanity and the faults that we share. 

Human's are just as violent if not more so than any of the Mutants lurking in the tunnels. The moral choices you are presented allow for different endings, depending on your style of play and interaction. 

Weapon sounds are perfect, and have plenty of weight. The chonky gun models / art style are much preferred personally over the realistic route taken in future titles. 

I will admit that this game does not like to be rushed. 

So take some time to stop and smell the irradiated mushrooms as you stroll through post apocalyptic Russia.

Hello i have been stuck in metro station since July 2013. I befriend the rats and we hunt for food together. Even though i have been welcomed by the rats as one of their own, I still long to return to my homeland of Yugoslavia. I have question! Do american planes allow passengers to board with roughly 25 rats? i have enough pizza leftovers to pay for their tickets if necessary. How do i leave the station via the tunnels? The regular entrance is too bright for me to leave without an umbrella, but the trains haven't stopped at this station since 1977. As an added question, does american police patrol the tunnels? I ask because me and my rodent companions have feasted on human flesh occasionally, and we have some left that we saved for the perilous journey ahead, and i don't want to get in trouble for that
and lastly, i remember a man offering to remove painful teeth in the station bathroom in exchange for 2 hot dogs. He went away when station closed. are these services offered at every station? some of my teeth hurt and i'd like that taken care of before i return home :)

Bleak, horrifying, and disgusting. The rich world of Metro shines through with fascinating settings, monsters, and lore. One of best narrative shooters I've ever played, and I can only hope LL and Exodus continue to improve on the amazing foundation laid by this game.

Only few nitpicks:
* Few levels on Hardcore are obscenely difficult due to enemy AI being overly reactive with instant snapping to you, everything else feels fair
* Resource management is necessary for the feeling of horror and survival, but lack of manual saves creates some moments where if you mess up your planning there's no going back (not objectively bad, just annoying)

[h1] Metro at it's finest [/h1]

For years Metro 2033 was used as a benchmark test for the latest graphics cards, so it feels strange to already be seeing a remastered version hit the digital shelves. It's easy to be cynical and assume that Metro 2033 Redux is aimed squarely at the console market, whose under-TV boxes have only just caught up with Metro 2033's full majesty. It's finally a way for living-room dwellers to see what the game is like with all its video options switched on. But what's the value for PC players?

Well, Metro 2033 Redux is an honest to goodness, genuine remaster. A collection of tweaks and polishes, do-overs and rejigs that elevates the game to even greater heights, this is a full visual revamp that brings it in line with Last Light in terms of graphical tech.

If you haven't played Metro 2033 before, this will now be the best place to start. It's post-apocalyptic FPSing at its finest, with a uniquely grim backdrop and appropriately negative portrayal of mankind in the midst of that. The premise of Metro is that the surface of Earth is scorched and irradiated, so the people of Moscow live within the tunnels of the metro (hey, that's the name of the game!) while the Dark Ones above their heads plot against them.

A feature which gives you the option of bartering high-grade ammunition for better guns/upgrades or using them to, you know, shoot mutants is a standout innovation that creates tension in how you approach combat. Scarcity of ammo is a staple of the survival horror genre, but never before has finding a stash of bullets prompted such an internal conflict.

For a game with a grim colour filter, 2010's 2033 was also remarkably pretty. 2014's version is a marked difference. I'm not talking a little texture upgrade here, I'm talking new meshes, new animations and reworked environments. Metro 2033 Redux is Metro 2033 tweaked and polished to a high standard; this feels like the definitive version of the game 4A originally wanted to make.

Even down to the main menu screen. It's the same, but vastly improved. It's not like the old one is looking particularly weathered, it's just that the difference in production values here make it worth paying for again.

There are other smaller changes to the Redux edition. Cutscenes have been reworked so that the camera never leaves protagonist Artyom's perspective. Again, there was nothing wrong with wresting the non-interactive viewpoint away from the player from time to time in 2033, but such a change demonstrates that this is closer to their vision of how this story should be told. In such a tense, atmospheric game heightening the player's engagement with the narrative like this just feels like common sense.

4A has revisited every aspect of 2033, evident in the improved lighting and weather effects, the expanded environments, added secrets or even the addition of some of Metro: Last Light's better features, like weapon customisation.

So is it worth buying again? Absolutely. Especially since you can grab Metro 2033 Redux for half price on Steam if you already own Metro 2033. If you don't already own it, then $24.99/£17 for an excellent game that you should have played by now anyway is a pretty damn good deal.

Also, the gameplay is one of the very strengths of the game, even with controller the experience feels fair and balanced especially in ranger mode, but the normal mode makes the enemies like sponges of bullets. Also, the linux support is something that I'll always take with open arms. 4/5 I'd recommend this game.

Metro: 2033 Redux - це перезавантажена версія класичної гри Metro 2033, і вона вразить як ветеранів, так і новачків геймерів завдяки своєму захоплюючому світові, атмосфері та глибокому сюжету.

Однією з найвидатніших особливостей гри є її атмосфера. Метро-універсум, в якому розгортається дія, є по-справжньому захоплюючим та занурює гравця в постапокаліптичний світ, де людство виживає в підземних тунелях, борючись з небезпечними мутантами та іншими загрозами. Відмінною роботою команди розробників є відтворення цього світу з вражаючою увагою до деталей та атмосферними ефектами, які роблять кожну локацію відчутною та неймовірною.

Геймплей в Metro: 2033 Redux поєднує елементи виживання, стрілянини та експлорації. Ви будете витрачати уважно ресурси, управляти амуніцією та розглядати оточення для виживання. Важливо робити тактичні рішення про те, коли стріляти, а коли приховуватися, оскільки амуніція обмежена, а вороги дуже небезпечні. Ця система гри робить Metro: 2033 Redux особливо відчутною, а надзвичайно різноманітні локації і завдання додають грі варіативності та глибини.

Сюжет Metro: 2033 Redux - це ще один сильний аспект гри. Ви будете подорожувати разом з головним героєм, Артемом, через небезпечний метро-світ, долаючи перепони і розгадуючи таємниці. Цей нарратив відчувається важливим і захоплюючим, з багатьма непередбачуваними поворотами сюжету.

Загалом, Metro: 2033 Redux - це незабутня гра, яка поєднує в собі захоплюючий сюжет, унікальну атмосферу і захоплюючий геймплей. Це гра, яка обов'язково сподобається фанатам постапокаліптичних шутерів та історій виживання. Переживіть цю подорож через підземний світ Москви і зануртесь в Metro: 2033 Redux, яка залишить вас з глибокими враженнями і бажанням повернутися ще раз.

Metro 2033 is a game that immerses you in a post-apocalyptic world where humanity is struggling to survive in the underground metro system of Moscow. The game is based on the novel by Dmitry Glukhovsky, and it faithfully recreates the atmosphere and the story of the book. The game features a rich and detailed environment, with realistic graphics and sound effects that make you feel like you are really there. The game also has a compelling and branching storyline, where your choices and actions affect the outcome of the game. The game is not only a shooter, but also a survival horror, where you have to scavenge for resources, manage your inventory, and fight against mutants and hostile factions. The game also has a moral system, where your decisions and behavior influence the fate of the characters and the world. The game is challenging and rewarding, and it offers a unique and unforgettable experience. Metro 2033 is a game that I highly recommend to anyone who loves immersive and atmospheric games. It is one of the best games I have ever played.

A lot of purists will tell you to just buy the original version of Metro 2033 if you can but truth be told, just get ANY version of 2033. you literally cannot go wrong-both versions are great games with largely the same gameplay and same story. the differences between the two boil down to a slightly darker overall art style in the original and some tweaks to level design and characters models, and the ability to customize weapons with attachments in the Redux, in the OG you just had to find the right weapon in the world and be happy. The brighter art style of the Redux is clearly just to show off some of the good texture work that goes unnoticed in the original. In all honesty, I prefer the Redux 90 percent of the time. The original lacks plenty of quality of life and immersive elements, such as being able to wipe your mask off. Redux has a clearer stealth system with less frustration and overall better presentation and storytelling; the original has actual cutscenes and shows Artyom's full body at numerous times, whereas the redux goes for a Half-Life style of presentation where the perspective never leaves Artyom's eyes. The benefits to the original are darker, more atmospheric lighting, and much better sound effects.

The story is simple, you are Artyom, a dweller of Exhibition Station, a neutral station in the Metro, where other stations are ruled by factions such as The Red Line (the commies), or The Fourth Reich (the nazis), the Spartan Order (also known as the Rangers, basically a neutral police faction), or The Hanseatic League (aka, the Hansa, the largest and most influential trade faction) Most, especially Hanza, aren't really explained in the game. the Reds and the Fourth Reich are self explanatory, just second iterations of these two political ideologies, however Hanza is largely unknown to you through this game (and the others in the series, its entirely possible to just not know who the Hanza are if you don't read the novels); I had to turn to the book to learn who they actually were. Most factions are obviously your enemy, but Hanza is interesting, as they do present a big threat, but they aren't your enemies, its more their paranoia and suspicion that Artyom has to deal with. You are Artyom, a young man in his early-to-mid 20s and who longs to see the outside world, collecting postcards depicting cities and places all over the world. When your station is compromised by mutants after the arrival of the Ranger Hunter, a friend of your adoptive father, Hunter embarks on a mission, and gives Artyom his Ranger dogtags, telling him to warn the Order of the Dark Ones, a psionic species of creatures that took over the surface after nuclear armaggeddon. Thus you embark on your journey with a single goal, get to the Order and give them Hunter's warning. To do this you'll do through various ordeals, such as sneaking behind enemy lines, dealing with mutants, bandits, etc, and surviving treks to the surface. The story unfolds similarly to Half Life or HL2, with each level feeding into the next in a linear path that feels more like a long journey than a traditional story, as well as the Redux version (this one) never leaving Artyom's perspective.

Graphically, its dated but thanks to good lighting and textures, it holds up fine.
Sound design is great, atmosphere is appropriate and the voice acting is largely good--this game uses a lot of Barbara Goodson, and while she is an iconic voice actor, her voice is super distinctive and doesn't quite work for the various kid roles they gave her; everyone else in the English cast is generally excellent. The one thing is guns don't sound brilliant-most lack punch, with the revolver, using a stock sound effect that you can hear in The Martix, oddly being the punchiest.

Stealth can feel a little underbaked and buggy at times, and the AI is not smart, but those are relatively minor. The original has much smarter AI, but loses the fun of being able to stealth through entire encounters, as without a silent takedown system (except throwing knives), the enemies tend to discover you quickly and force you to drain resources, something that makes later levels much more challenging.

Gameplay is immersive and fun, and never too difficult, as long as you're exploring as much as you can, especially on the Ranger modes. The Redux version of the game also offers a choice between the original 2033's "Survival" gameplay or it sequel, Last Light's "Spartan" gameplay. Like most people i recommend survival, the resource management and such adds tension to the story that it lacks otherwise.

Playing all three current Metro games sequentially provides a great, immersive world and overall storyline for Artyom as a character.
 
My biggest criticism of the game is with its morality system, moreso its effect of the ending. At various points in the story, Artyom is presented with a moral dilemma. None of them are hard to choose (give a begger a bullet, take ammo as payment from a starving group) and some of them are just given to you for exploring, making it easy to get the good ending of the game where you stop at the last minute from doing something terrible. the problems are A, the bad ending is canonical, meaning if you want the best experience for the whole series, you can't go for the points and B, since some points are just given to you for finding a specific body or room, its really too easy to get the good ending.

The rest of the review is full of spoilers and such so if you've decided to get the game, great, just don't read on. 

I've edited this review multiple times in the last week as ive been doing my second PC playthrough, third overall, and have been reading the books finally. I recommend it if you like this game, there's a lot more to learn about each faction and such through the books, just be wary that the books are absolutely not the same as the games, save 2033 somewhat. Metro 2033 actually adapts the book rather well (with obvious concessions so as to make the game actually fun). The book, once it gets going, starts with the same conversation between Artyom's stepfather (Alex in game, Sukhoi in book) and Hunter, albeit just in different circumstances. Like the game, Exhibition Station (VDNKh), has been under attack, but not from nosalis packs, from the Dark Ones specifically. Like the game, Artyom had, at a very young age, left open the hermetic seals open at the Botanical Gardens, letting the Dark Ones in (something more explored in Last Light), and like the game, has to go to Polis station to find Melnik (Miller being the character and a nickname, in Metro Exodus, he refers to himself as 'Colonel Melnikov'). The actual plot is pretty similar too, from reluctantly going alongside Bourban to meeting and befriending Khan, a tunnel mystic.

If i have a complaint about the entire series, its the fact that characters aren't shared between games, especially Exodus, which gives the player an entire crew of Spartan Rangers, albeit with only 2 that return from older games. In Metro 2033, you'll meet Miller and Ulman, alongside Pavel, Stepan, and Boris (all of whom die trying to either help Artyom accomplish his mission, or during the course of their own duties.) Miller, Ulman, and Khan go on to star in Last Light, but only Miller is in all three. Pavel dies trying to get you to Black Station, and Boris and Stepan die during the capture of D6. Last Light will introduce Anya (Anna) to the main three but those are the only three that go from these first two games to the last (Artyom, Miller, and Anya,) as Exodus introduces several characters that just should've been involved earlier.

It's a very fun, unique and iconic FPS survival horror game linear experience.

You play as Artyom, a silent inexperienced FPS protagonist who has a lot to say in his journal pages about the hellish, dismal but also slightly cozy places he visits, such as crowded metro stations full of worried but hardy refugees as well as the endless winter wastelands of the surface, where you have to wear a gas mask or suffocate on radiation when you're not busy trying to stave off countless giant mutants who want to rip your face off with a devastating three-hit melee combo, plus the frequent groups of trigger happy sociopathic bandit groups.

Story revolves around Artyom's journey to leave home and unravel the mysteries of the enigmatic and feared Dark Ones, shadowy giant humanoid creatures with telepathic powers who leave humans catatonic whenever they make contact. 

There's a certain type of narrative in place for the story and it's not exactly subtle (gameplay loop and moral points scale encourages the player to be stealthy and avoid killing human foes when possible), but aside from that narrative, the gameplay is excellent, one of the best examples of linear thriller stealth horror, even better than Dead Space.

Gameplay is broken up into level sections. Sometimes, you listen to people talk about their hopes and dreams and survival concerns in npc hubs for extra moral points that will help give you access to the good ending, if you want to shoot for it.

Other times, you can spend several minutes at a shop, listening to idle npc chatter and looking over the available firearm upgrades and attachments while debating with yourself on whether or not the military grade rounds you use as money (or extremely rare and powerful flaming machine gun bullets) are worth spending on a stock or a reflex scope or a quad barrel duplet shotgun upgrade when you're likely going to find an equivalent or better upgrade through scavenging corpses tucked away in storage caches in the next level section. If you're good at scavenging, you won't have to buy upgrades or extra ammo or grenades, and the game encourages the player to save MGR rounds for money and/or extreme combat emergencies, but given that you can have over 1000 MGRs in the endgame with nothing to spend it on aside from using them as ammunition against giant gorilla mutants... the player has a lot of flexibility for how they want to spend their hard-earned resources and bullets.

Sometimes, you go up to the surface and have frantic combat encounters with dangerous mutants where you blast away foe after foe with your shotgun of choice. You can also learn that due to the way atmosphere damage accumulates and resets upon putting your gas mask back on, you can get away with taking off Artyom's gas mask for around 3-10 seconds before he suffocates and then put the gas mask back on for a split second. It's a very cheap trick that the devs probably didn't intend with the game engine, but it's a great way to massively extend filter time if you're worried about running out of filters and/or getting your gas mask shattered by mutants and/or bandits, as the gas mask breaks slowly from mutants and breaks quickly when you get shot at with bullets and grenades.

Other times, you have interesting stealth segments that reward the player for using non-lethal melee takedowns from behind unaware roaming hostile humans as you listen to their idle chatter and discover hidden ammo caches and weapons for extra resources and moral points. You can also go guns blazing but it's not recommended due to all of the humans with heavy armor that makes anything other than assault rifle/pistol/metal ball/arrowhead headshots viable, and shotgun rounds are always best saved for mutants. Or you can use your overpowered, infinitely reusable throwing knives to silently kill everyone if you get frustrated by the stealth level layouts and light/flame source positioning, which is also a valid tactic that I myself hesitated to use at first due to the moral points system.

Overall, Metro 2033 Redux and Metro Last Light offer unique gameplay and story experiences that you really don't get from other survival/horror/FPS/TPS games (Resident Evil, Silent Hill, Dead Space, FEAR, those various other games that are post-apocalyptic survival horror similar to Metro like Stalker/Chernobylite, etc). The two games in the Metro trilogy are highly recommended classis, especially if you get the franchise sale bundle.

Picked up for cheap during a sale, and man, do I regret it. Nearly all of my playtime has been troubleshooting incredibly aggravating problems that shouldn't exist: FOV locked to 50, permanently halved vertical mouse sensitivity and hardcorded mouse acceleration, you name it. Even worse, most of the fixes can only be done through the config file, which if you've ever troubleshot an oldish game using the config file before, you know that your changes may literally just not work. The only issue I was able to fix was the halved vertical sensitivity, and that was through downloading a 3rd-party DLL. 

In short, seems like a good game with a welcome gameplay redux (based on other peoples' reviews), but has a myriad of problems that should never have made it out of development, ESPECIALLY after a redux/remaster.

Offers an immersive post-apocalyptic atmosphere with horror elements.
P.S. spiders are sensitive to light - they won't attack if you keep your torch on them - they even take damage from it.

Check the bottom of the review for must-know gameplay mechanics, including one you truly must know to actually progress the game.

Quick note: Arachnophobes should avoid this franchise. The spiders are huge, they are everywhere, and there are even moments where they literally crawl on your gas mask.

Classic game remade with a more modernized engine mostly as a way for nvidia to show off what their GPUs could do back then.

The lighting and post processing are amazing even by today's standards, but the animations are of course mostly pre-2010 standards still. Controls are still a bit jank and the storyline is pretty simple by modern standards, the chances of anyone getting the "good" ending are basically zilch without a guide but luckily the "bad" ending is canonical; yes you are a fated to be a huge fuckup.

Aims for an immersive experience and doesn't do a bad job of it, it's borderline an immersive sim.


As for must-know gameplay mechanics that the game never tells you:

Most importantly you can burn spiderwebs with your lighter (tap m by default). There's a point in the game where you're blocked by a spiderweb you can't just push through, and the game doesn't do ANYTHING to tell you how to get past.

Hold down the reload button to swap your assault rifle to pre-war military ammo. This ammo is treated as money, but the game is quick to move you past a point where there are any stores to buy stuff from. This ammo does a lot more damage than the regular stuff, late in the game it's likely to save your hide.

Metro 2033 Redux stands as an immersive masterpiece. It's post-apocalyptic world is a captivating blend of danger and beauty. Even years after its release, the graphics still hold up well. The game's qualities are exemplified through its gripping narrative, forcing players to navigate the haunting tunnels of Moscow's metro. The gunplay also offers a highly satisfying experience, complemented by an extensive array of weapons for players to choose from and dabble with. I discovered myself firing shots aimlessly, purely to witness the captivating reloading animations of specific weapons. With its rich story, immersive world, and enduring graphics, Metro 2033 Redux remains an essential play for both newcomers and returning fans of the series, and with an overwhelmingly low price of $4 on sale, it should not be overlooked.

Great game even in 2023. Played this before on Epic but then got the whole series on Steam for less than $10. It's truly a steal, great game, great discount and great optimization even on my HD 4600.
I get a playable 15-30 fps with my Intel HD Graphics 4600 on 1080P Low and managed through it. And truly, most of the time you're in dark tunnels or with a gas mask, so high graphics may not be much better than low.
Weapons are pretty fun, I usually play with an AK-74M/Kalash or later an AK-2012/Kalash 2012 with reflex sight, laser designator, ext. mag(Kalash only) and suppressor, a shotgun (Shambler or later the machine-shotgun) and a revolver with stock&fore end, ext. barrel and 2x sight for sniping (you might want to swap for a Lolife in Last Light for higher mag capacity).
Only thing I want to complain about is the nightvision experience. When you have NVG on, there's a weird IR flashlight that you can't turn off. Not that it compromises your location, you know, it's IR, but it makes everything washed out and it's extremely difficult to see things beyond like 20 meters. That's not what I'm expecting from the "redux" version of a game!

Overall I'm pleased with the game tho, and here's some tips for newcomers:
1. Holding a particular key results in a different behavior from pressing it. Like when you have a gas mask on, pressing G wipes its visor, while holding G takes it off.
2. Don't forget to charge your flashlight and NVG! Hold the default lighter/charger button to bring up the universal charger and press LMB until the hand on the meter reaches peak.
3. You'll need to charge weapons that use compressed air or battery like the Tikhar, Hellbreath and Flamethrower or they won't fire. Hold down R and press LMB.
4. Those keys with a glowing red ribbon will open a locked safe in the same level, just pay attention to corners and places you might miss.

It’s a linear, story-based FPS, situated in a post-apocalyptic Mosco and its subway system. No skills to upgrade. Just weapons you can find/buy and customize a bit. The story wasn’t much and the ending-choice can be reloaded, but I was greatly intrigued by the lore unfolding mostly through random conversations you overhear or the things you see, during your travels. Played it on hardest difficulty (Hardcore Ranger) for 35 hours to explore everything. There are many areas that become unreachable once you progress the main path, so I had to replay some chapters. It also required a lot of stealth and crazy-careful ammunition and utility management, without any UI. Had to google a couple of keys, but the immersion was worth it. Also, I had to reload most fights for ammo conservation, but I still enjoyed them all. The game’s best points come from its great graphics, its beautifully dreadful and mostly claustrophobic environment designs and its natural animations and sound effects, which together create a constant feeling of danger, plus some very cinematic and satisfying shooting of hideous monsters. Had a few loading crashes, but it generally loads fast and runs very well, given all the foggy and fast passed scenes.

Great survival horror with an unforgettable atmosphere. A lot of things can go wrong here really fast... running out of gas mask filters or ammo, random enemy encounters, and walking right into insta-kill spots.
However, even though this is a remaster, there are many critical unresolved technical issues like:
* The maximum in-game resolution is 1600x1200. This bug is related to having multiple displays connected. It can be fixed by using Special K's borderless windowed mode.
* Tesselation leads to missing geometry, such as holes in walls with the raw background being visible.
* Random crashes

Metro 2033 Redux stands as an undeniable masterpiece, seamlessly merging captivating storytelling with an immersive post-apocalyptic world. The game's meticulous attention to detail, from its hauntingly atmospheric environments to its richly developed characters, crafts an experience that lingers in the mind long after the controller is set down. The Redux version further enhances this brilliance, delivering refined graphics and gameplay mechanics that breathe new life into an already remarkable title. (Just finished playing this over on my Youtube channel - link at the end of the review for anyone who wants to see a sample of gameplay before buying)

Fun little story: I bought the original Metro 2033 back in 2010 when it first released, but was only ever able to play a couple of hours into it before I had to stop playing, as back then I was on a crappy PC that couldn't really handle it. Now, over 10 years later, I can finally say I've beaten Metro 2033 after returning to play the redux version!

I've never read the Dimitri Glukhovsky novel on which this game is based, so I'm going to be judging Metro 2033 Redux purely on its own merits without any external reference point. The game puts you in the shoes of Artyom, a man living in a postapocalyptic Moscow where the remnants of humanity are forced to live in the tunnels of the old metro system, fending off attacks by mutant beasts that stalk the ruins. When his home station is threatened, Artyom sets out on a journey across the metro to find help, encountering plenty of interesting friends - and more than a few enemies, human and non-human. That's the basic premise of the story; I found it nice and engaging.

The graphics of this redux version of the game are fine, giving the metro a sufficiently dark, grimy aesthetic. Sound design is also on point, helping to bring everything to life. The gameplay is exactly what you'd expect of any first-person shooter, with a mix of options for running and gunning versus taking a more stealthy approach. There's a variety of weapons for you to get your teeth into, but you can only carry three different guns at a time - so you'll have to pick and choose which ones you want carefully.

Given this is a postapocalyptic setting, weapons can be divided into two broad categories. There are proper firearms left behind from the end of the world, such as AKs and the like; these are the guns you really want to get your hands on, as they're powerful. However, ammo for them tends to be more scarce (something exacerbated by the fact that in the metro, military-grade ammo serves as currency for buying equipment and upgrades, so you'll never want to use all of your military-grade ammo for fighting). Then there are the improvised firearms that the metro dwellers have crafted from whatever junk they have lying around; these tend to be weaker than proper military weapons and might have their own quirks (such as air-propelled weapons that require you to pressurise them by hand), but ammo for them is makeshift and therefore tends to be more plentiful. So part of the game is about balancing your ammo currency and the types of weapons you carry, figuring out what sort of upgrades to buy for them.

Other weapons and equipment you'll need: throwing knives and grenades always come in handy, and you'll always need to ensure you have plenty of filters for your gas mask. Your gas mask is vital - the surface of Moscow and more than a few of its metro tunnels are irradiated and thus will kill you if you venture out without protection. This is where exploration becomes vital to the gameplay; do not race through levels blindly. Take your time to explore every nook and cranny, as quite often you'll find goodies hidden everywhere - ammo, gas mask filters, even keys to safes crammed with lots of pickups. In short, the game rewards you for examining your surroundings!

Overall, the game isn't too long either - I beat it in roughly 10 hours or so, which I felt to be just the right length for the story it was telling. On the whole, therefore, I highly recommend Metro 2033 Redux!

In 2013 the world was devastated by an apocalyptic event, annihilating almost all mankind and turning the Earth's surface into a poisonous wasteland. A handful of survivors took refuge in the depths of the Moscow underground, and human civilization entered a new Dark Age.

The year is 2033. An entire generation has been born and raised underground, and their besieged Metro Station-Cities struggle for survival, with each other, and the mutant horrors that await outside. You are Artyom, born in the last days before the fire, but raised underground. Having never ventured beyond the city limits, one fateful event sparks a desperate mission to the heart of the Metro system, to warn the remnants of mankind of a terrible impending threat. Your journey takes you from the forgotten catacombs beneath the subway to the desolate wastelands above, where your actions will determine the fate of mankind. But what if the real threat comes from within? Great and Awesome Game to play! Improved graphics and interesting story itself! The gunplay is on another level. From pumps to AK! Different choices you can choose from. Help or refuse and etc. The environment of destroyed Moscow, what can be better than this! Definitely recommend checking this game if you never did! У 2013 годзе свет быў спустошаны апакаліптычнай падзеяй, якая знішчыла амаль усё чалавецтва і ператварыла паверхню Зямлі ў атрутную пустку. Жменька тых, хто выжыў, схавалася ў нетрах маскоўскага падполля, і чалавечая цывілізацыя ўвайшла ў новы Цёмны век.

Надышоў 2033 год. Цэлае пакаленне нарадзілася і вырасла пад зямлёй, і іх абложаныя станцыі метро-гарады змагаюцца за выжыванне адзін з адным і жахамі-мутантамі, якія чакаюць звонку. Ты Арцём, які нарадзіўся ў апошнія дні перад пажарам, але вырас пад зямлёй. Ніколі не выходзячы за межы горада, адна лёсавызначальная падзея выклікае адчайную місію ў сэрцы сістэмы метро, ​​каб папярэдзіць рэшткі чалавецтва аб жудаснай надыходзячай пагрозе. Ваша падарожжа прывядзе вас ад забытых катакомбаў пад метро да бязлюдных пустак наверсе, дзе вашы дзеянні вызначаць лёс чалавецтва. Але што, калі рэальная пагроза зыходзіць знутры? Выдатная і цудоўная гульня! Палепшаная графіка і цікавая гісторыя! Стральба на іншым узроўні! Ад помпаў да АК! Вы можаце выбраць з розных варыянтаў. Дапамагаць або адмаўляць і г. д. Асяроддзе разбуранай Масквы, што можа быць лепш за гэта! Абавязкова рэкамендую праверыць гэтую гульню, калі вы ніколі не рабілі! Зроблена нашымі украінскімі сябрамі! Агучка лепшая каторую я чуў! Гуляў па Ўкраінскі! Слава Ўкраіне! Жыве Беларусь!

U 2013 hodzie sviet byŭ spustošany apakaliptyčnaj padziejaj, jakaja zniščyla amaĺ usio čalaviectva i pieratvaryla pavierchniu Ziamli ŭ atrutnuju pustku. Žmieńka tych, chto vyžyŭ, schavalasia ŭ nietrach maskoŭskaha padpollia, i čalaviečaja cyvilizacyja ŭvajšla ŭ novy Ciomny viek.

Nadyšoŭ 2033 hod. Celaje pakaliennie naradzilasia i vyrasla pad ziamlioj, i ich abložanyja stancyi mietro-harady zmahajucca za vyžyvannie adzin z adnym i žachami-mutantami, jakija čakajuć zvonku. Ty Arciom, jaki naradziŭsia ŭ apošnija dni pierad pažaram, alie vyras pad ziamlioj. Nikoli nie vychodziačy za miežy horada, adna liosavyznačaĺnaja padzieja vyklikaje adčajnuju misiju ŭ sercy sistemy mietro, ​​kab papiaredzić reštki čalaviectva ab žudasnaj nadychodziačaj pahrozie. Vaša padarožža pryviadzie vas ad zabytych katakombaŭ pad mietro da biazliudnych pustak naviersie, dzie vašy dziejanni vyznačać lios čalaviectva. Alie što, kali reaĺnaja pahroza zychodzić znutry? Vydatnaja i cudoŭnaja huĺnia! Paliepšanaja hrafika i sama cikavaja historyja! Straĺba na inšym uzroŭni. Ad pompaŭ da AK! Vy možacie vybrać z roznych varyjantaŭ. Dapamahać abo admaŭliać i h. d. Asiaroddzie razburanaj Maskvy, što moža być liepš za heta! Abaviazkova rekamienduju pravieryć hetuju huĺniu, kali vy nikoli nie rabili! Ad našych ukrainskich siabroŭ! Slava Ŭkrainie! Žyvie Bielaruś!

У 2013 році світ був спустошений апокаліптичною подією, яка знищила майже все людство та перетворила поверхню Землі на отруйну пустку. Жменька тих, хто вижив, сховалася в глибинах московського підпілля, і людська цивілізація вступила в новий темний вік.

Настав 2033 рік. Ціле покоління народилося та виросло під землею, а їхні міста-станції метро, ​​які знаходяться в облозі, борються за виживання одне з одним і жахливими мутантами, які чекають зовні. Ви Артем, народжений в останні дні перед пожежею, але виріс під землею. Ніколи не виходячи за межі міста, одна доленосна подія викликає відчайдушну місію в серце системи метро, ​​щоб попередити залишки людства про жахливу загрозу, що насувається. Ваша подорож перенесе вас із забутих катакомб під метро до безлюдних пусток угорі, де ваші дії визначатимуть долю людства. Але що, якщо справжня загроза йде зсередини? Чудова і приголомшлива гра! Покращена графіка і сама цікава історія! Перестрілка на іншому рівні. Від насосів до АК! Ви можете вибрати різні варіанти. Допомогти або відмовити і т. д. Оточення зруйнованої Москви, що може бути краще цього! Однозначно рекомендую перевірити цю гру, якщо ви ніколи не робили цього! Від наших українських друзів! Слава Україні! Живе Беларусь!

I had already left this game half the way about a decade back. It was interesting, but difficult. Being a Fallout fan and after hearing a lot about Metro, I finally gave it another try and loved it. I do not finish a lot of games, and having completed it at least once proves how much I loved it. The mechanics are great, and if you ignore the bugs (I only had it once or twice), it's perfect, except for the fact that you cannot reload a saved game and go back to change your decisions.

It's also interesting how it forces you to manage a pretty small inventory of three guns unlike other games that let you carry more weapons but have you micromanage your inventory. I was worried that I would run our of ammo or gas masks, but with my play-style (on Sparta mode), not being an expert gamer, especially after I had to leave my keyboard+mouse combo due to RSI, I could still survive till the end.

The game does get a little frustratingly difficult at times, especially for a story-based gamer like me, but it still sort of worked out with a little strategy.

TLDR; I'd definitely recommend it as it's reasonably short for a great story.
