Very good game. Like deep feeling of Mother Russia.

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. Realistic Combat
I was awed by the way the monsters moved in combat. The movements looked fluid compared to combat in Half Life, where the fight between characters were "blockish" or "robotic". E.g. The watchers attacking Bourbon and Artyom while moving to Riga Station.

2. Interactive Background
It is amazing to see the demons fly around in the background and see them swoop into the active zone. Compared to other games where the background is just an unending cinematic loop, this provides a sense of realism. E.g. The demons flying around Moscow.  

3. Moral Points
It is interesting to note that there are points that will affect your morals in this game. While they are not explicitly shown, it is a good point to note.

4. Traps
Holes in the ground, tripwires, hidden cans. All these traps make the game so much more exciting. 

5. Sneaking
There are some occasions where you can sneak by and avoid combat totally. This really gives the game variety. If you prefer to fight, you can fight.

6. Story
Some Cthulu-like parts included. Interesting. The dream modes don't really make sense but they are an interesting aspect.

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. Movement
Following characters around isn't smooth. E.g. Bourbon leaving Exhibition to use the tunnels. Bourbon will walk to a point and rotate about that point before continuing his walk.

2. Guns
Crappy simulation. For a country that makes tons of weapons, it is strange that their post-apocalyptic nightmare will have such rudimentary weapons like the Bastard. You would think that their technology would at least be in the 21st century, not Cold-War era.

3. Repetitive model
The adults look the same. In 2 different zones, the children scribble on the floor wearing the same clothes. Boring.

4. Lousy Tutorials
Tutorials do not teach you how to use the sticky grenade or the knife throw.

5. Confusing situations
The scenario in the hidden subway with the child ghost was retarded. Every other spider web in the game can be pushed through, yet this scenario requires you to turn on your lighter to burn the web. There are no hints to use fire and people are known to get stuck at this particular scenario.

6. The gas mask.
How does it change the game? The only difference is an annoying "Press T to change the filter" and minor cracks in your mask to simulate damage taken.

If you're coming over here expecting a full review of this game, well, fuck you. Here's a delicious peach crumble recipe instead.

INGREDIENTS :

6 large peaches, sliced (about 2 1/2 lb.)
1/4 c. granulated sugar
Juice of 1/2 lemon
1/2 tsp. ground cinnamon
1/2 tsp. ground ginger
Pinch kosher salt

 TOPPING :

1 1/2 c. all-purpose flour
1 c. packed brown sugar
1/2 tsp. kosher salt
1/4 tsp. ground cinnamon
1/2 c. (1 stick) melted butter
Vanilla ice cream, for serving



Step 1
Preheat oven to 375°. Make peaches: In a large bowl, combine peaches, sugar, lemon juice, cinnamon, ginger, and salt. 
Step 2
Make topping: In a medium bowl, combine flour, brown sugar, salt, and cinnamon. Pour in melted butter and stir until mixture resembles coarse crumbs. 
Step 3
Pour peaches and juices into a large baking dish. Sprinkle crumb topping evenly over peaches. 
Step 4
Bake until topping is golden and peaches are bubbling, 45 to 50 minutes.
Step 5
Serve warm with ice cream, if desired.

Metro 2033 is a good FPS shooter that has a very unique atmosphere. Its biggest strength is the setting, with its realistic characters and the post-apocalyptic world inhabited by all types of living and dead horrors. The shooting has its ups but for me it was mostly just slightly above average. If you are looking for a shooter with fantastic gunplay, this might not be your choice, but if you want a unique setting which has been perfected and spreads atmosphere all over the place, you have found your game.

One of the most commendable aspects of Metro 2033 is its attention to detail. The post-apocalyptic Moscow setting is brought to life and an ambience that creates tension and despair. This level of detail not only enhances the visual experience but it also helps to deepens the emotional connection to the characters and the world they inhabit. The sound design in Metro 2033 is nothing but brilliant. The echoes in the tunnels, the distant growls of mutants, and the whispered conversations of NPCs all contribute to a feeling of immersion that few games can achieve. At last i just want to say that "Metro 2033" is a worth it game.

I didn't like this game that much. I played through it several times and found it to be rather thin in several areas. The combat is repetitive and the stealth is half-baked. It's often not clear when enemies can see you and it's not usually worth it to avoid conflict anyway. Visually, it's not very impressive. The whole thing felt like a 7th gen console game rather than a PC game in the worst way. The story seems pretty interesting at first, but it really doesn't go anywhere, and it gets rather heavy-handed at parts. I cannot stress enough how bad the stealth is, and it's not like you can build your loadout around stealth either since there are many areas where you're forced to fight out in the open. I found this game to be very cryptic in its storytelling, and the ending left me confused. [spoiler]There is a true ending that can only be obtained by getting enough "points" throughout the game. This is never explained. The way you get these points is by either performing good deeds like donating a few shells to beggars or exploring hidden corners of the map and finding evidence of life before the apocalypse, which is sometimes accompanied by a flashback. (It is never explained how Artyom is able to see these.) The only indication that you have received one of these points is a sound cue and a white flash on your screen. It is not explained what the significance of collecting these points is, how many you have, how many you need to get the good ending, or even that collecting them yields a better ending than the default one.[/spoiler] I'm all for secrets in games but finding the secrets in this game did not feel rewarding. The payoff really isn't worth it either. All you get is a slightly different cinematic at the end. I have no idea if the sequels to this game are any good but I feel confident in saying that you can go ahead and skip this one.

This is one of those "meh" reviews where there is no YES or NO answer. I'm leaning towards no, but that would mean it's a bad game - it's not. 

[h1]Books[/h1]
If you've read the books, this is an incredibly shallow adaptation where everything is oversimplified into a shooting gallery. If you did not read the books, then you still get a story that's falling apart with instantly forgettable characters who all look and sound the same, with a very anti-climactic ending. You will find files to read that add to the context but it's a very out of place and outdated format to add more depth to a story they sort of failed to well represent. Artyom having inner mologues during some walking or crawling sections could've been better, perhaps.

[h1]Overall atmosphere[/h1]
What the game is incredibly good at is providing you with a unique atmosphere. It *is* beautiful in it's own, post-apocalyptic way, and there are some much welcome mechanics that modern games no longer use such as stealth where enemies are not blind-deaf, smartly placed wire traps I've last seen in Vietcong. This is very much a rail-FPS and pun aside that means there are no choices, and maybe only one or two levels have small optional routes for discovery. Checking corners is very rewarding, but in general you should not worry about ammo or "money-ammo" you'll have more than plenty enough in hard + survival on your first playthrough. 
[h1]Lenght[/h1]
The game is roughly 8-9 hours long, my playtime comes from starting and abandoning it twice in the past decade until I finally finished it now. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
One off from the bucket list, but honestly? I've been shooting at giant rats, giant monkeys, and giant gorillas - all the same "it runs at you so you shoot it" archetype of 0 creativity enemies, so the overall gameplay is quite boring when it comes to monsters, the best parts of the game are definitely the stealthy-firefights against hostile people. 

Is it worth it? Look, if you've not picked this up on one of the million Steam sales, Steam free gifts, Epic free gift, Fanatical / GMG / Humble bundles, you can pick this up for 4,99 anytime you want during any sale of any store. But to me, it was a little bit of a wasted time because as an FPS it's not too creative or exciting, as a METRO story you are way better off reading the books for an even better atmoshpere and far more depth. I think the developers chose the wrong format to adapt this story, it should've been a survival horror with action elements, instead it's a rail shooter action game with *some* horror / survival elements at certain points. Resident Evil 7 and 8 managed to do twice as much story and mystery with actually satisfying discovery of the story, from the fraction of the source material METRO devs had.

[h1] A great story packed into a nice FPS [/h1]

[b] Overall [/b]: 7/10

Metro 2033 is all about a great post-apocalyptical story, spread across numerous chapters, and packed into a nice FPS. A definitive must do for any shooter lover who is looking for a great scenario.

[b] Gameplay [/b] : 7/10

The game tries to remain as realistic as possible while maintaining some fun. Therefore, the gunplay can feel a bit heavy at times and movements are not the smoothest I know. However, I loved the fact that we can choose between 2 game modes, one turned toward realism and one more arcady.

[b] Graphics [/b] : 7/10

A nice engine, nice FX. Very much acceptable for 2022 even.

[b] Story [/b] : 9/10

No spoilers but a great adventure set in a post-apocalyptic Moscow.

[b] Achievements [/b] : 9/10

All of the achievements are straightforward and can be grabbed along the story. 2 playthrough required. No Grinding.

I tried so hard to like this game. I played the original for 2 hours straight and couldn't get into it but decided to buy the Redux version a couple of years later to give it a fair shake. I still didn't like it so even more years later I am playing it again and sadly, I am still just not impressed.

The game feels janky. There is a slight microstutter that isn't consistently there. No frame dips though and the game does run smooth in terms of performance. The mouse doesn't suffer from the janky-ness though it does have an issue in which the horizontal sensitivity is significantly higher than the vertical. This cannot be adjusted independently.
Speaking of janky, the animations aren't smooth to me at all. This makes the creatures so difficult to shoot. Coupled with the fact that the character moves so ridiculously slow, the combat feels terribly unbalanced. It's like the game can't decide if it wants to be a fast paced action shooter like Doom or something slower and more methodical so they tried to pick a middle ground and got it all wrong. This will of course be subjective opinion.
The game supports 21:9 but the FOV is SICKENINGLY NARROW and cannot be adjusted in game.
The sound effects, which are one of the most important things to me in a game, are terrible. Guns sound like toys and all the other little things are weak sounding as well. I would say the poor sound effects are by far the most disappointing aspect.

They talk about being a survival horror game but to succeed at that I think they need to clean up the animations some and slow the creatures down as well as spawn in less of them then provide less ammo to balance it out. The hit boxes are off a bit too as I occasionally shoot one like 5 ft away and I see dust/snow kick up off the ground behind it but yet the creature seems unaffected.

I like the theme and setting plus the level design really is impressive when it comes down to the little details. However, the beauty of a game's visuals is never enough to save it, in my mind.

EDIT: one last thing I forgot to mention...there is no manual saving. No quicksaving either. Just stupid checkpoint autosaves.

This game is kinda short even for normal difficulty and after all i went through theres no way in hell i would torture myself with the highest difficulty,its just not worth the stress.

The only reason it took me around 10hrs to finish it was due to some faulty checkpoints and some exploration,speakin of which...

There were some instances where the game actually punished me for exploring and wouldnt let me just admire the enviroments,to the point i literally legged the hell out of two entire sections of the game in frustration and some glitches forced me to wander around wasting ammo and time which led me to look up gameplay videos only to realize the npcs didnt said their lines to let me know what was i supposed to do in a new section where theres literally no indication of what you are supposed to do unless you wander around getting swarmed by mutants and get lucky pressing the action button on 2 very specific spots.

The plot is okay and interesting at some points,it has some sort of supernatural element,sadly,it does nothing to expand it and ends up feeling lackluster by the end. 

The dynamic between the characters whenever you are in an squad is entertaining and decent enough.

The fire grenades are useless,somehow throwing 5 of them at a bunch of mutants clipping in to eachother is less effective than a couple of well placed handgun shots and i couldnt find a single instance on which i could rely on them which sucks,considering there are several parts where you get swarmed by enemies and its one of the resources you loot the most.

Constant crashes towards the last 3 hours of the game turned an otherwise good experience in to a frustrating rush to the next check point,managed to fix them but the damage to my experience was already done,so i am very glad i bought it dirt cheap during a sale,otherwise i would be furious.

I really wanted to love this game (the atmosphere,the enviroments,the setting and the characters are really good),but for everything it did right,there were atleast 2 or 3 frustrating things setting it back from being great,id argue it would have worked better as an interactive story game rather than a shooter.

This game took about 10 hours to beat. Many scary moments, good fps mechanics, lots of stealth (or fighting). There's a hardcore "survival ranger" mode with no HUD and scarce resources, which I quite enjoyed, and there is a "metro: exodus inspired" FPS action mode as well, for those who prefer to shoot a lot. 

Most notably, the game feels like a classic FPS story. Great world, based on a book series. Systems that make you feel connected to the world and do not undermine your immersion, a common issue in modern games.

Its kind of like Tarkov meets Half-Life... 

Can't wait to play the second two installments!

The original is so much better. There is a lot more bugs in this one than what I remember from the original. Not, like, tiny annoying bugs that don't really matter. I'm talking about bugs that make the game unplayable and impossible to progress.

To be fair, it does have significantly better graphics and other quality of life improvements. But the cons outweigh the pros for me. It's a shame the classic Metro 2033 is so hard to find. This is such a great experience for a 10-year old game. It's a short but very fun game and the setting is surprisingly very unique from other post-apocalyptic worlds in gaming. A bit mediocre gameplay and story-wise due to its age but I still had a blast playing it.

Story: The story is pretty basic and nothing special even from the previous decades' standards. It's just the typical story where the main character is trying to fight the horrors of the apocalypse and possibly saving the world. I won't deny, it actually gets pretty bland in the latter half and the last 2 chapters before the last one bored me quite a bit. There are also moments in the game that seemed too convenient for the player to just run into or discover.

Gameplay: The gameplay is also your average 2000s FPS with short and easy platforming and little to nothing puzzle solving. However, the small details in the gameplay is what makes it so special, like pumping your pneumatic guns, charging your flashlight manually, looting bombs from disabled traps, even wiping your gas mask and many more. These simple things really brings out the post-apocalyptic vibe and adds a sense of realism and scarcity in resources. I also love the iron sights on this game as it felt accurate compared to other games from its era where the iron sights are total garbage. Aside from gun combat you can also opt to kill enemies stealthily although I do not recommend this because the stealth in this game is very very clunky.

Sound & Visuals: The graphics are all right, they are nothing new, nothing special. Although, I appreciate that they revamped most of the major character's faces so that you can distinguish them more properly now compared to the original. The guns' design and customization are amazing, you can really see that the developers tried their best to fit the look of these guns in the post-apocalyptic setting. The ambiance also is amazing, its has that constant eerie, unsettling and dangerous vibe in it that you seemingly cannot escape even in safe areas. On the other hand, the voice acting is very bad, it seemed just like the minimal effort from most of the main characters while the children NPCs are downright cringe-inducing. It also did not help that the main character had a non-speaking role which breaks the immersion.

Enjoyment: Although a lot of bad things can be said about this game, it is still actually pretty enjoyable even in today's standards. As long as you can put up with the mediocrity of the other aspects of the game the immersion will carry it for you.

This game is a masterpiece. However, for those new to the game, there is one section that I must advise is probably a deal breaker.

There is a section in the game where you are put on a "Onrails" shooting section that is possibly the most difficult thing in the entire series. I'm not even joking. It is around halfway in and I won't be going into spoilers but it is something that ruined my game for around a day.

There is a bug where the enemies won't spawn at one section, which somehow makes you vehicle instantly die when taking any form of damage at the next part of the level. Which is an absolute pain in the ass. No matter what happens, you will always die. Even if every enemy is killed.

To pass this part, exit to the main menu and restart the entire level. If it happens again, restart it again. And this is on the easiest difficulty of Normal. I haven't tried it on the harder difficulties.

An amazing story, an excellent world building and lore, and amazing controls and shooting for a game this old, my only gripe with it was the FOV but that was fixed by editing the .cfg file in 

AppData\Local\4A Games\Metro 2033\110000114a6feab

just use Ctrl+F to find the FOV settings and change the value to your desired fov, for me changing it 83 was enough because that meant the fov in game was changed to 110

First-person plus slow-pacing adds gravity to your every move. Visually, the shadows could use some work, so maybe set your gamma a bit higher than what's recommended, if your eyes strain from the darkness. The story is probably my favorite part. You walk in and out of many distinct characters lives, getting a good incomplete picture of all the major sites from whats left of civilization. 

     Wish some areas were more interactive. The outside scenes of action were, while when you arrive at a new station they are mostly a pretty sight with places to stock up on ammo and medicine. Sometimes I get the feeling I'm an outsider watching a long cinematic rather than playing as Artyom. 

     And why make him the silent type? It works in Half-Life because you spend it mostly alone, but here you get repeated questions and directives, awaiting a response, followed by an awkward silence, all because the only narration you offer must oddly be kept to reading aloud from your diary at the end of a chapter. Also, typos and bad grammar in them. And while I'm complaining: locking a "good" ending behind collectables is always a bad decision. It makes the surreal sequences and warnings from Khan feel like a buildup to nothing. I get that it's incentive to replay, but for such a short scene I could just look it up instead of tediously collecting notes and whatever else. The game is a bit buggy, as it froze once, and apparently more often for others. The physics of the game engine is wonky. If you've played a Source Engine game and ever tried moving an object against wall, then see as it proceeds to have a breakdown, you'll get what I mean. And the NPC kids live in uncanny valley territory. 

    Still, the majority of the story remains atmospheric with memorable characters. More common than those sore spots of melodrama are sequences where the story finds life in homespun stoicisms. Khan is my favorite, as his presence brought an otherwordliness the dream sequences could not. The environmental storytelling is on par with other good post-apocalyptic entries. The world is starkly, even disgustingly beautiful. Crawling out of the dark to see a cloudy sky eventually fills you with both relief and dread. Those scenes of terror from holding off mutants with, becoming a one-man-army in the process, are so much fun. I could sense every step, every bullet taken. Whether alone or with NPCs, yelling into dark, the experience is always a roller coaster. First impressions of this are pretty positive.

Only having played through this game once i can say i will be returning, Metro 2033 offers an immersive world in which i was able to sink myself into.

Starting with the game play itself, Metro is not overly complex however elements of tracking heals and gas mask filters is vital especially in the harder difficulties. The atmosphere in the world is unreal, so many times i would catch myself fully immersed only to be taken out by getting scared. While not being predominantly a horror the elements of horror really shine thanks to the atmosphere players find themselves in. While playing this game i felt as though the plot was rather consistent with very little blunders in it, even the notes found help deepen the understanding of this apocalyptic world and its horrors on the surface.

My only real flaw with this game was the gun play, by no means being bad the variety was very minimal while making sense for the setting the subsequent games have more variety while only being set a year ahead of 2033. I found myself only really using two guns and while stealth was often encouraged many places it felt very unreliable whether its against creatures on the surface or humans underground. But by no means does this ruin the game it is just one aspect and the only one i disliked.

Overall, this is the best story game i have played in years. Having me on the edge of my seat so often, its world building allowed me to place myself in the Metro world and really enjoy what the game has to offer.

Metro 2033 Redux is a remaster of sorts of Metro 2033 which is an FPS game following the story of a book by the same name by Dmitry Glukhovsky. 

Set in a post-apocalyptic Russia after a nuclear strike by the West, it follows Artyom's journey through the Russian metro system to warn other stations of an incoming attack by some strange forces.

The game is pretty linear, meaning you have to go from point A to point B to advance to the next level and so on, it does have some markets in some stations to buy or trade for weapons, bullets, medkits, filters, etc.

Overall I recommend it, the game holds up pretty well by today's standards and the story will keep you entertained for a while. It has a very dark atmosphere and it's very immersive too. It also features 2 endings which is nice and gives some replayability. 

Performance wise, I remember playing it on a 650Ti Boost at my time of playing, then a 970 and it ran fine both times, haven't tested it in more modern hardware but it should run fine.

Good: The atmosphere is great; really liked that. The story is interesting and the sets are very detailed. Fantastic work on that aspect. Also works on my PoS computer, which (I thought) was a good thing for me.

Bad: This is one of those games that try to be 'realistic' with its game mechanics. Your character has bad aim unless you upgrade your weapons. The monsters have wonky hitboxes. Combine the two and you get a fun time. It also has a very annoying mechanic: the gas masks. Sometimes you have to go into places with bad air and you need to put on a gas mask. They use filters that you have to scavenge for or buy. This feels like being rushed and you just can't explore...

This game has like 2 game modes and 2 difficulty levels or something which change the experience; I forget what they do and don't care.  I wrote this review out of frustration at the game, so take that into consideration as well. I was excited to try it and neglected to research it. Lesson Learned... meh.

Finished this game last night. It was a great time and with the current steam sale it would be criminal not to pick this game up. These are my pros and cons.

Pro:
- Great Story/Characters
- Great Visuals
-Great Voice Acting and really cool we can also toggle Russian Voice Acting with subtitles
- Makes every resource matter and makes it rewarding to search every nook, space, body  for valuable resources.

Cons:
- Lackluster/barely any weapon customization/upgrades
- Weapons felt like they did  terrible damage like enemies still living after several headshots with a shotgun or ak.
- Enemies have too much health. 
- Only has autosave and no option to save progress manually

Overall it was a great experience and I can't wait to try out the other metro titles.

Metro 2033 Redux takes players on a haunting and atmospheric journey through the dark and treacherous tunnels of the Moscow Metro. Based on Dmitry Glukhovsky's novel, this game is a remarkable survival horror experience that immerses you in a world where humanity clings to existence amidst mutated creatures and political turmoil.

The atmosphere in Metro 2033 Redux is nothing short of captivating. The dimly lit tunnels, dripping with suspense and tension, create an oppressive and claustrophobic ambiance. The attention to detail in the environmental design, from graffiti-covered walls to dilapidated stations, adds to the immersion and paints a vivid picture of a world ravaged by a nuclear catastrophe.

The storytelling in Metro 2033 Redux is masterful. The narrative unfolds through the eyes of Artyom, a young survivor tasked with navigating the hostile Metro and its factions. The richly developed characters, coupled with the exploration of moral choices and the exploration of the human condition, create a thought-provoking and emotionally engaging experience.

Gameplay-wise, Metro 2033 Redux strikes a balance between intense combat and stealth. Ammunition is scarce, encouraging resourceful approaches and well-timed stealth takedowns. The array of weapons and attachments allows for customization and adaptation to different combat situations. However, it's important to note that the game truly shines in its ability to make you feel vulnerable and in constant danger.

The Redux version of Metro 2033 brings improved graphics and enhanced gameplay mechanics, further immersing you in the haunting atmosphere of the Moscow Metro. The updated visuals make the world come alive with increased detail and atmospheric lighting effects. Combined with the exceptional sound design, the game delivers an audio-visual experience that heightens the tension and makes every encounter pulse-pounding.

In conclusion, Metro 2033 Redux is a gripping and atmospheric journey through the depths of the Metro. With its immersive storytelling, oppressive atmosphere, and a perfect blend of combat and stealth mechanics, it stands as a testament to the power of narrative-driven survival horror. If you crave a post-apocalyptic experience that challenges both your skills and your conscience, Metro 2033 Redux is a must-play.

This game was the start of my favorite gaming series. It is a relatively short compared to other games but an extremely intense experience. It offers a magnificent world that pays great tribute to the books on which it is based. The immersion is superb, and the gameplay is simply fantastic. The story is equally impressive.

Of course, it is somewhat limited since the developers were not a big studio, but they made the best out of it, and you can feel the love that was poured into this project. Graphically, you can hardly tell that it was created by a small studio. Although the game is a bit older, it has still aged incredibly well.

I can only recommend this game. Everyone should play it at least once because the experience is simply amazing. Get it and experience this world for yourself.

[h1]4/10[/h1] Really disappointing. Seems like at one point this game was supposed to be open world - they have "outposts" and traders etc. but was scrapped. Kind of sad. Clearly inspired by Stalker. The atmosphere is there but the combat is ass. Guns feel shit and you fight the same mutant lizards for the whole game. The dialogue is laughably bad. The Russian VA is trash too, which is surprising, characters talk in the same monotone voice. The animations are stiff and glitchy. The ending is one of the worst in any game ever. Cool premise but executed poorly.

I really, really, love this game, and it was recommended to me by a friend on Discord (you know who you are wink wink). I love how it captured the desolate atmosphere of what remained of Moscow, Russia twenty years after a global nuclear catastrophe. It also immersed me into the post-apocalyptic horror scenery, encountering various mutants and even factions that made me curse out of frustration every time I died to them. Yeah, it was the first non-SW game that I finished, so please forgive me for my fucked up learning curve, and to all those who are gonna pick up this game, keep in mind that this relies upon a lot of stealth mechanics and some wits to keep your ammo and military grade ammo (the main currency in this game) on check. But yeah, the story was actually good, the characters were compelling, and your actions throughout the game would definitely bear some major consequences as you play. For someone who dreads the horror aspect of the game, it was still enjoyable for the gameplay - regardless of the modes and difficulty levels. 

If you like post-apocalyptic films and books (by the way, there's a novel with the same name along with the other two sequels) and games, along with a lot of stealth (you can shoot your way out still which can be a challenge, I did that a lot as a first timer HAHA), then this game is for you.

Fantastic remaster that brings some QoL improvements and can usually be picked up for a song. It does lack a bit of the atmosphere of the original, being brighter in some of the darker areas and some of the mutant redesigns are, in my opinion at least, inferior to the original, mainly just being Last Light's redesigns. Some of the more unfair sections have been rebalanced and are more enjoyable but the trolley chase is still absolutely awful, like unbelievably bad in it's design and implementation. Not to mention it is also a particularly buggy area that is prone to scripting errors including enemies not spawning, random instant deaths and NVG being stuck to your face leaving you blind. The two former problems can be solved by restarting the chapter but the NVG bug requires you to replay the previous one and to remove the NVG before exiting the level. Really, really stupid and indicative of a lack of quality control. Aside from that, really good and well worth a buy.

I switch between my PC and Steam Deck constantly, so being unable to sync my saves between them kills the game. Why would I play a game I can only play on one platform at a time when I could play anything else in my library?

To my knowledge too, this is an issue with the whole franchise. Last Light is reported to have it, and while Exodus syncs save data, it also syncs GRAPHICS CONFIGURATIONS. Deep Silver, pull your head out of your a-s and fix the cloud saves, it is NOT a difficult job.

İlk olarak tavuklarımızı haşlamak için tencereye koyuyoruz ve üzerini bir parmak geçecek şekilde su ekleyerek kaynamaya bırakıyoruz.
Haşlanan tavuklarımızı soğuması için kenara alıyoruz.
Biraz soğuduğunda tavuklarımızı tiftikliyeceğiz.
Bu sırada pirinçlerimizi de ılık suya koyup nişastasının çıkmasını bekliyoruz.
Pilav tenceresine yağımızı ekleyip eridiğinde şehriyelerimizi kavuruyoruz.
Şehriyelerin rengi değişip, kokusu çıktığında pirinçlerimizi de ekliyoruz ve 5-10 dakika kadar daha kavuruyoruz.
Daha sonra pirinçimizin üzerine tiftiklediğimiz tavuğumuzu ekliyoruz.
1 bardak tavuk suyu ve 2 bardak kaynamış suyunu da ekledikten sonra tuz ve karabiberi de ilave edip bir kere karıştırıyoruz ve kapağını kapatarak kısık ateşte pişmeye bırakıyoruz. Ben pilav pişirirken çok fazla karıştırmıyorum size de böyle tavsiye ederim.
Pilavımız suyunu çekip tane tane olduğunda altını kapatıp, kapağın üzerine demlenmesi için kağıt havlu koyuyoruz. Servis yaparken havluyu alarak afiyetle pilavımızı yiyoruz. Ellerinize sağlık.

[h1] Redux Review[/h1] 
I recently got to play the redux version for the first time. I can’t really tell which content was directly taken over from last light (or the redux which I didn’t play) as I don’t have that many memories with that game as I played only the original a couple of times. Original review [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/Lord_Sithaniel/recommended/43110/] here [/url]


[u]Gameplay[/u]
I think the biggest and best change was the economy. If you play on survival mode on the highest difficulty, you don’t have tons of money anymore to spare due to you not directly getting a super expensive weapon 1/3 through the game which you can use throughout the rest of the game or sell for lots of bullets. The whole weapon evolution is done in a way much proper manner, meaning you can find or buy better versions of existing weapons slowly throughout the game, forcing you to use different types of weapons.  Also you can buy attachments for weapons on your own.

Additionally, you aren’t required to have a revolver, and can sell weapons and just go with whatever you find. I don’t like that the grenade and knife aren’t equipable items anymore, takes off a bit of the realism but gameplay wise they are way much more useful now, so I give it a pass.

Gameplay is still the same, although the maps that have optional stealth sequences are now way much better suited for that playstyle, making more logical map layouts trough very small changes. I like this a lot, especially that you can now knock out or right out kill people in melee combat in a silent way. For some reason the non-lethal method is faster than the lethal one making it rather useless to use.

Also new weapons are added which as mentioned slowly upgrade your gear but also keep the homemade weapon fashion. My highlight was a revolving shotgun made with a bike saddle as a shoulder stock. Great stuff!

On a side note, I’m not really sure but I feel the game is way much more difficult. Gun handling changed slightly but on both spartan and survivor modes more enemies appeared, or they took much more of a beating. Welcome change as I found the base game too easy, even on max difficulty combat encounters aren’t that much of a challenge.

[u]Sound[/u]
There are new musical pieces who I really really like. Most noticeable during the loading screens, but some environmental ones changed too, I really like that, giving me something new and fresh while still fitting to the tone of the game.

[u]Graphics[/u]
General improvement in every aspect, albeit I didn’t overanalyse any changes or anything. It just looks in general much better, additionally gasmasks have now actual huge visual impact. You can even clean it if it goes dirty via blood mostly but its fading away eventually on its own and the visual hinderance is not that big.

The only negative thing I have to say is the reload animation for the old weapons. It’s weird, for the spartan mode these are sped up, and for survivor slowed down. But some are apparently animated for the sped-up version first and then slowed down and for some its vice versa making some odd looking/feeling reloading animations. And even then, the base weapons from the original had better ones, having way much more weight behind the gun, especially when Artyom is slamming the magazine inside or onto the gun.

Also i personally liked the old hud way much more, this one is clearly more tendered towards a console audience. There is also a bug i didnt had in the previous version, when i hit ESC to open the menu/pause the game, my mouse often gets stuck at one corner of the screen, probably due to my second screen.

Big warning tough, the game has terrible performance if you turn SSAA. I have a 3060(laptop) and AMD Ryzen 5600h and 16GB Ram. If i put everything on max, and SSAA off i have 144+ FPS with SSAA 4x 32 FPS+-. No idea what they did wrong, isnt SSAA supposed to be better FPS wise than MSAA? Anyways if someone has problems just lower the SSAA as they did something wrong there.

[u]Conclusion/TL;DR[/u]
Really successful remake of a game I liked. Everything except the tedious trailing missions are now improved, from gun upgrades to better suited reworks of stealth focused maps or general upgrades of the graphical aspects of this game.  While some aspects i personally prefered from the older games, i solely dislike that they dont give you the decision anymore which edition to play, as i really like playing both and seeing the differences.

Great fps where the redux improves some combat aspects and a lot of visuals.

Only thing that was different color gradient, from more brighter to pitch black textures. Here enemies do visually differ, but they totally broke their behavior. Now all their unscripted animations are extremely twitchy and their models flies everywhere. Looks like Get Down - Geddan, legit. You're done if you couldn't manage to kill mutants in their scripted appear / scene animation, be cause when "Geddan" by "Get Down" starts right after it, they'll shorten the distance between you and them in a brief moment and will shake your screen so gawd damn hard you won't feel ur left leg, making shootin near imposible (damage is not that big even on Ranger diff, feels too weak after playing games like STALKER Anomaly, Gamma and Misery).

Yea, it's not that big of a deal when you got mass damage dealing weapons, high damage & rate of fire ARs and SMGs and shottys. Again - "when you got" them. At the very beggining of the game when you're about to enter Riga Station if I remember it right, you'll have shootout with mutants and you CLEARLY can see that their animation is not supposed to be like that when machine gun from the other side starts to shoot them. Their models just go haywire.

Stealth is even more broken than in original. You might be at the very start of the level and enemies on the other end of the map are somehow already aware of your presence, that's how it feels...

TL;DR

Visuals - Better than original.
Gameplay - Significantly worse than original.

First game of the Metro Series and although the game is a bit short, and is turning 10 years old next year, I still recommend this for a play through.  It is a FPS but is quite slow and atmospheric.  It's not the typical FPS which is full of action.  There's quite a limited variety of guns and enemies and generic story.  I am not a fan of the last stage which is a trial and error without much action, but I appreciate them trying to mix up the game play.  It's sort of like a survival horror at times, and maybe when it was first released, it had more impact.  Still, I treat this as an introduction to the series and it made me excited to play the next 2 installments so good job on giving a nice first game to the series.

Although the setting is very unique, they did a great job with the voice acting, and the story isn't too terrible. But this game SEVERELY lacks enemy variety. At the point where I quit playing about 7 and a half hours in, there's been only about 4 non-human enemies up to that point with only one type dominating most of the encounters. 

The gameplay is really just a drag-and-drop first-person shooter. No bells and whistles added just point and click. Which is too bad because the game seriously could use something extra to not end up boring me to tears. The game also often utilizes respawning enemies with you being required to grab a certain item to progress. I found that really annoying and disappointing. If you like that type of gameplay though then perhaps this is for you. But I just can't recommend a game that bored me and doesn't have much unique outside of the world. Not to mention there is an atrocious on-rails shooting section which just keeps going.

I remember first seeing Metro 2033's trailer years ago which made me buy the book before release and fall in love with the setting and lore. I originally had the game on Xbox and absolutely loved it - the environments, gunplay and graphics were fantastic and I played through multiple times.

I didn't buy Redux when it initially came out, but when I saw it on sale recently I had the urge to play through it again so I picked it up on the cheap. Seeing it with updated graphics made me fall in love with it all over again - the Redux version is fantastic and for anyone who loves atmospheric games, shooters, stealth or even survival horror games should definitely pick this up too.

If you're new to this, I'd recommend playing on Spartan mode to ease yourself into it and then after your first playthrough you have to play on Ranger Hardcore (survival). It basically turns the game into an extremely challenging survival horror experience which is incredibly satisfying to complete. Also, for added atmosphere, keep your brightness low and play with Russian language enabled with English subtitles.

The only negatives I can say is that I did experience a couple of random CTDs for seemingly no reason and often background chatter subtitles don't actually appear which means you can miss some tidbits of information. This isn't a huge issue, but if like me you enjoy playing it in Russian with English subtitles for that added immersion then you can miss some dialogue. 

9/10 for me, and remember: Artyom, if it's hostile, you kill it.

Great Game! From the atmospheric tunnels to the station cities the ambience was very unique. The game itself crashed a lot for me, and I clipped through the floor a total of 3 times. Also sometimes I had to look up a guide on where to go because I was unable to find a hole where you had to drop down to continue or for like which crack in the wall was i suppose to crawl in. And yes, that's after using the compass thingy, which actually does not do a good job at letting you know where to go when things are on top of each other. Also the library section towards the end of game, I hated it. Was not fun, and can you even kill those ogre mutant librarian monster? I do not know, I emptied all my weapons but it did not die. So I just pulled up my compass and ran straight to the exit. I wanted to explore, see more of the library. There were a lot of good moments too, like the church safe house before heading on to D6. Also the first sequence with Khan and all the ghosts (after bourbon dies) was really really good. 

Overall, my rating would be a solid 8/10. Really innovative on immersion and environment.

[h1]An Unique FPS Game with a Great Story...[/h1]

I've been a FPS fan since I played Far Cry 3. I heard a lot about the [b]Metro[/b] franchise. The story developed brilliantly throughout the whole franchise. I'll point out some of the things that I liked most...

[+] Voice Acting was good as for the NPCs

[+] Graphical Details were top notch

[+] Gun Mechanism & Gunfire sound was satisfying

[+] No pointless quests

[+] Lighting of the Environment was truly mind-blowing!

[+] None of the weapon felt overpowered & there were quite a variety of them

[+] Loots & Resources were well balanced

[+] No noticeable problem with graphics optimisation

[+] Animation physics were excellent.. like pulling off the gas mask, opening doors etc

[+] Story was engaging & made sense


[-] Will [b]Artyom[/b] ever talk?

[-] No real guideline often puzzled the path

[i]Looking forward to play the next metro game & yes of course I want to play the latest addition [b]Metro Exodus[/b]! [b]Giving it a rating of 80/100[/b][/i]

Not a bad game, gave it a try a couple of times before, which is why I have 18 hours in the game, when the game takes a total of about 9-10 Hours to beat!

Like I said, it's not a bad game, and a lot more fun than I initially thought it would be, the only thing that I disliked was the small amount of guns available, and the attachments for them, the ending "Fight" was pretty dumb, and the ending cut-scene was pretty scuffed.

All in all, not a bad game, and I had fun with the Gameplay I got!

"Steam Deck Verified", oh except that cloud saves don't work. Now I am stuck playing this entire game on my Steam Deck. Spent like 2 hours trying various "fixes" that didn't work before finally realizing I could just beat the game in the time I was going to waste trying to figure it out. I also tried remote play from my Deck to my main PC to at least play it on a bigger screen, just got a black screen. Awesome stuff.

So yeah, this game will run on your Steam Deck, but make sure you want to play the *entire* game on your Steam Deck.

Also, every time you launch the game, the whole intro sequence is like a full minute of unskippable stuff. It's infuriating. 

The game itself is fun, still the same game it was when it originally released, but it looks better. I probably won't bother finishing it because of the issues mentioned above.

Metro 2033 Redux remains an enjoyable experience for fans of the book and the post-apocalyptic genre. The game successfully captures the essence of the source material, offering a gripping plot, atmospheric environments, and detailed gameplay mechanics.

However, a notable drawback of the game is its fast-paced gameplay, which can detract from fully understanding and appreciating the world and its events. The protagonist is constantly pushed to complete tasks quickly, making it difficult to take in the intricacies of the environment. This rushed gameplay undermines the sense of immersion and discovery that could have been achieved.

Furthermore, Metro 2033 Redux lacks a comprehensive narrative that delves into the backstory of the world and its characters. While the plot is engaging, there is a missed opportunity to provide deeper context and a more fleshed-out exploration of the game's universe. Additionally, the predefined levels often offer only one way to progress, limiting the player's freedom and sometimes leading to unclear paths.

Another aspect that could have been improved is the absence of in-game tutorials. Many important mechanics and features must be discovered by the player themselves, which can be frustrating and hinder the overall experience. A more informative and intuitive tutorial system would have been beneficial.

Metro 2033 REDUX is the engine-improved remake of the original Metro 2033, and is almost entirely the same in terms of actual gameplay. It's a dark, dreary game that has some issues but is still a great experience.

To start, visual fidelity. It's a mixed bag, mostly due to the game's age. Animations are stiff and wonky, some effects (like flies buzzing on your gasmask) are not very well done, and there can be some clipping issues. However, this all pales in comparison to the actual textures, models, and environments. The game is a gorgeous look even all these years later. Everything looks dreary, dilapidated, and grungy. The monsters are horrific mutants, the tunnels feel abandoned and desolate, it's just an extremely well executed visual style.

Audio design is top notch as well, bar the voice acting. Guns range from sounding like they were made with shoddily crafted parts (a good thing in this case) to sounding like real powerhouses. Monsters sound fierce, and each has an extremely distinct audio design as well which is much appreciated. Voice Acting is a bit meh though. Very few actual voice actors worked on the game (14 in Total) with each of them not really putting much effort into making every character sound unique or interesting, which is annoying given the sheer volume of dialogue you'll hear. Hell, half the characters are Yuri Lowenthal doing one of the most lazy Russian accents I've heard, and I don't dislike the guy.

For the story, you'll hate me for this. [b]The book did it better.[/b] With that out of the way, the story isn't bad but it has some caveats. You're a wanna be Ranger who gets given a mission to save your underground station home from a new threat in the metro tunnels of a post apocalypse Moscow. It has plenty of action, plenty of horror, and a bit of intrigue. The problems I have with it is that you don't really get attached to characters, and that the ending is abrupt. I won't delve into why for the sake of spoilers, but just know it's not as character driven as you might like.

Gameplay is varied, with there being two modes. Spartan and Survival. Spartan mode offers a more relaxed experience with more ammo, resources and a faster movement speed. Survival is the opposite, with fewer bullets, resources and a slower movement speed. I personally believe Survival is the better experience, as it makes every action count far more. Aside from the obvious of shoot enemies and move forward in the levels, as the game is linear, there are other mechanics that help the game feel unique and interesting. When on the surface or in poison fog, you'll need to both wear a gas mask and change it's filters. Stealth is entirely optional but allows the saving of resources for when you need them most. Cobwebs blocking your sight can be burned, and oil lamps can be short to set environments on fire. Gunplay is a little dated, but certainly not terrible. The only bad part is the excessive flinching when you are damaged, your character's camera will jump a foot up each time and it can get annoying.

Put all this together and you have a game that, while a bit dated, provides a unique FPS experience compared to other games in the genre. It's a great first game for the Metro series, and I'm glad it didn't end up forgotten by the world like Singularity or TimeShift.

One of the most thought-provoking, world-building-heavy and immersive games ever made. Graphics are stunning, sound design is quite good and music is impeccable. The environments feel so realistically horrifying and help with delivering the main messages and themes of the game to the player.

Throughout the entire game I only had 2 problems: the English voice acting is a bit goofy (I just switched to Russian Voice, English Subtitles) and the alternate ending is annoying to get: you have to make all the good decisions, listen to some conversations, play the game stealthily against humans (because apparently fighting back at extremist soldiers is bad) alongside other miscellaneous objectives. All of which is never explained to the player and they barely even know if they progressed in the morality system or not. Not only that, this doesn't even give the canon ending! Even though I engaged in most fights stealthily and made every good moral decision I came across, I didn't get this alternate ending so I ended up just watching a video on it instead of replaying the game with the wiki open to engage with this bullshit system.

That aside, Metro 2033 has been one of the best games I've played in a while and I'm definitely going to play the other 2 games in the series. As an added bonus, I'm able to support a Ukrainian developer. 100% buy this game.

Metro 2033 Redux, the remastered version of the popular post-apocalyptic shooter, attempts to improve upon its predecessor but falls short in several key areas. While it offers a dark and atmospheric world, it ultimately disappoints with its technical issues, lackluster gameplay mechanics, and missed opportunities for innovation.

One of the main drawbacks of Metro 2033 Redux is its inconsistent technical performance. Despite the visual enhancements, the game suffers from frequent frame rate drops, occasional glitches, and unresponsive controls. These issues detract from the immersive experience and can frustrate players, hindering their ability to fully engage with the narrative.

While the original Metro 2033 was known for its immersive storytelling, the Redux edition fails to capitalize on this aspect. The narrative feels disjointed at times, lacking the cohesion and emotional depth that made the original so compelling. Character development is underwhelming, with many individuals feeling one-dimensional and lacking meaningful interactions. As a result, it becomes challenging to form a genuine connection with the game's world and its inhabitants.

The gameplay in Metro 2033 Redux also leaves much to be desired. While the core mechanics remain intact, they feel dated and uninspired compared to modern first-person shooters. The combat encounters often devolve into repetitive shootouts, with limited variation in enemy encounters and tactics. Stealth mechanics, while present, feel underutilized and lack the depth and nuance seen in other stealth-focused games.

Another missed opportunity in Metro 2033 Redux is the lack of significant innovation or improvements beyond the visual upgrade. While the enhanced graphics are commendable, they alone cannot salvage a game that fails to deliver fresh ideas or meaningful gameplay enhancements. The Redux edition feels like a missed chance to introduce new mechanics, refine existing systems, or address long-standing player feedback.

Furthermore, the additional content included in Redux, such as the Ranger Mode, feels more like an afterthought than a substantial addition. While it does increase the game's difficulty, the lack of proper balancing and the absence of other noteworthy additions dampen its impact.

In conclusion, Metro 2033 Redux falls short of its potential as a remastered edition. Despite its atmospheric setting and the allure of the post-apocalyptic world, the game is marred by technical issues, underwhelming storytelling, and lackluster gameplay mechanics. While fans of the original may find some enjoyment in revisiting the Metro universe, newcomers may be left unimpressed by its outdated design and missed opportunities for innovation. Ultimately, Metro 2033 Redux fails to capture the essence of what made its predecessor a standout title in the genre.

I first played this game in 2010 and was blown away by the depth of the experience, the seamless cinematic scenes, and just generally the beauty of the world it created.  I had just played S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow of Chernobyl, and this game took all of that and raised it up dramatically into a visually stunning narrative.  It was truly immersed from the first moment until the last.

Now in 2023, I bought it in a package with the sequels (which I haven't played yet!) and just played through a good amount of it last night on Steam Deck.  Not only does it play perfectly on Deck, but it brought me right back to the same mental place I was in 2010.  I don't think hardcore or survival was an option the first time I played, and it definitely makes the horror of the experience that much more intense.  I can only survive a few hits and ammo is scarce, so I'm finding myself bypassing many more enemies instead of engaging, which absolutely adds to the immersion.  I'm really glad I picked this back up, and I will definitely be finishing this play through and moving onto the sequels.

Rating: ★★★★★

From the moment you start playing, you are immediately immersed in the world. The attention to detail in the setting is amazing, and captures the beauty of the destruction of civilisation. Every flickering light, crumbling ruins and lurking shadows add to the tension and create an amazing experience.

Based on Dmitry Glukhovsky's novel of the same name, the story follows Artyom's quest to travel underground to save his people from an impending threat. The great story combined with characters you meet along the way, add to the depth and emotional weight of the overall experience. The game amazingly ties in considerations, personal struggles and emotional questions to make you feel more than just an ordinary shooter. 

In terms of gameplay, Metro excels in offering different styles of approach. Resources are scarce, which forces you to shoot carefully and to count your shots, it also heavily encourages you to scrounge for supplies such as ammo, filters and other essentials. The game rewards you and encourages you to use the shadows and stealth to your advantage to eliminate enemies. However when the fighting kicks up, the game becomes a stressful and adrenaline pumping experience, with a total of 10 weapons at your disposal and with a variety of customisation such as sights, lasers and silencers.

In addition to all that, the Redux version includes "Ranger mode", which is a fantastic option for those looking for more challenges and realism.

Metro 2033 Redux is an unforgettable post apocalyptic world, with a captivating narrative, beautiful setting and amazing gameplay, and it is a testament to the power of story telling which games these days are so lacking of. Whether you're a fan of shooters or just want an engaging immersive experience, Metro 2033 is a game that will leave you in awe.

As a fan of the first Metro game, I have to say this Redux version is the one to get. Not just for the graphics (though they do look spectacular, even compared to the original version) but for the many minor improvements to the gameplay experience.

The first game is based on a novel with the same name - which I also highly recommend reading. Although the novel is more complex and many of the events and characters go differently, the core story is the same. The setting is based on a future post-apocalyptic Russia in the aftermath of a nuclear war (here's to still hoping this increasingly believable scenario never turns into reality). The games and novels are set within Moscow in particular, where the survivors dwell within the Metro stations and over time formed multiple communities and factions, and are often at conflict with one another and face political struggles. Some are neutral, some are capitalist, some are fascist, and some even communist. However, mankind's inability to unite and make peace is just part of the problem as the city's outdoors are drenched with radiation and both, the city and the Metro alike are full of dangerous mutants. Suffice to see, the world is as grim as it can get. There is something disturbing about the fact that some kids are born without ever having seen Earth's sky. The story follows Artyom, one of many Metro dwellers being tasked by a Ranger to assist with an upcoming threat involving "Dark Ones" - a group of mysterious mutants that are almost impossible to kill, and "appear" to be threatening what remains of humanity's existence.

The game has a fantastic setting and plot that truly grips you. Though the journey is linear, the game does have a moral point system that adds up depending on some choices you make along the way (e.g. choosing stealth over combat, sparing lives etc) and how much of your environment you are willing to explore and scavenge. If enough points are gained, then it is possible to experience 2 possible endings (though only one is canon). There are some truly inventive weapons along the way that Artyom can add to his arsenal, assuming the player is willing check various corners and barter/trade when able. In the Metro's world, bullets are the currency, not cash money. Thus it is important to both scavenge and conserve as much ammo as possible if you want to obtain some very cool weaponry. The player will experience many different scenarios along the way, from sneaking past (or fighting) Reds and Nazis in the tunnels to facing the terrifying librarians in the archives on Moscow's surface. 4A Games nailed many things, but nothing did they nail better than the incredibly dense and dark atmosphere - I can never forget the sequence walking with Khan past the ghosts.

So how does the Redux version fare compared to the original aside from graphics? Well, it is the same game for the most part. However, character models are different, and the gameplay is much more polished. The vanilla Metro 2033 suffered from broken stealth segments where it was not only difficult to avoid getting spotted, but also to stealth kill without raising the alarm. Thus combat was often inevitable if you didn't want to reload checkpoints multiple times. Redux fixes all that with much smoother stealth mechanics: you know more or less when you are visible or not, and you can either knock out or stealth-kill enemies without unexpectedly alerting the whole garrison. This time you have a genuine choice in how to approach situations, and that's all from just a bit of much-needed polish. Thank you for that!

I definitely recommend the series as a whole, but it's imperative that you start with this one. Metro 2033 is a great start to a deeply emotional trilogy, and in my opinion it nails the gloomy atmosphere the best. The fact that this Redux improves the whole experience is a welcome bonus.

I love this series. I obviously started with this game and immediately moved over to Last Light and Exodus and I must say, this has been one of the most fun and rewarding series of games I've ever played. This series is a must-play in my book for anyone who enjoys single-player games. 

Onto this game specifically, it is a true classic. The story is fantastic and is enthralling from the first mission to the very last. I decided to play a very normal way with the average difficulty and the easier play style instead of a harder difficulty and Spartan Mode, which I will be playing soon as I plan to replay the series again on the harder mode. The gun-play is also a standout feature, that melds together incredibly with the economy of the game. Another part of the game that made it so unique is both the setting and the enemies. The way the game keeps the underground levels fresh and interesting is wonderful considering how many studios of their size would usually use the same assets everywhere making the environment feel too familiar, they also do a great job of including things outside of the Metro to really spice things up. The monsters are also very different and interesting. The inclusion of some decent AI pathing and interactions with the environment, along with the variety of different monsters that really test your skills makes this game (and series) stand out.

Overall, I'll give this game a solid 9/10.

Metro 2033 Redux is a gripping game that immerses players in the dark depths of a post-apocalyptic Moscow! As a fan of atmospheric shooters, I found myself enthralled by the game's rich storytelling, tense gameplay, and chilling atmosphere.

The gameplay seeks a balance between stealth and furious first-person shooting combat. Players must explore hazardous environments while using stealth to eliminate enemies quietly or engage in heart-pounding firefights with a variety of weaponry. The scarcity of resources and ammo adds suspense and strategy to the game, forcing players to think carefully before engaging in combat. The survival mechanics, such as managing gas mask filters and using a hand-cranked torch, add to the immersion and difficulty of the game.

One of the game's strongest points is its attention to detail and world-building. The Metro is its own society, full with unique personalities and factions, each with its own set of objectives and beliefs. Conversations with these characters and observing their hardships bring depth and nuance to the story, making the world feel alive.

The Metro 2033 is an absolute must-play for fans of atmospheric and story-driven shooters. Its dark and immersive atmosphere, captivating narrative, stressful gameplay, and dedication to detail combine to create a remarkable post-apocalyptic journey. A journey that will take you to a haunting and atmospheric world, a journey worth taking!

Not surprised they give it away for free.

[TL;DR]

The graphics are beautiful and the atmosphere is nicely made. Good so far.
The rest is one massive meh.

[Plot]

By most part it is a conceptual ripoff of Fallout series morphed into FPS. Post-apocalyptic world, travel between stations which are full of demoralised people fallen into decadence. Interesting idea, but not particularly developed into anything more, thus monotonous. Gets boring quickly. The game is supposed to have some humour, but it is all just ancient Russian memes. You need to be Russian to find them funny.

[Graphics]

Pretty nice. Pretty, great ambience and colours.

[Gameplay]

There's probably an audience for this kind of games. It is not a traditional FPS, the whole gameplay revolves around walking around without any danger only to enter the dangerous zone where you have to fight the mandatory monster. Not just this grind is insane, boring and requires a huge investment of time and precise calculation, it feels dated and, again monotonous.

What else? Skip, not worth it. Unless you like grind for grind's sake.

我实在是太喜欢太喜欢地铁系列。
虽说小说没有看全，但三部游戏是一点没落下。比较感慨的就是在相同的世界观下阿尔乔姆的命运完全不一样啊！
游戏里他有信赖他的队友与一起合作的伙伴，小说里全然是怀疑与种种灾难。。。
三部的评测就一起写了。
2033。老游戏但是重置过，主玩剧情，难度不高，主页面音乐与好结局音乐很好听。危机感塑造的还行，人物形象到位，只是由于制作方面的种种原因我总觉得代入感没有想象的那么强，算是有点可惜（我本认为能做的更好的）。主打一个剧情共鸣，这点我甚是喜欢，需亲自游玩。游戏难度不高，轻微有点点恐怖元素（我是一点不怕，考虑到我有个玩l4d2都害怕的朋友，我认为对于恐怖的定义还是不怎么好说）。
The Last Light（最后的曙光）。大部分同上，感觉末日带来的震撼感要更强一点，并且主要以侧面刻画，算是我比较讨厌的人类战，因为不擅长潜行之类的，个人更偏向于喜欢打隧道垃圾（就是游戏里最常见的变异怪）。重点就是有着全系列最经典也是最好听的音乐The farewell，我真的是太太太太太喜欢这首歌了，如果感兴趣请务必欣赏！
Exodus（离去/离乡）一改前两作的线性流程，走的半开放式玩法，总体更加多样更耐玩，游戏流程时长也是肉眼可见的涨，美术制作等各方面大幅度优化（除了游戏本体，号称显卡杀手）。剧情一贯是在绝望中找寻希望，只不过这次由原地徘徊变为了踏上旅途，结识了许多地区的各种各样的人，也少不了危险（不详细叙述）。风景也很漂亮啊，支持高画质的可以闲的没事欣赏风景。另外由于时长的增加与大地区的变换，结束后给玩家带来的“戒断反应”也将更加强烈，也就是空虚感，类似思考人生，感慨万千。
三部游戏的通病就是，bug。恶性bug导致游戏无法过关的现象不在少数，小型不影响通关的地形或显示bug更是常见，这点必须要吐槽。
以上，综合来讲还是十分推荐的。

Updated 5/10/23: I was wrong originally, it is a decent game. The problems are still as noted below. I watched and read many walk-through items so I was finally able to figure out what to do, where to go, how to use things which took a lot of the frustration away. The mfrs could (should) have done a better job in the explanation department for the 'non-pro' gamer as it was a huge waste of time. The 2nd play through was more enjoyable, for sure (except for the cut scenes). There are some really good parts of the game....... but as a pretty casual (non-expert) gamer I found way too much stupid s#@t while playing, even in the Normal (easiest) difficulty. For instance, every time the game starts there is a long scene that can't be skipped. I personally  would not have remembered the game is based on a book (hopefully much better than the game) after the initial 25 times this scene plays out when I started the game. Now I start the game & walk away for a couple of minutes. There also seem to be way too many cut scenes. This seems strange because even with all the stoppages it was usually extremely hard to figure out what to do or where to go. At times this was especially frustrating because while you were attempting to determine who, what or where you get attacked. Quite often more enemies attack at once than you can shoot bullets to kill because reloading or switching weapons is too slow compared to the attack rates (IE: a Nosalis can be killed, usually with 1-2 shotgun head shots. The best shotgun holds 6 rounds & takes ~5 seconds to reload. The Nosalis may attack in an ongoing group of 10-15+). So when under an intense all sided attack, IF you actually land 6 head-shots (kills)  AND run away to reload you often get chased down & slaughtered like a dog. Or if you just switch weapons many need to be loaded & cocked before using. You also NEED to explore to have enough oxygen masks/filters yet as you do this you're using up what you had been looking for & being attacked relentlessly. I turned the game off many, many times just saying "this is too fricken dumb". IDK, to me the entire point of a game is to be somewhat enjoyable & exciting. The game did not do that for me. Maybe if I was a much better gamer I would like it as the game does have many favorable reviews.

Metro 2033 is a thrilling first-person shooter game that takes place in a post-apocalyptic Moscow. The game's narrative is based on the novel of the same name by Dmitry Glukhovsky. Metro 2033's gameplay is intense and challenging, and it offers a unique experience that is unlike any other first-person shooter game out there. The game's graphics are impressive, and the sound design immerses you into the game's world. I highly recommend Metro 2033 to anyone who is looking for a thrilling and immersive gaming experience.

[b]Graphics and story[/b] 9/10

[i]Metro 2033 Redux[/i] is a first person shooter game, although it contains a dose of survival. The story takes place in a post-apocalyptic world after a nuclear war. Beneath the ruins of Moscow, humans begin to live and survive in the subway stations. Radiation shaped the earth and sculpted new life forms, giving rise to new species that many of them will menace human existence. Soon the Exhibition Station will be under peril from Nosalis raids, as well as constantly facing mysterious enemies named the Dark ones. Hunter (Хантер), an elite Spartan ranger, decides to trek to Polis to report the situation to his superiors. However, with the presentiment of not returning, he consigns his dog tags to the young protagonist, Artyom (Артём), so that he can relay the message entrusted by his stepfather. This is how the journey to the Polis begins: going through dead places, tunnels and stations full of hostilities.

The narrative and script of the game is based on the novel of the same name written by Dmitry Glukhovsky. This game is an adaptation, in which we can partake in the circumstances of that world while we’re embodied in a silent character. The way of relating the story is ensured through chapters. Always Artyom reveals his insightful and intimate thoughts. We read his notes with a lyrical tone of his uncertainties, views and visions. While on the ride he becomes silent to interchange for an outside dialogue. Thus we can heed, eavesdrop or listen to them through an excellent narrative twist and role swapping that allows us to understand their context through opinions and anecdotes. The game tries to show us Artyom's intimate journey, made on purpose in a first person camera and with a brilliant script. It’s shrewd, insightful, ironic, cynical, and with a wide variety of tones and voices. Without a doubt, this is an excellent narrative game as if it were an interactive novel.

The game suggestions three varieties of sensations: fear of hostility, loneliness, and the feeling of home in subway stations. We can perceive all of this in the design of the levels, enemies and characters, as well as its artistic side. On the one hand we have an oppressive and dark atmosphere dominated by unknown hostiles. Where exploration becomes a deadly trap. The game manages to convey that feeling of constant danger. Outside, the dead city, is visible by dilapidated buildings with dying vegetation. The colour palette between blue, grey and white are appropriate with which they expose deterioration and loneliness. The tunnels remain in the dark and with its mystery. The diversity of mutants overwhelms the player. While in the stations offer the opposite: warmth, security, a breather or a pause before continuing on the path. Ruled by a colour palette with warm tones (orange, brown), but always showing deterioration and decadence. A good job has been done of having various scenarios that generate numerous tensions. From the liveliness of Polis to the loneliness in the library.

[b]Playability[/b] 9/10

At the beginning of the game, we can choose one of the two game modes: Spartan (action) and Survival. The first focuses on a common shooter, with plenty of resources and no need for stealth. In the second case or mode it’s the opposition to the first.

Stealth is something that’s well implemented, especially when playing the highest difficulties. So we must watch our movements and not step on broken glass, or stumble over traps (made of cans, booby-traps or spike traps). All of them make a noise that can trigger combat. Being crouched with the lights off, we attract less attention. Enemies are usually alert when running into a corpse, they see us walking/sprinting or when they’ve heard our footsteps. They won't stop looking for us. There are actions to shoot down or take down an enemy stealthily. For the first case there are throwing knives as we can also attach a silencer to some weapons. For the second case, being behind the enemy: we can eliminate him or leave him unconscious. Other actions that allow better stealth is the action of deactivating traps, turning off generators or shooting lights. Darkness and silence becomes the best condition to play stealth. It all depends on how we move and use our surroundings.

We get resources and weapons in two ways. Some we can buy, sell and trade at stalls and kiosks located in some stations, while others we find while exploring and looting different places (crates, strongboxes or bodies). The in-game currency is military-grade bullets. First aid kits and filters will be important in the game. We can also purchase and add attachments to weapons. An important note, only rifles can utilize both ammos, so it's important to verify the appearance of bullets contained in the magazine. The gas mask plays an important role during exploration. It requires constant filters: a clock will display duration of a filter. Once consumed it will emit a beep to replace it. If the mask breaks, we agonize suffocated. Although there will be bodies with masks with which we can change them. To avoid getting lost, we have a compass and a board where our objectives and indications are. We also have some other items that will help us on our expedition. The indicators are simple and that would be the basic elements of the game. It all depends on the player.

[b]Music and FX[/b] 10/10

The soundtrack was composed by Alexey Omelchuk and Geology Beloglazov. The music expresses Artyom's journey and also contains two main themes: the new civilization inside the metro and the ruins of Moscow (or the ruin of civilization). There are three musical styles within the game. The classical guitar that we hear in the intro and in the subway stations. The melody is warm, mellifluous and a bit nostalgic. Through the arpeggios and the warm chords it gives that homely but ominous feeling that resides or belong to the subway. The music of the guitar causes that need to be together with people and it does it well by wanting to stay in a station. That is one of the leitmotivs that reflects the new life in the subway. That and mixed with the noise of the crowd talking.

The other musical style present is electronic music. It does this in a few brief moments by implementing music similar to action movies. That accentuates the drama of the action. Although such music was not necessary. For that there is a counterweight, minimal dark ambient (with drone and down tempo noise) in some places that instigates fear, disturbing and horror. A good mix for those ambient sounds, consists of the presence of noise from environment (distant moans, mutants howl or growl, the wind rustles or some object falls from its place). The third style is condensed and concentrated on the leitmotiv for Artyom. They are symphonic pieces that accentuate the narrative drama of the game. Many of these are already found in the chords played on the guitar. The symphony shows us the cruel, dark and harsh atmosphere in which the world has been transformed. It uses many dark and gloomy tones. Always it highlights the strings. But it manages to provoke us that feeling of fear, commotion and astonish at every moment. As a plus, a good soundtrack will always have something of a miscellany — a little rock or a waltz, maybe?

[b]Duration[/b] 9/10

Redux is a better-quality version of the previous game of the same name. Apart from its various difficulties, the game contains a brilliant narrative. I played both versions. In the end, a seed of nostalgia grew in me when visiting each place in this game. The game is durable, the exploration is not demanding, and the high difficulty is not ruthless. The journey of this messenger is worth enjoying. Without a good script the game would be hollow, sterile and empty.

This game is a classic! I personally prefer the original version, but the Redux is still very good. If you've played the original, then the shooting and movement feel much smoother and it looks much better. Additionally, you can now pick up groups of items at a time instead of individually, which makes scavenging for items a little less time consuming. They also added additional notes which you can pick up, which function as audio logs, and these add additional information about the world and help flesh out Artyom as a character, although there are some spelling/grammatical errors in these files near the end of the game. The main problem that I have with the game overall is that you can't hold as much ammunition as the original. Some players may prefer this, but I kind of liked being able to horde ammo for the end-game. It felt like a reward for successfully using stealth throughout the early and mid-game. They also removed the ability to buy armor and the stealth suit from the Redux version, which is kind of disappointing because that choice allowed players to enhance their preferred playstyle. However, these gripes are pretty minor and should not be a reason why you don't play this game.  Definitely check this one out.
