classic

Metro 2033 Redux is a game with a fantastic setting and world, which creates an unmatched horror atmosphere in shooters. However, it is noticeable that the first game of the trilogy lacks a clear path, and its quality is rather mediocre when compared to its successors. The game tries hard to be like F.E.A.R., with its dark corridors, ghostly apparitions, and sudden visions in long hallways, forcing you to flee from something. The inspiration is clear, but what's cool is that you can approach many combat encounters stealthily, which takes some time, but it makes you feel pretty cool. The world is the actual star of the game, with its bombed-out Moscow, abandoned ruins on the surface, and shantytowns underground in the titular Metro, with the crowded survivors seemingly going about their daily lives. The game is atmospheric, even though some of the dialogue with Russian dialects feels a bit cringe. Some characters also behave illogically, like Sasha, a little boy whose uncle has just died. Without knowing me, he just goes off with a stranger and seems happy instead of mourning his uncle's death. When not sneaking, you shoot monsters and people with up to three weapons. The weapons are standard, but the game has a twist: ammunition is the currency to buy items and weapons. It's pretty cool, but managing ammo on normal difficulty is never really essential, but that changes on higher settings. You travel from station to station, from railway station to railway station, through dark atmospheric corridors, to reach the end. The ending is rushed, but bombastic, and it basically leads into the second part, which takes things up a notch. The journey through the Moscow Metro is still good, although it is just the beginning.

Edit : Turns out i completed the game in Survival mode, not Spartan mode ( Spartan is the easier mode) So my review is based off the Survival difficulty.

Based on Dmitry Glukhovsky's novel of the same name, Metro 2033 transports players to the post-apocalyptic world of the Moscow Metro, where humanity struggles to survive amid the horrors of the nuclear fallout. The game excels in crafting an incredible atmosphere and providing an engaging survival experience, immersing players in a chilling, captivating world that leaves a lasting impression.

The visual design in Metro 2033 is masterfully crafted, with dimly lit tunnels, eerie shadows, and desolate, frozen landscapes perfectly capturing the essence of a world ravaged by nuclear war. The attention to detail in the environments, from the makeshift settlements to the remnants of the past world, serves to draw players deeper into the world of Metro 2033.

The story follows Artyom, a young man born in the underground Metro, as he embarks on a perilous journey through the tunnels to save his home station from an impending threat. The narrative is rich and captivating, inviting players to become fully engrossed in the harsh reality of life in the Metro and the desperate struggle for survival. The game's themes of hope, sacrifice, and the nature of humanity resonate deeply with players.

The atmosphere in Metro 2033 is nothing short of exceptional. The pacing balances moments of tense, claustrophobic horror with brief glimpses of beauty in the devastated world above. The game's sound design further enhances this atmosphere, with the distant howls of mutated creatures and the creaking of the decaying Metro tunnels instilling a constant sense of unease.

Gameplay in Metro 2033 combines first-person shooter mechanics with survival horror elements, requiring players to manage resources such as ammunition and air filters carefully. The game also features stealth mechanics, allowing players to navigate through dangerous situations by either confronting enemies head-on or using the shadows to their advantage. These gameplay elements serve to create a sense of vulnerability and tension that keeps players engaged and connected to the game world.

In conclusion, Metro 2033 is a masterfully designed experience that effectively transports players to a hauntingly beautiful post-apocalyptic world. With its captivating narrative, stunning visuals, exceptional atmosphere, and engaging survival elements, Metro 2033 stands as a testament to the power of atmospheric, story-driven games. For fans of the genre, this title is a must-play experience that will leave a lasting impression long after the credits roll.

Dear reader,

This game is absolutely superb. It is disappointing to see that this game does not have the recognition it deserves (at least in the west), as this game ought to be on top FPS lists everywhere. This is my favorite game out of the current trilogy, but the others are still absolutely spectacular. I will now dive deeper into the specifics of what makes this game truly remarkable.

Firstly, the story needs to be dealt with. This game is based on a book series, Metro (2033, 2034, and 2035), which was written by the Russian author Dmitry Glukovsky. The books are excellent as well, I highly recommend that you pick them up as well (there are English, French, Polish, German, and Russian versions if I can recall correctly). This game (2033) is based more on the original source material than the later two entries in the series and the story mostly follows the plot of the first book, Metro 2033. The adaptation of the book into a video game was done fabulously and the story is gripping and emotional. The only way I feel the game doesn't quite get from the books is Artyom's naivety; he is a silent protagonist in the game and feels like an expert on everything while he is quite the noob in the books. In my opinion, this doesn't really detract from the game's story and emotion though, it is just different from the source material.

Gameplay is unique and feels specifically like its own thing. It is very recognizable movement, stealth, and shooting that feels like Metro. This game is not really a run and gun shooter like Titanfall or Quake, it is a slower paced stealth based shooter. Realism is a key part of the game here with Artyom needing to replace gas mask filters to stay alive and only a few bullets can take him out. There is even a mode that removes the HUD for full immersion. My only gripe is that movement feels loose and kind of clunky at times, but the game design is very compensating of the way movement works, so this really isn't that much of a problem. Overall, incredibly good.

The game is very technically impressive as well with stunning graphics for its age and very good performance. The game is very well optimized and runs at very high FPS (hits my 144hz cap) on max settings  on my RTX 3060 Laptop. Character animations and models are also very good for its time and even hold up well today. The main impressive feature of the game is the lighting which really gives a good creepy vibe to the game and enhances gameplay alongside the stealth features. This game is still very beautiful today. New AAA games should be held to this game's standards.

[h1] Metro 2033. [/h1]
I don't know anything about the book or the universe beyond what this game has shown me so far, but I have completed the campaign and am intrigued to find out what the sequels offer. Metro starts you off in a battle alongside the Rangers, fighting with strange beast creatures. At one point during the fight, you flashback to a time when you not a member of the fighting force. You are just an armed citizen of the Metro. You are Artyom, and you are tasked with saving the Metro, unknowingly at the time. As you proceed through the campaign, you will get to fight many strange enemies, human or not, with a increasingly more potent array of weapons and gear. All of which is scavenged. Eventually, you emerge from the tunnels to complete your mission, deal with a terrible walking mission, and then BOOM credits roll.
Pretty good.

[h1] Pros [/h1]
+The atmosphere is STUNNING.
+Visual style is very good, even for a game that is over 10 years old at this point.
+If bought recently, runs flawlessly. No frame hiccups, no audio issues, no crashing.
+Audio engine really supports all of the ambiance and effects. This really has you feeling claustrophobic in the tunnels, and very different in the chasms and larger areas.
+Weapons are great. Every weapons has a unique usage style, and also support attachments to tweak each gun. Big shotgun? Get a hip fire laser. Big revolver? Get a scope and suppressor on that bad boy. The style of the weapons fits the theme, and are pretty sweet to look at as well. the animations for all the guns are very well done as well.
+Introduction to the universe was a slow burn, but also doesn't leave me wondering what all of this was about. READ THE NOTES YOU FIND and the game becomes much more than just a tense tunnel shooter.
+Never feeling lost after returning to this game in the back log. I completed the game in roughly 8 hours over the course of several years of ownership, and at the beginning of each session I remembered the events before. Not too many games can pull off having so many good clinch moments to jump in and out of a game with, so this is a MAJOR plus!
+Works offline.

[h1] Cons [/h1]
-The game is a tunnel, both in theme and game play. 1 and done, unless you want to try certain parts in different ways. The game is linear. I completed the campaign in 8 hours (spread across several years of ownership) and honestly, I don't think I'll ever do another run again.
-Playing without the use of headphones is DETRIMENTAL to the experience. Most games have a pretty decent stereo mixing setup for tv/speaker users, but this game just doesn't do well in that regard. Make sure to play this one with some headphones.
-The walking mission at the end. What was the point of turning that into game play? It could have been a trippy cut scene with a few QTEs sprinkled in. As a hater of QTEs, I think that they would have been a better alternative to what that part offered.

metro 2033 redux is a FPS survival horror game developed by 4A games and published by deep silver. this is a remaster of metro 2033, a game that came out in march 2010 based on dmitry glukhovsky's novel of the same name. metro 2033 was the debut title for 4A games, whose founders had experience working on the s.t.a.l.k.e.r. games before founding the studio. metro 2033 was originally published by THQ, but deep silver acquired the publishing rights from them before releasing the sequel, metro last light in 2013. in august of 2014, both games were remastered for PC, PS4, & xbox one. it was also later released on the nintendo switch in 2020.

metro 2033 redux is a classic first person shooter with a linear level layout. it's predominantly set in the tunnels of the moscow metro so it makes sense narratively at least. the game does feature survival horror elements so you want to preserve ammunition and have a constant need to scavenge for supplies on dead bodies and throughout the level. ammunition also acts as currency, and it can be traded for weapons and upgrades. the atmosphere and immersion you get as a result is considered one of the game's highlights, as it puts you right into the amazing dark post-apocalyptic setting. the AI definitely needs some work as it is entirely too easy on every difficulty and the best way to play the game is to start ion the highest difficulty with survival/hardcore mode turned on. 

i definitely recommend waiting for a sale for this game as you can get it for $3.99 on it's own, or in the metro saga bundle, you can get this game, last light redux, and metro exodus for around $15. those are great prices for a couple almost-decade-old remasters, PLUS you get the third game in the saga and it's season pass.

Metro 2033 Redux is a fantastic game that will impress anyone who loves post-apocalyptic survival games. The game features stunning graphics and an immersively realistic world full of danger and adventure.

One of the outstanding features of Metro 2033 Redux is its addictive gameplay. The game emphasises exploration, gathering supplies and crafting items to help you survive in the harsh world of the Moscow underground. The game's combat mechanics are also fantastic, offering a wide range of weapons and equipment that can be customised and upgraded to suit your play style. From stealth infiltration to all-out war, Metro 2033 Redux gives you complete control over how you approach each encounter.

Overall, Metro 2033 Redux is a must-have for anyone who loves atmospheric survival games with great storytelling and intense action. Whether you're a fan of the post-apocalyptic genre or just looking for a unique gaming experience, Metro 2033 Redux is definitely worth checking out.

TL;DR
Absolute garbage. Don't waste your time on this dumpsterfire.

-Old, clunky and frustrating mechanics.
-Unsatisfying combat. Absolutely horrible and clunky.

Metro 2033 is an amazing game that delivers an immersive and intense post-apocalyptic experience. Developed by 4A Games, the game is based on the novel of the same name by Dmitry Glukhovsky.

Set in the ruins of Moscow after a devastating nuclear war, Metro 2033 follows the story of Artyom, a young man who must fight for survival in the harsh and dangerous underground metro tunnels. The game features a compelling narrative, with well-developed characters and a deep lore that draws you into the world.

The graphics of the game are stunning, with detailed environments that evoke a sense of dread and despair. The lighting and sound design are also top-notch, creating a tense and atmospheric atmosphere throughout the game.

One of the most impressive aspects of Metro 2033 is its unique gameplay mechanics. The game features a combination of first-person shooter and survival horror elements, with a heavy emphasis on stealth and resource management. The player must scavenge for supplies, craft weapons and ammunition, and carefully navigate the dangerous tunnels filled with hostile creatures and enemy factions.

Overall, Metro 2033 is an amazing game that manages to deliver a truly immersive and engaging experience. Its combination of storytelling, graphics, and gameplay make it one of the best post-apocalyptic games ever made. If you're a fan of first-person shooters, survival horror games, or just great storytelling, then Metro 2033 is a must-play.

Metro Exodus Redux is a fantastic game that perfectly balances survival, exploration, and storytelling. The game takes place in a post-apocalyptic world where players must navigate a dangerous and harsh environment while also battling mutants and other enemies. The game's visuals are stunning, and the attention to detail in the game's world-building is impressive. The game's storyline is engaging, and the characters are well-developed, making players care about their fates. The game's audio design is also top-notch, immersing players in the game's world and creating an intense atmosphere.

In terms of gameplay, Metro Exodus Redux offers a variety of options for players, allowing them to customize their experience to their liking. Players can choose to play stealthily, avoiding enemies whenever possible, or take a more aggressive approach and engage in combat. The game's weapon customization system allows players to modify their weapons to suit their playstyle, and the game's crafting system lets players create useful items and tools to help them survive in the game's dangerous world. Overall, Metro Exodus Redux is an excellent game that is sure to please fans of the series and newcomers alike.

Firstly, I’d like to start with the short end of my review and then elaborate on my review and then present a score.

[b]Pros:[/b]

+ [i]Good remastered graphics[/i]
+  [i]Improved mechanics[/i]
+ [i]Decent story[/i]
+ [i]Likable characters for the most part[/i]
+ [i]Good gunplay[/i]
+ [i]Decent stealth mechanics[/i]

[b]Cons:[/b]

- [i]Gamebreaking bugs remain even long after the game was released[/i]
- [i]Metro 2033 having multiple endings was completely pointless[/i]
- [i]The ally AI was pretty much useless[/i]


A forewarning before I elaborate further, there will be some spoilers in this review and I will note such spoilers as such by blacking them out in my review. View these spoilers at your own risk, as that is your choice if you ruin the game’s story for yourself. You have been warned.

Pros – Elaborations:

[b]Good remastered graphics[/b]

I like that this game was cleaned up and polished for newer hardware and made to look better than it had before. I very much liked how the game looked.

[b]Improved mechanics[/b]

Props on 4A games for improving the mechanics of the old game and adding quality of life features from Exodus such as giving the ability to wipe the gas mask visor off, for example. 

[b]Decent story[/b]

I liked how the story of Artyom thrust a young, 20 year old man out into the brutal world of the Metro, only to find out that he was the one to be lucky enough to understand the words of [spoiler]The Dark Ones, where they desperately try to communicate with him and tell him who they really are[/spoiler].


[b]Likable characters for the most part[/b]

I enjoyed the characters Artyom is introduced to in his journey such as Khan, Bourbon, along with his [spoiler]Ranger brothers[/spoiler] and how they interacted with him.

Cons – Elaborations:

[b]Game-breaking bugs remain even long after the game was released[/b]

This is especially notable with the Tihar, a semi-automatic multi-stroke air gun that you get which ends up being a pretty good silent weapon to easily and stealthily take out enemies. The bug started occurring with me later in the game where [spoiler]the Nazis were on the surface of the Metro in a outpost[/spoiler]. This game-breaking bug occurs when you over-pressurize the Tihar, causing functions such as lowering and raising your [spoiler]Night Vision Goggles[/spoiler] as well as making it impossible to aim down the sights of any weapon. I learned about this bug later on and ended up ditching the Tihar as a result. This bug still remains in Metro 2033 Redux as far as I am aware.

[b]Metro 2033 having multiple endings was completely pointless[/b] 

Having more than one ending was pointless and putting stock into one of them [spoiler](The ‘Enlightened’ Ending)[/spoiler] was a complete and utter waste of time. If you want to be less disappointed in the ending of this game, just go for the other ending [spoiler](The Canon Ending, known as the ‘Ranger Ending)[/spoiler]. While I’m not at all against [spoiler]dark, depressing endings that are full of dread and tragedy,[/spoiler] I take issue with it when the following game after doesn’t acknowledge the other ending in any way. I’m not saying it has to follow through in the next game or anything, but tie it off somehow to fit it in the ending the developers clearly wanted you to play and get. 

[b]The ally AI was pretty much useless[/b]

I get that in most shooters that you are supposed to be the one killing the enemies and living out a power fantasy. But when it seems as if your allies are as blind as bats, as deaf as Beethoven, and have guns loaded with .22 caliber rounds to kill mutants it makes them pretty much a liability and completely useless.

Anyway, that’s my review and to some extent, a bit of vent about a game I liked. I don’t suggest this game unless you get just this game or the bundle it’s in on deep discount.

I completely forgot how good/bad this game was, but apparently I left a bad review on the original so I thought "hmm maybe I was harsh on this game in the past" but nope as it turns out this game is still as shit as I remembered it.
Stealth is still broken, wonky, and just plain dumb as hell (also not fun). Survival is a worthless difficulty option; all it does is make everything more cumbersome and you'll likely be playing on Ranger which limits you to two weapons so the "less pickups" shit hardly matters at all. Speaking of Ranger, what absolute moron thought to NOT include a simple tutorial for the controls at the beginning, especially since half of the controls are the most dumb shit ever (M for the fucking lighter?).
There's still tons of annoying bugs/crashes that force you to reload chapters, still a bunch of goofy sound effects that ruin the atmosphere (a big deal in this game since the atmosphere is the ONLY good part), annoying gimmick sections, some with bad controls, and you STILL have to manually fix the god awful FOV and even when you do you can still tell it's fucked up. Talk about a massive "redux".
Just an all-around outdated mess that's all surface-level coolness but lacks any substance.

Playing this game nearly a decade after it was originally released and it holds up very well in atmosphere, story and gameplay we see today.  As a fan of Fallout, Last of Us, sneaking (Metal Gear Solid, hello!) and general survival games, this was an absolute treat - I'm sorry I didn't play it earlier and kept on passing it over.

Oftentimes it was difficult to know where to go navigation wise, which lead to wasting time and filters, but I guess that only lends itself to the tension of trying to balance supplies, acting quickly yet cautiously, and avoiding or, depending on one's playstyle, engaging enemies.  I enjoyed being able to choose my style of knocking out human enemies, and how curiosity was rewarded well in this game (though often a sheer necessity when looking for supplies).  Sometimes instructions were unclear for certain missions - on one I was left fighting waves of enemies only to discover I had to actually go out into the fray and find supplies to stop the attacks, but that was only ascertained after I had completely run out of bullets trying to defend an outpost and died several times.

I hate to say it but the librarians scared the living daylights out of me more than anything else and I ended up doing a speedrun through that level (hah!).  If I never run into one again, I'll be immensely happy.

As a casual gamer, rate this a very solid A-.  Some minor quibbles, but nothing that would ultimately ruin this incredibly immersive experience.

Every now and then I go back through my library of games and I find hidden gems that I bought, but never played. This is one of those games that really pulled me in from the very first moment of gameplay. Its an older game, but so much love and care went into making this story very believable. And its not just the moment to moment shootouts that feel really good, but its the NPCs that feel alive when you are walking around a safe-zone. People are talking, eating, drinking, working. And you get the sense that when you leave a location and continue your journey, those same people you saw are continuing their lives also. This game also offers some of the most intense moments on harder difficulty to survive the mutated monsters and the bandits that control parts of the Metro. I cant wait to finish the game and move onto the next one.

"Metro 2033 Redux" is a captivating and immersive game that takes place in a post-apocalyptic world where the remnants of humanity struggle to survive in the ruins of a once-great city. The game is a remastered version of the original "Metro 2033," with improved graphics and enhanced gameplay mechanics.

One of the standout features of "Metro 2033 Redux" is its stunning visuals and attention to detail. The game's environments are beautifully rendered, with dark and claustrophobic tunnels, dilapidated buildings, and hauntingly beautiful outdoor areas. The game's character models and animations are also incredibly lifelike, adding to the overall sense of realism.

Another aspect of the game that sets it apart is its gripping storytelling and atmosphere. The game's narrative is engaging and well-written, drawing players into a world of danger and uncertainty. The game's sound design is also excellent, with a haunting soundtrack and atmospheric sound effects that add to the sense of tension and dread.

However, what really makes "Metro 2033 Redux" special is its gameplay mechanics. The game is a first-person shooter with survival horror elements, where players must scavenge for resources and fight off mutants and other dangers lurking in the shadows. The game's combat system is excellent, with a variety of weapons and tactics to choose from, and the stealth mechanics are also well-implemented.

Overall, "Metro 2033 Redux" is an exceptional game that is sure to provide countless hours of entertainment. With stunning visuals, engaging gameplay mechanics, and a gripping atmosphere, it is a must-play for anyone who loves first-person shooters, survival horror, or post-apocalyptic settings.

I recently got Metro Exodus on the steam spring sale, so I'm going through and replaying the first two games before launching into Exodus. 2033 holds up very strong I'd say. The graphics still look as good as I remember, the weapons still feel as good as I remember, and I still have just as much fun romping around through the metro tunnels. There are a few sections where it's easy to get lost, but you have a compass and a lighter to guide you. The story isn't anything to write home about, but I don't think it really needs to be. Overall I still had fun with this game even though none of the plot twists were surprising anymore. The only section that I really needed outside help on was the library and that's because I didn't listen to one of the NCPS who specifically tells you to listen to what he has to say.

This game, being the first in the series, is certainly a must play. I've been a fan of this series since the very beginning (pre-redux release) and I've yet to lose my love of this game, and its sequels.

This version makes a few tweaks to the original, but the overall experience is the same. This last time I played it felt a little more like a shooter than adventure/survival. There were plenty of ammo and health packs (in a world that supposedly struggling to survive so much that ammo is literally the new currency), and I was able to run and gun a little more than I had wanted to. That was probably based on the settings and difficulty I set it at, however. Despite that, this game still feels very unique. You have to make sure your flashlight and night vision goggles are fully charged, you can use a lighter for a slight bit of light as well as burning spiderwebs, and check your objectives in real time ton your clipboard.

A lot of people MIGHT compare this  to the Fallout series, and say that it's just a "linear, non open world version" of those games, and while I can see where they're coming from, I feel this is nowhere near the case. Yeah, they're both set in a post nuclear apocalypse setting, the tones and game play aren't supposed to resemble each other. This game is cramped and claustrophobic on purpose, as it's all set within the confines of the subway tunnels. You're supposed to feel trapped and confined in this game, and the story has far less humor than the Fallout games. 

My only complaint with this versions is I found a few texture glitches that I hadn't seen in the original (layers of textures not playing nice and clipping and tearing through each other whenever I would move to look at things, as well as a couple spelling errors within the journals), but they weren't anything that I felt destroyed my experience with this one.

Definitely try this one out if you haven't played these games yet. It's certainly one of my favorites. Even if you've played Last Light or Exodus first, if you haven't played Metro 2033, it's well worth a play through.

Absolutely holds up! The story is pretty standard for the genre, just your average post-apocalyptic plot where the main character has to go from point A to point B, however the gameplay speaks for itself. I played on Survival and I don't regret it, it's challenging, but fair. It feels rewarding when you actually explore some of the linear environments and find better supplies. You also get this very satisfying feeling whenever you swap out one of your ammo-less guns with ones that do have plenty of ammo, just in time before you get ate up by those monsters or fascists bullets. It's heavily reminiscent of the STALKER games, (which it's most likely inspired by), but with prettier visuals and guns that actually hit something most of the time. The best parts of the game is whenever you fight the human enemies, they do not f*ck around and have a lot of armor, which makes it euphoric whenever you mow them all down with whatever arsenal you have in stock. Metro 2033 Redux has it's fair share of bugs though, pretty much the game's only blunder. I'm not just talking about goofy ragdoll effects, I'm talking about falling through the world sometimes and the game refusing to move ahead, forcing me to reload the closest checkpoint. Not too many glitches, but these took me out of the game and can be spotted easily. It's a great game though, worth the experience and price.

It's been a long time since I've played a FPS campaign that was carried by the strength of its world and its story.  Where other FPS relish in how much they can give the player, new weapons, abilities, skill trees, Metro excels through what it manages to take away.  Fewer weapons, limited upgrades, limited currency (that you can use as ammo in a pinch), few light sources, and linear level-design allow Metro to expertly curate your experience so that you get the most out of the world of the metro, and the mysteries unfolding within it.

A complaint that I've seen a lot of people have with this game is that it's linear, and while that is understandable, I think that the game is stronger for its focused execution.  It didn't feel linear while I played it for the first time.  There is a genuine thrill to feeling your way around in the dark, trying to find any to keep pushing forward to accomplish your seemingly impossible journey.  Every scripted moment felt genuinely surprising and the danger felt very real.  The game is still difficult, and it still rewards deviating off the beaten path, if only slightly.  The linear nature of the game also serves the story incredibly well, as it just continues to build momentum.  By the end, you are locked in.

Metro 2033 Redux is... interesting in its way. Playing through both Survivor and Spartan Modes of the game, I could only gather a mixed bag of a game review. However, before I go into details, I'll put a disclaimer and admit that I never played the original game, nor did I interact with the franchise prior, so this is purely a standalone game review, not comparison to the original product review.

Metro 2033 takes place in Moscow, twenty years after World War III devastates the capital of Russia, and, subsequently, the world. Most of the surface has become uninhabitable, courtesy of nuclear fallout and mutated creatures taking over, forcing the survivors to descend into the Moscow Metropolitan to outlast and overcome the extinction threat. The game narrates the story of Artyom, the inhabitant of 'Exhibition' subway station, whose survival routine is interrupted by his family's friend, Hunter, gone missing after a mutant raid on the station. True to his word, the protagonist goes out of his way to find out the truth behind the incident, going deep into the tunnels of the Metro.

The gameplay is similar to FPS's of its time, namely Call of Duty: Modern Warfare or Far Cry. The weapon arsenal, although isn't as big, varies a lot, ranging from makeshift weapons to WWIII-era assault rifles, which can be customized with laser dots, holographic sights and suppressors. On topic of in-game economy, the most prominent feature is the currency: as the world economy was blasted away with a number of nuclear strikes, the Metro citizens adapted ammunition as means to trade with each other. On paper, this sounds like a great game feature, making you choose between conserving gun ammo to buy other tools of survival, such as med-kits or throwing knives. In practice, however, the 'ammo currency' is only applied to High-End Ammunition, which can only be used in pair with certain weapons you may not get access to until late game, but by this time you've already gotten every gun that flat-out excels High-End Ammo demanding weapons. The makeshift ammo, which you're going to use for the majority of the game, is easy to come by and can be bought for a relatively cheap price from vendors.

The story and lore were interesting to dive into at first, but eventually got dull and sometimes lacking, with some prominent plot holes being left behind. The whole concept of The Dark Ones and them being portrayed as the primary antagonists, who, in reality, only appeared in Artyom's daydreams, which by themselves were merely a plot device to keep you on feet with the supernatural theme of the apocalypse. Khan was a missed opportunity for a main character, only appearing twice in the entire game and only for a short period of time. Some of the supporting characters were exaggerated in terms of altruism and comradeship, easily sacrificing themselves with a grenade in their arm after being overwhelmed by the enemies; one or two sequences like that could be fine for the overall atmosphere, but this theme continued throughout the entire game, with at least three characters ultimately throwing themselves into a horde of enemies to let the protagonist progress through the story.

The reason why I woudn't recommend buying Metro 2033 Redux at full price is concealed within its main glaring flaw, that being the target audience. From what I could tell, the game is clearly tailored for the two categories of people: die-hard STALKER fans and Russian/East European players, and that is not an exaggeration by any means. Alas, I did not fall under either of these categories, which I think is the main reason why the game didn't appeal to me. This is by no means an offense to the aforementioned people, I'd say this is a disclaimer for the West European and North American players out there like myself.

Ultimately, I found Metro 2033 an outdated and underwhelming product, given its gameplay and length, so I'd only recommend it to the people metioned above or someone looking for an eerie gameplay experience. Even for a sticker price of ~$15 CND, I'd advise to be better safe and sorry and grab it on sale if you don't want to lose much.

A number of issues with the game, most of which I was overlooking until the last one was too much.

First, most of the game is walking behind a guide NPC while they constantly stop, tell you to wait, while something "spooky" happens.  This is ok once in a while, but it gets old and just pads out the game's playtime without any real gameplay.

Second, too many fights with the dog/rat/mole monsters where everything just stops while you fight a few waves of them.  This gets old really fast, and the game does it over and over again.

Third, forced first-person platforming with controls and ground collision boxes that are not made for this.  Lots of deaths to falling after making a best-effort jump.  Also an area where you need to drop down to the lowest level, but the game will kill you even dropping a few meters, unless you find the exact spot where they wanted you to drop down.

Finally, I hit a point in the Front Line chapter where the game auto-saved me right in front of an enemy vehicle coming down a tunnel.  No option to load a previous save, and I was pretty much forced to restart the whole mission or reload over and over until I got extremely lucky and executed everything just right to get out of the situation.  It was like when you accidentally quicksave right before you die, except the game did it for me of no fault of my own.

The game really shines when it lets you go in an area by yourself without any NPC guide, but these segments are few and far between, and I feel like it would be maybe 2 hours long if it only included these segments.  The rest is a waste of time.

Great environment design, compact shooting gameplay with some elements of RPG and immersive atmosphere with many artistic and creative dream-like sequences. Some very weird but cool shooter mechanics like charging flashlight or it will run out of battery, bump pressure into flamethrower to keep firing, replace filler for gas mask (and wipe water of it to get a better view) and throwing knife for stealth kill. Metro is well-loved FPS darling for small details like this, despite the horrible "Russian accent English". You could play "survival mode" to fully immerse yourself into the story or just gun blazing like Hollywood action movie. The story is ok, entertaining but don't expect anything deep like Bioshock. I encounter some small bugs that could be fixed by reloading checkpoints or chapters, nothing game-breaking. Overall a well-earned shooter classic.

This is supposed to be the Redux version, yet it is full of bugs. In some places, enemy soldiers will straight up ignore you even if you bump into them. They will stand still like statues. In some places, your character will get stuck and require a reload. At some points, a mission trigger will not be triggered so you will have to play the mission again. 

In other words, if you are not good at Google-fu to find a solution to these bugs, I am almost sure you will abandon this game midway. Oh yeah, this game has a checkpoint system - it does not allow you to save.

Short answer - good game. I'd buy it again.

Very fun.  I played the original on a pc that could barely run the game at 25-30fps and had a blast and I played this entirely on the Steam Deck and had fun again.

Techinical infomation about the Steam Deck, if you care. I ran the game at high/medium settings just with the buggy physics and motion blur off. The game ran 60 through out, though cinematic cut scenes are 30 (the beginning and ending cutscenes) and there are some audio hiccups in cutscenes. The game had a few consistent bug, mostly that certain combinations of soundFXs cause the audio to crack for a second, but a bit loud. The game isn't bugfree by any means and I fell through the floor at the end of a level (level still completed), Audio glitches, Hardlocked twice and crashed once in 7 hours of playing (thankfully the game auto saves so basically no progress was lost). The most annoying glitch was that after I got the night vision goggles I entered a cutscene with them on and since most cutscenes are in engine I had the night vision filter over the enter cutscene. That alone wouldn't realy be an issue but for the next like 5 cutscenes My guy quick threw the goggles on even though I didn't have them on and they would play in night vision. It also had me do a rail gunning section in night vision and also I had to go through two hubs with night vision on with no way to take it off (The battery actually died once in a town and I was glad because I finally had normal vision). But it never really was a huge issue, just a weird annoyance and it stopped before the last stretch of the game.

What a blast of a dystopian game. The Metro world is so interesting and engaging, as an American getting to experience a game set in post-apocalyptic Russia is a very foreign and yet familiar experience. I love linear story and first person shooter games so this game was a natural buy and I am happy to say it was worth it. 2033's gameplay is short but sweet but what is mainly standout is the story and atmosphere, 2033 has a very well-developed world with realistic feeling characters and unique creatures (which I am sure is partially due to Dmitry Glukhovsky's novels). My only complaint is that v-sync is capped at 60fps so I left it off and had a lot of screen tearing in my playthrough (didn't think to enable v-sync by control panel which probably would have fixed this issue) but that is a relatively minor complaint considering the quality of this game. Overall I highly recommend this game if you are looking for a fun single player game to sink roughly 10 hours into.

Metro 2033 Redux - це дуже захоплююча гра, яка змушує гравця відчувати напруження та відчай, які владні в постапокаліптичному світі. Гра базується на романі Дмитра Глуховського "Метро 2033" і переносить гравця в майбутнє, де людство виживає в мережі тунелів московського метро після ядерної війни.

Гра має дуже глибоку та емоційну історію з вражаючими персонажами, які відтворені в деталях. Гравець відчуває багато емоцій, що змушують його зосередитися на грі і відчувати все, що відбувається в грі.

Один з найбільших плюсів гри - це атмосфера. Гра відтворює дуже відчутне враження постапокаліптичного світу, з його пустелі та небезпеками. Визначними особливостями є хороша візуальна графіка та звукове супроводження, які створюють неперевершену атмосферу.

Загалом, Metro 2033 Redux - це дуже захоплююча гра, яка буде цікава для любителів постапокаліптичних ігор та фантастики. Я б рекомендував цю гру всім, хто хоче насолодитися незабутнім досвідом гри в захоплюючому світі.

ENG:
Metro 2033 Redux is a very addictive game that makes the player feel the tension and desperation that reigns in the post-apocalyptic world. The game is based on the novel "Metro 2033" by Dmitry Glukhovsky and takes the player to the future, where humanity survives in the network of tunnels of the Moscow Metro after a nuclear war.

The game has a very deep and emotional story with impressive characters that are reproduced in detail. The player feels many emotions that make him focus on the game and feel everything that is happening in the game.

One of the biggest pluses of the game is the atmosphere. The game reproduces a very tangible impression of a post-apocalyptic world, with its desert and dangers. Distinctive features are good visual graphics and soundtrack, which create an unparalleled atmosphere.

In general, Metro 2033 Redux is a very exciting game that will be interesting for fans of post-apocalyptic games and fantasy. I would recommend this game to anyone who wants to enjoy an unforgettable gaming experience in an exciting world.

I ended up crashing twice across my two playthroughs. once at the end of my first playthrough and once more within the Dead City during my second. Other than that, I had a great time playing with no issues at all.

NOTE: Those who are afraid of spiders or may have arachnophobia should hold off buying. there are big spider-like creatures in the game. Do your own research to see if its something you can handle.

I think everyone should play this game, but as always it's best to wait for a discount before buying if you can wait.

As an avid fan of post-apocalyptic games, I have to say that Metro 2033 Redux has quickly become one of my favorites. This game manages to perfectly capture the sense of tension and dread that comes with surviving in a world ravaged by nuclear war.

The graphics and overall visual design of the game are truly stunning. The game world feels fully realized and immersive, with a level of detail that really brings the world to life. The sound design is also top-notch, with an excellent soundtrack and atmospheric sound effects that help to set the mood.

The game play is incredibly engaging, with a great mix of stealth, combat, and exploration. The mechanics are well-designed and easy to pick up, but still provide a satisfying challenge. The game also has a great story, with well-developed characters and an intriguing plot that kept me hooked from start to finish.

Overall, Metro 2033 Redux is an outstanding game that is definitely worth playing. The attention to detail, excellent visuals, engaging game play, and gripping story make it an unforgettable experience. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys post-apocalyptic settings, first-person shooters, or just great games in general.

A couple of things to know before buying and how to fix/access them.

1. Game not launching
The game might not launch for you. Its fixable if that's the case. There is a link to download a C++ redistributable to fix that ( https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=30679 ). The game should launch after it's run and shouldn't have any more issues related to launches. You might still experience some minor lag/stuttering but they are rare and don't happen in the same areas once reloaded. I haven't experienced any crashes so far.

2. Spiderwebs and your lighter
You might notice that going through spider webs will slow down your movement. You can destroy the webs by equipping your lighter (press M). It also will have the added bonus of getting rid of the spiders if you're an arachnophobe. 

3. Battery and charge
You won't really notice at first, but as time goes on your trusty flashlight will go from bright to dog-shit rather quickly. You have a recharger with you that the games doesn't tell you about for some reason. It becomes especially useful after you gain access to some night-vision goggles. (Press and hold F to equip the recharger and right click repeatedly to recharge your batteries).

4. Weapon selection and throwables
You won't really find out if you don't look at your keyboard/controller binds in the menu, but you can have a more detailed view on weapon and equipment loadouts than just the number keys at the top of your keyboard. It shows you what weapons you have, all the ammo you have (for weapons you do or don't have including military-grade ammo), how much time you have left on your filters, and your throwables (press/maybe hold onto tab). You can select your throwables in the bottom left of that menu and you can then throw them in combat (press C). 

5. Military-Grade ammo and regular ammo
You have access to two different types of ammo depending on your currently equipped weapon. They are military-grade ammo and regular ammo. The regular ammo is the one you pick up the most and is what you would preferably use through most of the game. Military-Grade ammo is the currency of the game (used to buy weapons and their attachments, regular ammo, throwables, filters, and health kits), however it can be used in a pinch to defend yourself (Hold R to switch between ammo types). As far as I know, military-grade ammo is only able to be used in modern weaponry, not in the makeshift weapons or in pistols. Do keep in mind that it is only advisable to use military-grade ammo in emergencies as depleting it will mean that you won't have any to purchase upgrades or resupply when the opportunity presents itself. 

And that's everything that comes to mind as of right now. This is a solid game with some small hiccups, but they shouldn't discourage you from getting it. They are fixable or can be accessed with the right knowledge. I will update this review as things come to my attention as I'm still a ways into the game. The comments are open so leave any suggestions you think should be added down below.

Here are some reasons to play Metro 2033 Redux:

Post-apocalyptic mayhem: Who doesn't love a good end-of-the-world scenario? With Metro 2033 Redux, you get to experience the thrill of surviving in a world that has been utterly destroyed by nuclear war. Plus, it's a great way to prepare for the inevitable zombie apocalypse.

Immersive atmosphere: The game's stunning graphics and eerie sounds will transport you to a post-apocalyptic Moscow that's teeming with danger and suspense. It's so immersive, you'll feel like you're really there, dodging mutants and scavenging for supplies.

Engaging storyline: Metro 2033 Redux has a gripping storyline that will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. You play as Artyom, a survivor who must journey through the underground Metro tunnels to save his people from a new threat. It's like a Russian version of The Walking Dead, but with more guns.

Challenging gameplay: The game's challenging mechanics will keep you on your toes, whether you're sneaking past mutants or engaging in intense firefights with enemy soldiers. It's a game that rewards strategy and quick reflexes, so get ready to think fast and shoot even faster.

Multiple endings: Your choices in the game affect the outcome of the story, so there's plenty of replayability. With multiple endings to discover, you'll want to go back and try different approaches to see how the story plays out.

Gas mask: Let's be honest, the real reason to play Metro 2033 Redux is so you can feel like a total badass wearing a gas mask. It's like being a superhero, but with radiation poisoning. Plus, it's a great way to keep the coronavirus at bay.

Metro is a universe created by Dmitri Gloukhovski and most like other contomporary works of fiction written by individuals from the other side of the world (like The Witcher), this universe has been adapted as a videogame series and quite amazingly so, I might add.

In this very atmospheric FPS, you take on the role of Arteum (or Artyom, whatever you fancy), who was born and raised in an underground station. Thing is, after the nuclear bombs fell, the surface world has become uninhabitable... and to discover the waste that lies upstairs, you'd have to wear anti-radiation gear and arm yourself to the teeth to fight off all the mutated hordes of hungry rabbits, sheep and fliers that live and strive in the radiation. Humanity, living now in Metro Stations, must make do with whatever food supplies they have down there before they send their "rangers" up there for supply runs. It's a genious idea and a very probable apocalyptic scenario. Arteum will find himself, in no time, entangled in a plot bigger than all of the Metro network.

The game does absolutly great when it comes to the weapon play... As a typical shooter, you're allowed to take aim and enjoy headshots and whatnot... but unlike other typical shooters, the mutated specimens strewn around the Metro and the surface allow for some very costly jumpscares... One frightening case of "poop my pants" was the Librarian; a mutated humanoid blob of... irradiated matter... who stalks you and strikes at the most opportune of moments.

The only let down with this game was the Russian English accent... NOOOO! I'm gonna get the biggest backlash because of this, but it's true! You might have a much better experience with Metro games if you just suffer through the Russian English with subtitles, than to actually play it with the atrocious Russian English accent... Imagine The Witcher with a Polish English accent, wouldn't that have been annoying as all hell? Anyways, the game is awesome... the accent makes it not so immersive, but it's still very original. [b] 9/10 [/b] FPS that was way ahead of its time.

Metro 2033 is a masterpiece of a game, blending atmospheric storytelling with intense survival horror gameplay. Set in a post-apocalyptic world, the game's haunting world and intriguing story create an immersive and captivating experience.

The game's attention to detail is also impressive, with a deep and intricate world that is both realistic and terrifying. The game's use of scarce resources and brutal combat create a sense of tension and urgency that keeps you on the edge of your seat throughout.

Overall, Metro 2033 is a must-play for fans of survival horror and immersive storytelling, with its haunting atmosphere and intense gameplay making for a truly unforgettable experience.

The Metro series is both my favorite post-apocalyptic and favorite FPS series, and this game is a damn good reason why. A bleak environment combined with an enriching story makes this a game that'll hook you for hours, so if you haven't already, PLAY. IT. You'll love it, especially if you're a fan of the aforementioned genres.

Imagine you wake up one day to visit the local park with your mom. Everything is going perfectly, you buy some ice cream, you enjoy yourself, and then the world around you burns. Missiles crash into the ground and explode, and later nukes, you hastily retreat into the underground city metro. Although this scenario is quite extreme it is what happened to the people of Moscow in the Metro 2033 world by Dmitry Glukhovsky, and what you as the player wake up to after a few years living in the metro. Metro 2033 is a great game, here's why. (and you should play it!)
	Metro 2033 takes place in the near future after a global nuclear conflict has left, at least Moscow, totally destroyed and in a nuclear winter. You play as someone named Artyom and start his adventure through the tunnels of the Metro and onto the surface of the destroyed world. With 12.8 almost 13 hours in Metro 2033 and having finished the entire series after many more hours, I can say that it is more than good. Metro 2033 has many amazing aspects so we will go one section at a time discussing them.

Story ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐
	The Metro 2033 story is amazing; due to the fact that it's based on a book series of the same name by Dmitry Glukhovsky. With five million copies sold in 37 different countries, you can expect the book and therefore the story to be good and the stats back that up, on amazon, the book has 4.7 stars with 79% of those being 5-star reviews. This amazing narrative makes the game's story make sense and keeps everything following. His book is the foundation of the game and creates a very powerful story-driving narrative.
	That gets me to my next point. Metro 2033 is a story-based game, now I won't get into the details of the story to avoid spoilers but it is good. Some of you are now turned away from the game, ¨ew a story-based game? All I want to do is to shoot monsters!¨ but believe me when I say many many monsters will die at your hands, and much like Yin and Yang the story revolves around combat and combat around the story.

Combat ⭐⭐⭐⭐
	Metros combat is solid, although not the best I've played. The combat system is split into two paths, stealth, and fighting. There are a total of ten weapons Metro has to offer all with modifications and attachments available that do drastically change the play style of a gun, surprisingly the revolver is pretty versatile. Obviously, you can go for a combat and fighting play style, always shooting your way through every encounter, and the game does have settings that make this option more fun and doable. But the game is designed in a survival stealth play style that you can easily increase in difficulty in the start menu. When playing this way your supplies will be very limited and stealth is the most effective way to get through your enemies, especially humans. Personally, I find the stealth play style very fun and it fits the game really well, having to sneak past enemies looting and to get behind them to silently take them down. The game's flashlight is also designed around this as enemies will see it if it's on and start shooting, whereas, with the night vision goggles, this debuff is removed.

Setting ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐
	The metro setting is insanely well done, you can tell the game developers put a lot of effort into making you feel as though you are there, with good headphones this effect is very potent. The general ambiance of the metro tunnels is perfect, dark, scary, radioactive glowing mushrooms, corpses of brave souls who died, you are never sure what will be ahead, your flashlight only going a bit ahead of you. But occasionally there are moments when you can feel safe, light coming down from the world above. The metro stations, their version of towns, are full of life, even though there are not that many NPCs walking around or vendors selling goods, the stations feel more alive than countless of the other games have played, you can tell what it would be like to live in these settlements, always in fear, not much space, and food always being an issue. One of the best touches to make this world feel alive is the currency, military-grade bullets, you can shoot them and they do more damage, but the vendors take them as money, showing how much weapons and bullets are needed to keep everyone alive and safe and how dangerous the tunnels truly are. 
The surface is a different story, there are no moments of peace on the surface, and you are in constant fear. There could be any number of dangers around every bend, from packs of hungry mutants to flying demons. You literally are never safe. You also have more to manage on the surface which can lead to very tense situations, your gas mask needs its filter changed every few minutes and if its alarm goes off during combat you are in for a sticky situation, that is if it's not already broken from being hit… 

Settings/Graphics ⭐⭐⭐⭐/⭐⭐⭐
	Metro has a large variety of gameplay settings, with five different difficulty settings and four levels of graphic settings; your game can be however you want on any system you want. I really don't have much to say here but I'll mention a few things. First, the difficulty settings are very good in this game, turning up the difficulty level will affect how you play the game. If you want more information I would go look at the wiki. Second, the graphics are pretty good for a 13-year-old game. They can stand up to time. The graphics setting will allow for any modern system to run Metro, the recommended settings on Steam show you only need 4GB of ram and a GeForce GTX 480 to run, and a 280 for minimum settings, the game will not be pretty but it will run with such low graphics. If you have anywhere near a modern system you should easily be able to run the game with max settings. With max settings, the game looks good, a few areas should look better, but for a 13-year-old game the graphics are amazing at max and after a while, of playing you won't notice the lack of photorealistic graphics. And if you do notice, there are mods that you can get that add in way more enhanced graphics, and/or raytracing!

In conclusion, I believe that Metro 2033 is a great game. For the low price of $20; It has an amazing story, an amazing setting, good combat, and decent graphics. From a story-based gamer's perspective, this game could even be up with RDR2 in its story. And I am not alone Metro 2033 has almost 60,000 reviews on steam and 88% of those are positive reviews, and 95% of the 870 recent reviews are also positive, there are still active players and still people reviewing the game. Even though it's 13 years old it still puts up a hell of a fight.

So I'll start this off by saying that this game is incredibly old and therefor doesn't hold up in many ways graphically to current gen games. It doesn't look bad texture wise but some of the animations can seem a bit stiff and robotic, so if you wan't ultimate graphics, you came to the wrong game.

Now that we have that out of the way, lets start with the actual review. For starters, I'll talk about the story(without going into too much detail). You play as Artyom, a Russian boy who grew up living in the metros of a post-apocalyptic Moscow. One day your uncle comes to visit your settlement, of which is promptly attacked by the mutated creatures that now roam the metros and surface wastes. After defending your settlement from a mutant invasion, your uncle is informed about an attack that is occurring and leaves, giving you a message to deliver to the group he is a part of. From there the game takes you on a wild run through the desolate metro tunnels and toxic surface wastes, helping and killing people along the way. The game has some decisions that when made could lead to one of two different endings. Some of the decisions can be really easy to miss which can make getting a desired ending kind of annoying without the use of a guide. All in all, the story is good, though nothing particularly special, and definitely worth at least one playthrough.

The gameplay is a bit of a different beast. While it advertises itself as a horror game, I personally wouldn't classify it as such. Granted, I played on normal, so maybe the hardest difficulty is more scary, though I imagine that is only the case because the hardest difficulty makes supplies like ammunition and the like incredibly scarce. Though even on normal difficulty resource management can be a bit of a challenge. The mutant enemies in this game tank rounds like miniature panzers; which can result in you loosing vast quantities of your ammunition stores very quickly every time you have to enter combat with a hoard of them. The human enemies are far more enjoyable to fight as you always are given multiple solutions to a problem. You can go in loud and messy, or quiet and clean. The stealth works very well, with only the occasionally weird enemy detection. My only gripe is that once they have been alerted to the fact that you're there, they never stop looking, no matter how long you stay hidden. Besides that, I would say the combat is very solid when fighting humans, and a bit frustrating when tackling any of the mutants. I will say that you need to be careful with resources though as the game has no qualms with essentially soft locking you if you run out of things like filters or ammo and can't find any nearby. I was almost unable to beat the game as I ran out of regular bullets for all my guns at the very end, and one of the last cutscenes requires you to shoot an enemy in order to progress. Luckily the bullets that you use as currency can also be used in certain guns, of which I just happened to be carrying on me.

Now for the problems. The game is buggy and a bit unoptimized. Not game breaking by any means, but it certainly has its fair share of problems. The game can be kinda laggy any time you are in a cutscene, though in my experience the rest of the game ran rather well. This is a little bit of a bummer as the games cutscene aren't terrible, and would be better if not for the massive frame drops I was getting. Mind you, I'm not running on an old system either. I have a 2080ti, Ryzen 7 3800x and 64gb of 3600mhz ram. I have a beefy computer, but the game still struggled to stay at a consistent 60 at times. As for the bugs, those range from visual, AI/gameplay, to full blown crashes. While I say crashes, I have only every crashed once, but I know that several other people are running into issues with the game crashing, so I figured it is still something to keep in mind. The visual bugs can be ignored as the are mostly just things like z fighting in several areas, but nothing that actually affects the gameplay. The AI and gameplay can be a bit of a bigger problem though. I've encountered everything from enemies continuing to stand after being killed, them snapping backwards as if they just turned on their lag switch to them just not responding to being shot. I've also run into a couple of gameplay bugs, such as getting grabbed by an enemy and upon getting out of the grab; the player model got stuck to the enemy and I was dragged around and eventually forced to reload as I couldn't move. This was probably the biggest and most breaking of bugs I found, though I only encountered it once, so I would say overall isn't anything like a Bethesda title in terms of its bugs/glitches.

Overall the game is worth getting despite the few gripes I have mentioned above. It is a definitive must play, especially if you can get the game series while its on sale, though for the amount of hours put in, I will still say it is worth picking up at full price.

Has some good stuff in it, but overall, so much absolutely TERRIBLE design. The Air Filter feature for example, where you are always running out of air and must find new air filters. On harder difficulty settings, you are always short on them, and literally have to use cheese to survive. But more importantly, it kills exploration, as you are always in a rush, and fun, and turns the game into some kind of a sadistic exercise by the developers.  Then throw in lack of ammo on harder difficulty settings, and it's just a shit-show all around.

I'll give an example: 
There is a mission towards the end where you and a group of elite rangers sneak into archives. A massive firefight against Nosalises (mutants) begins. These elite rangers cannot hit the side of a barn with their full auto weapons, so all the Nosalises just march past them in slow motion and head toward you. You have to spend all your ammo to take them down, and then the next level begins without even giving you a chance to buy new ammo. There is stuff hidden around here and there, but it will kill all your fun to be constantly desperately searching for filters or ammo, while being seconds away from failing the level. Other games like System Shock 2 had similar mechanics (scarce ammo, etc), but those were well designed and implemented, leading to a fun flow of gameplay, here it's just constant cursing and frustration.

[h1]Review 6.5/10[/h1]

[b]Good Points: Good Script and Art Direction[/b]

Despite being an old game, Metro has a really good Graphics in comparison with the games released around the same year, as an CGI Artist I can say the game explore really well: 

- Good adaptation from Dmitry Glukhovsky Universe
- The environment and World Build 
- Good Modelling and textured objects 
- Really well made camera effects, creating realistic experience

[b]Bad Points: Bad Gaming Design in general[/b]

- Enemy AI dont make a Noise when approaching, as a Hardcore FPS player playing on the maximum difficulty with no HUD, is really frustrating when an enemy creature come from behind and kill you, without making a single noise, we're talking about a bear sized creature.

- Throwables keep stucking in the middle of the air sometimes, despite any FOV changes.

- Multiple commands in a single key, misleading the character action in game sometimes 

- A lot of camera effects turns the screen really polluted in some game parts

- When playing some chapters with ally AI, enemy AI will always focus the player, wich is really annoying because sometimes you're walking in the map with 3 allies and 10 creatures starts jumping on you without a single attack on friendly AI

Oh man, my first horror game and what an entry into the genre :) I've listened to the Metro 2033 audiobook a few years ago, but kind of half-heartedly, and I'm revisiting the books now thanks to this gem.

The game had a really good balance between action/scary moments/relief/story - in other words, pacing. It was really enjoyable to go through the missions, but not in the ''Ok, gotta collect X, Y, and Z resources, level up, and gear up" grindy way that keeps you hooked but isn't actually enjoyable thoroughly. I played the game on normal mode, and if I wasn't doing stupid things, I didn't really struggle for filters or ammo like I was scared I'd be. I could upgrade my weapons, but I'm not sure in the end how much of a difference that made. There's no stats to anything. I had a 3 weapon combo that just worked for me so I kept them the whole game without issue.

For me, the atmosphere was great in the game - besides the visuals: as far as we're concerned, Artyom is just a young guy given a mission that genuinely could kill him at every step of the way, but there really is no other way. There's no mentor who can help you master every skill you need before the quest, you just have to buy/scavenge as much gear as you can and get on with it, because if not you - then who? Artyom is a silent and faceless protagonist, which allows us to empathise with him all the more. He's not a badass witcher trained from childhood and mutated to suit the purpose he's given. He's us; an average girl/guy handed a gun and told "see that horde of monsters? Let's go! Woops, actually you're on your own now, good luck." This makes completing each mission so beautifully satisfying for lack of better word.

The world is immersive despite limited ability to interact with it in non-essential ways, and being composed of essentially corridors. Each dialogue and overheard conversation is worth hearing, and the world - although fantastical - is realistic. And the story, considering the ending, great :) 

Although I gotta say it was annoying at times, as others mentioned, how many hidden mechanics you have to discover yourself with no hint from the game - I had no idea the whole game that you could actually know how visible you are/how much time on a filter you have/you can wipe your mask clean. Many things I had to look up e.g. that you can destroy some doors with attacks, and I did get lost a bit.

All in all, solid 8/10. It's just genuinely a good, enjoyable experience. Shooting mechanics are good, all the stats and numbers are taken out, allowing you to just live the story, and not stress about craft/grind so often found in games. And if it's hostile, you kill it. [spoiler] But what if it isn't? [/spoiler]

Metro 2033 provides a unique and intense gaming experience. The post-apocalyptic world of the Moscow Metro is beautifully rendered and the survival elements of the game add a level of difficulty and immersion.

The combat system is challenging, forcing the player to think strategically and make every shot count. The use of scarce resources adds a layer of tension to each encounter. The A.I. of the enemies is also noteworthy, as they behave realistically and can catch the player off guard.

The story is engaging, painting a bleak picture of a world struggling to survive. The characters are well developed and the player can sense their desperation and hopelessness. The decision-making mechanic adds an additional level of depth, allowing the player to shape the story in their own way.

Overall, I highly recommend Metro to anyone looking for a challenging and atmospheric shooter. Its unique setting and survival elements set it apart from other games in the genre.

Rest in peace Andrii Korzinkin, you will live on in our games!

Animator Andrii Korzinkin, who worked at developer 4A Games, has died following a combat mission in Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The news was confirmed by designer Leonid Stepanov, who worked with Korzinkin at 4A on Metro Exodus before leaving to work at Remedy Entertainment.

"Andrii 'Nizrok' Korzinkin died while performing a combat mission in the struggle for independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine," wrote Stepanov. A talented animator, incredible person and real hero."

Korzinkin began his animation career as a 3D animator at Ukrainian studio Pixelation, during which he worked on the TV series Angel Baby. In 2017, he entered the game industry as a senior animator for 4A as it was working on 2019's Metro Exodus. Following Russia's invasion of Ukraine earlier this year, Korzinkin voluntarily enlisted into the Ukrainian military.

"Andrii was an awesome human being, very responsive and supportive, always ready to help, incredibly responsible and dedicated person," wrote 4A's technical designer Vitalii Keda. "He always stood out with his dry humor and strive for excellence. [...] You will be missed, dear friend. Rest in peace. Heroyam slava!"

About the game:
The game's atmosphere and unique design choices will make it a worthwhile experience for some, but Metro 2033 suffers from a number of issues (poor implementation of stealth, recurring glitches, etc.). Fans of post-apocalyptic stories should consider giving this a shot, if they can tolerate the aforementioned setbacks.

I picked this game up looking for just a bread n' butter kind of FPS since I felt in a rut with my regular gaming genres. I didn't realise I was signing up for a series and also the anger at EA games for hoarding the 3rd instalment to themselves for so long. 
This is classic Russian Dystopia at it's finest. This is fallout in a different, darker timeline with a different playstyle.
Years after playing through this I bought the books these games are based off of and just now, about 40 minutes ago, finished the first one and ever since starting it I have been ITCHING to replay this series. 
I don't know if I've ever replayed a story based game after I've finished it, but I'm happy for this to be my first.
If you're interested in the world I would highly recommend the book(s). There is less action in the pages as the game needed to be, well, a game, but the world caped in despair is incredible and the ending is so so well done.

It's a good game and it reminds me a lot of Dishonored regarding the impact your actions have on the ending, but my complaint is that if you want to attach such importance to your choices, then at least make the level design good enough to sustain it. In Dishonored you had the level design specifically crafted for both stealthy and aggressive approaches, but here, the way it is, it just invites the player to do everything to survive. For example, when it comes to gameplay the crouch is so badly designed, you don't know whether the enemies can see you or not even if you're behind an obstacle - which makes finishing a level in a stealthy way quite difficult.

Other than that, the game feels great, it's very immersive, has good humor, good music, funny voice acting reminding those from former communist countries of stories from the age. The gameplay is smooth and responsive and there is variety in gear. It's worth playing.

It's pretty, I'll give it that; sadly it is also boring, linear, and scripted. 

Now I could deal with some of those aspects, you see?

But I can't deal with the terrible pacing throughout the game; the slow lines of dialog and their deadpan delivery by the voice actors, the long walks of just watching and hearing people speaking to one another.

The vain attempt from the game to try to create a credible atmosphere gets reduced to the graphical fidelity; but it can't only be relegated to that, right? There has to be more to make the world believable and real, and since it's also a game, well, shouldn't the game have its focus in its gameplay and interactions more than in its presentation and story?

At least in the gameplay segments I do believe there's an argument to be made here.

I love how atmospheric this game is. For me, this is a satisfying substitute for my Fallout/post-apocalyptic urges when I wanna mix it up from Fallout. I've played 2033 before Redux on the original Xbox 360 and I loved it then. I subjectively feel the game has aged well. 

My only complaint is that there are still several level mesh/environment bugs when loading into new areas. Sometimes it flickers, and other times just doesn't show up. However, if I were to reload my last checkpoint, it usually corrects itself. These environment mesh bugs are usually scattered throughout every level, but it's not really the immersion breaking when when you just ignore them after awhile. Maybe someday an update will be address this.

I bought all three Metro games some time ago, when there as a sale for the bundle, and then sat on them for a while without any real drive to play them. I had seen Exodus gameplay when it was first released and that was what prompted me to wishlist these games. I finally got around to starting 2033 recently since I have a cache of older games that I haven't played and I should really do something about that before I buy more... anyhow, I'm really into this game. It's like Fallout Lite, or Creepier F.E.A.R. It's just challenging enough that it isn't boring but not so convoluted that you give up in frustration because you can't figure out what the heck is going on. And maxed out on my new GPU, it's really pretty for an older game. If you like horror FPS games with an ongoing and involved story and haven't played Metro yet, then definitely get on that. I'll probably get the books too because I'm an avid reader and having these visuals will enhance the reading experience.
Fantastic game, engaging gunplay and a very unique world to play in. Loved this game from beginning to end.

Metro 2033 is a linear horror shooter set in a post-apocalyptic universe.

The universe of the game is quite complete, we find different factions, a good bestiary and a very good story. In spite of the linear side, during the adventure you can find materials to improve your weapons in a complete way, you also have to manage the filter of your gas mask in order to pass in some areas of the game.

The combat system is also very satisfying, you can do it by shooting everything that moves or in infiltration with various equipment for the 2 styles of play.

There are two different endings depending on certain choices you make during your adventure.

In conclusion, if you are looking for a short (~10 hours) and not too expensive game with a good story, a satisfying gameplay and an excellent atmosphere, then this game is for you.

Metro 2033 Redux is a pretty faithful remaster of the original title. This was actually my first experience with Metro 2033 I ended up playing the original quite a while after playing this version. Realistically, this is the superior version on a technical level. It runs better, plays much better and doesn't have the bugs and such that the original has as a result of a lack of support.

That being said, there will be people who are peeved at the way certain elements of the originals art-design have been messed with. The game is remastered based on the visuals of Last Light, however not just on a technical level. This game uses a totally different lighting system to that of the original and combined with a lot of new/updated character models, this game has a different identity to that of the original. The old version is much darker and depressing imo, this new version is might brighter and it does contrast in strange ways in certain areas.

It's not gonna be noticeable for most people, but if you're a hardcore fan there will certainly be minor details that will bother you. For everyone else however, I think this remaster is very serviceable and is a perfectly valid way to experience this modern fps classic.

Metro 2033 which was released in 2010 left in me only good memories. Years later in 2014 was released Redux version of the game, technically it’s the same 2033 but with improved graphics. Due to developers notifications said - were improved also AI of the opponents and stealth.

Metro 2033 is one of the few games which I played more then one time. So I played original 2033 version in 2013, then in 2014, after the release I played Redux version. And now I played the console Redux version of the game.

2033 Redux today looks the same good, it’s wonderful game about post-apocalypse. Developers wonderfully showed not only the dark atmosphere but also all nuances and details of the city. Walking through the post-apocalypse Moscow you see city in all details, and you have feeling that it’s real. In some periods of the game it feels not only dark, but as a thriller with some elements of horror. In the game you won’t see screamers, but due to the atmosphere you feel scared to move through location.

The game remained exactly as I remember it from the first playthrough - gloomy, intriguing and addictive. Years past but I still remember how scary I was when used to pass first location alone, and when I first have seen librarian.

About gameplay it’s regular shooter, as Call of Duty, with good plot. But to kill opponents you need not only skill, because one headshot is not enough. It’s really hardcore game, where opponents have much health and you need at least 2 headshots to make a kill. But for me it was not bad, I enjoyed it.

The game has two endings, about which I didn’t know before. To get the good one you need to make good things during the game.

If you only want to get into Metro universe and thinking about playing 2033 or go straight to Exodus version - you definitely need to try the 2033 Redux version. But to understand the plot it is not necessary to play the first part, Exodus has a minimum of references to its predecessors. Rather, it is worth playing in 2033 to expand understanding of the world, which is discussed in the sequels of this universe.
