The game is very clunky as far as shooters are concerned. Especially considering when it released. At the height of FPS games (CoD, Battlefield, CSGO etc) you'd think the aiming would be decent, but even at max movement speed it feels sluggish and unresponsive. Mechanics gotta work well in a survivor shooter.

That aside, the game is well paced and segmented with respect to levels and chapters. The plot is fine enough; nothing convoluted or that takes itself too seriously. The sound design is very good; it makes the stealth sections easier to complete since you can hear where enemies are when not in immediate view. Levels are fairly compact and well laid out as expected of a linear shooter game. Supplies are plentiful enough; on Survivor difficulty I was never wanting for ammo or money until the final level (though that is clearly by design).

Just wish the way the game plays and controls were better. It really feels like the game was coded 10 years before it even released. Plus the game frankly isn't critical to play the others. Wouldn't pay above $5 for this.

Very much a product of it's time. The Redux version improves the graphics slightly (still ended up not aging well) and that's about it. It's not a bad game, but you have to put up with all of the contemporary crap that video games had when it originally came out.
Still, the game has its charm (exploring creepy metro tunnels, characters with heavy Russian accents - everyone loves those), and you can get it for really, really cheap on sale. So if you're looking to burn 6-7 hours and are willing to put up with some 2010 jank it's still worth a playthrough.

You are a survivor of the nuclear holocaust, living in a Russian subway. This game is far more punishing than the average post Apocalyptic game: tougher and smarter enemies. Fewer supplies. The need for specialized gear that requires replacement filters. Which is part of the game's strength. You won't be mowing down hordes of radiated mutants with miniguns while standing in a puddle of green goo. Nor are you some hero with special abilities. All you are is another nobody with his gun. 

Not my favorite post Apocalyptic game. Not open world. No crafting or building. Exploration isn't rewarding. Game is story-driven. However, I love post Apoc games, and there aren't very many of them set in Russia. Nice for a change of pace.

The Metro series of books have been some of my favorites for a long, long time. There is a lot to love about the content of the stories, from the rich world building to the characters to the action. Topics are touched that are still relative and important to this day.

The games take upon the base of Metro and turn it into an intensive, immersive experience. It's a relatively simple and straightforward game as far as mechanics go, but the way everything is broken into chapters/acts is quite fun and gives the player a break between events.

I would recommend picking up the games, as they are fun, still hold up very well, and the story is enjoyable. 

And read the books, too.

The post-apocalyptic setting is incredibly immersive and the sense of danger and isolation that it creates is palpable.

One of the things that stood out to me about Metro 2033 Redux was the attention to detail in the environments and character models. The game does an excellent job of conveying the harsh realities of life in a world that has been devastated by nuclear war. The tense and claustrophobic atmosphere is further enhanced by the use of limited resources and the need to constantly be on the lookout for danger.

Overall, I would highly recommend Metro 2033 Redux to anyone who is a fan of atmospheric games or post-apocalyptic settings. The gameplay is engaging and the story is well-written, making for an immersive and memorable gaming experience

Metro 2033 is a perfectly serviceable relatively low-budget FPS from the early 2010s with one foot firmly planted in the Xbox 360 era of console shooters. This means it has a nasty, low field of view, decent enough graphics with noisy textures and lots of weird post-processing effects and colour-correction, and very okay gunplay.

The story is okay, but many of the philosophical, sci-fi, horror, various other ideas contained within the game are in themselves probably more interesting than the story itself. Artyom's tale is perfectly adequate, though there's some problems with it, such as the game not doing a very good job of explaining what it is your goal actually is, how you intend to go about solving the problem, and how you even obtained the information the leads to the solution at the end of the game. I'm being vague cuz spoilers.

Metro 2033 is a very easy game, I played on Hardcore and it's what I would recommend for new players trying it out for the first time - Ranger mode and Ranger Hardcore mode are both not worth playing because, while I like a lacking HUD for extra immersion and I think the game is somewhat capable of it, it feels very haphazardly implemented because it hides EVERYTHING. Including tutorial prompts, which is very bad for your first time playing, as well as interact prompts. This is problematic if you haven't played the game at least a couple times beforehand and already know every step inside and out.

Aside from difficulty selection, the game is very easy in general. You almost always have an AI partner who will do most of the work for you, and the game only will filter out one or two enemies in a pack to focus you, and those are the only ones you really have to deal with. The amount of loot is pretty ridiculous too, so you'll never really be short of gear so long as you give your surroundings a cursory glance. This didn't really impact my enjoyment.

Since this is in spirit a 360 console shooter, it has all the hallmarks, it has vehicle sections, on rails sections, turret sections, it has all of that stuff. It also has no final boss, as in traditional FPS games - as was the style at the time, in favour of a cutscene.

There's a fair selection of weapons you can pick up through the game, but I felt the balance was a little inadequate, all you really need is the throwing knives and any suppressed weapon to deal with every human enemy in the game silently and efficiently, and for mutants all you need is any shotgun. Even the 'earlygame' duplex will work quite late into the game because they never get stronger, so for the entire game my loadout was the revolver, an AK, and a duplex/shambler/other shotgun. I guess it's fine?

There's only two endings in the game and you can get both of them by just reloading the last checkpoint, basically, and picking the other ending (as far as I know) so uh, that's nice I guess.

Overall it's a perfectly good game and I enjoyed my time playing it, it has a lovely melancholy tone, some good graphics, great accents, and some okay characters kind of. It's worth playing for the story, maybe pick it up on sale if you just really love FPS games and you need a shooter to play.

Masterpiece that still holds up ,Its fairly well known metro series are spiritaul succesor of S.T.A.L.K.E.R series taking many pages from its book, but i prefer the metro universe, as cool as stalker is. I have played around 50 hrs on console previously. Its still a game i daydream ,comes up in conversation every now and then.For a game with a grim colour filter, 2010's 2033 was also remarkably pretty. 2014's version is a marked difference. I'm not talking a little texture upgrade here, I'm talking new meshes, new animations and reworked environments/particle effects, improve SSMA,AA etc. Metro 2033 Redux is Metro 2033 tweaked and polished to a high standard making it look still fairly modern in 2020, 'Almost metro exodus'

They also balanced the combat so that it isn't just a game full of intense combat making you feel combat fatigued it also offers time for you to look around and explore the world a little  in fallout esque open world feel, some areas are far more linear . but in open area the more inquistive and explorative types they are sometimes rewarded by finding a hidden stash that you may find yourself in desperate need of on the harder levels of difficulty. Ammo is everything in the game, always in short supply. if your a scav. Ammo is currency as it is, what you need to survive, there common and  reloaded grade. and pre war Military Grade Rounds, MGR currency, or sometimes refered to as 'Premium grade or top shelf ammo' is main Money due to its value increasing as its becoming rarer. The value yeilds higher for than gold and silver. , due to good ammunition is held to high value due to that all parts and settlements of metro will always be willing to trade for it.

The story keeps you interested throughout the entire game and they did a good job at building an entire world to immerse yourself in with underground towns and markets to explore even going down to the small details like the blood,rain or radioactive waste splattering against your gas mask if you've just had a close encounter with an enemy or the way it fogs up occasionally or cracks if you were fall over or get stray bullet skims you.. The game also doesn't give much background music instead allowing you to immerse yourself and focus on the sounds in the environment.Expect for 'Stalker campfire' Moments.

Moral Points form a hidden system in the Metro video game series that follows Artyom's progress and affects the ending of each game.It is commonly understood that every time Artyom gets a moral point, the screen flashes light blue and whispers or the sound of water dripping can be heard. When Artyom loses a moral point, the screen darkens and an ominous sound can be heard. There are more opportunities to gain moral points than to lose them, and moral points that are gained and lost are speculated to vary in severity. Moral points can be gained through making morally correct decisions, being stealthy in certain levels, but can also be awarded for exploring every part of the map to get weapons and supplies. The best way to gain moral points is to knock out enemies and spare lives when possible - doing so will almost always activate the good endings. This is hidden system for the most part, but note worthy , if not a bit of spoiler.

[h1] METRO 2033 REDUX - REVIEW: HOW TO NOT FALL IN LOVE WITH IT? [/h1]

I'm writing this review right after finishing the game for the first time. It's my first time with a Metro series game but because I like a more challenging gameplay I decided on the Ranger Hardcore difficulty which makes the game a little more "realistic" having to really manage your resources like ammo, gas mask filters , medkits... Artyom can die very quickly to the point of being one-shot but you also deal more damage to enemies.

It's a game that suits all types of players, those who like a more stealth gameplay or Rambo mode and both can be extremely fun to play. As I was on Ranger Hardcore difficulty I opted for Stealth for most of the game since otherwise I would die every 2 seconds, but the parts where you just shoot everywhere are also incredibly fun.

Also not forgetting the fact that being a Survival Horror this game has an incredible ability to make your heart race with suspense/jump scare moments, or to relieve you with cozy environments or make you freak out because you think a scene would be scary and ends up being relieving.

In the most Metro 2033 Redux is a complete game to please everyone, great setting and graphics for its time, it also does not shy away from the adaptation of the novel by Dmitriy Glukhovskiy, a very calm pace and smooth learning curve. Easy to learn and not too difficult to master.

Magnificent game. Post-apocalyptic Russia, Mutants, Nazis, Communists- what an experience! 10/10 recommended.

A really solid game. Graphics still hold out for a game that was released back in 2014, and options to reduce the quality in favour of performance worked well. I played this on my 2017 13'' Macbook Air (really bad for gaming), and i was able to get consistent 40 fps with the lowest graphics setting. 

While some parts can get frustrating at times due to the lack of information given regarding directions (died a few times because of this) and some gameplay mechanics (i wasnt able to figure out how to use throwables until i looked up a guide for it), the immersive gameplay and story makes up for it. Gunplay experience is pretty decent and there a quite a bunch of options when it comes to gun selections, although the customisation options for some guns are kinda lacking. As for the story, you take the role of the (almost) mute protagonist Artyom, as he embarks on a journey to save the people living in the metro system from mysterious creatures called "The Dark Ones". While he doesn't speak much in the game, most of his thoughts about the events happening around him are explained through his journal entries. 

Multiple difficulty choices are available for those who wants to challenge themselves. Personally i stuck with Spartan & Normal difficulty for my first playthrough.

While it is atmospheric and somewhat engaging, the demerits outweigh the merits.
For starters, almost nothing is really explained in regards to controls/difficulty, so it takes some tinkering to figure things out. The story goes places I guess, but from what I've read, while there is a choice it is completely disregarded in the sequel, so is there even a choice?

Graphics don't look that bad, but it's nothing special either. Lens flares are extremely annoying however and it seems that the AI is not affected by your flashlight at all, while they can blind you completely. 

Gunplay is subpar most of the time, and there sometimes seems to be some sort of input lag/delay. Movement also feels extremely janky. It feels like vertical and horizontal sensitivities aren't the same, I could be wrong tho.

All of that I would get over and would even finish this game and probably give it a mixed-positive rating, if it weren't for the level "Trolley Combat". Whoever thought this level was a good idea should teach a course "How to make bad and needlessly frustrating video games". It's such a bad and annoying level, you die and have no control over the RNG of whether you'll make it through or no. So I stopped playing at that point. 

The game is passable overall, but nothing special. Yet for me, personally, it is disappointing.

I think this is my first review on steam. I usually cant be bothered to leave reviews, but this game was so damn good that I felt obligated to show some appreciation to the developers. Note, that this more a rant about how much I love this series rather than an objective review. 

Good Lord, the atmosphere of this entire franchise is just insane. Imo, the metro games are the #1 most atmospheric video game franchise of all time.  Dark, bleak, clostrophobic, underground, melancholic. If you are deciding on whether to buy this, if the atmosphere in the screenshots and gameplay looks like your cup of tea, then you cannot miss out on this one. 

Don't expect this game to have the best FPS mechanics. It's plays just like any other single player FPS and it is linear and not open world. But the game makes it work and there are still plenty to explore in these linear levels. 

Something I wasn't expecting was how much of a tactical FPS experience this game can be. When facing monsters, the gameplay is like any other FPS, but i can be quite intense, because you're often in tight areas, and they are hard to out run. It really makes you feel trapped underground and forced to confront these mutants. However, when facing human enemies, because you can use stealth, one shot them in the head, the gameplay can become basically a horror themed tactical shooter experience, if you choose to play that way, and I think that is amazing. 

This is only game series I know of, that has level of atmosphere, combined with gameplay that while isn't necessarily innovative, provides a duality of both intense slow paced and face paced gunplay, and the option to choose stealth as well. 

If someone were to force me to choose what my favorite video game of all time is, you can bet on me saying its Metro. Happy new year to the Metro developers, I'm very late to say this, but fantastic job on this video game adaptation.

Favorite FPS franchise as of right now. Brilliant shit. I'd recommend looking into the history of these games, 4a put their hearts and souls into the Metro series and you can feel it when you're playing

A dark atmospheric shooter through a STALKER inspired wasteland based on the novels of the same name. 

PROS:
-Good plot
-Tense dark levels: the developer cleverly guides the player along a well sculpted linear path.
-A reasonable amount of good first person animations further aid the atmosphere and immersion

NEUTRALS:
-The gunplay is very basic, but sufficient. 
-The original lacked some basic "quality of life" features, but the redux version remedies most of those issues

CONS:
-The gameplay mechanics are barely explained. Most are self-explanatory, but a few (like the morality system which dictates the games ending) is never really explained or mentioned at all. 
-Little variety to enemies or weapons
-Little to no replay value
There's a good game buried in here, but the game is too clunky to enjoy.

From my experience, Metro 2033 is a quite linear corridor shooter with some sprinkle of open spaced area in between to keep things fresh. Atmosphere and sound design is top notch, immersing you in the storyline and combat.

Gameplay wise, there are not much to say about this game. Nothing quite outstanding in every aspect but in a good way. It might not be the next innovation in this genre but it did everything just right.

Resource wise, you will have to manage a few types. One for crafting filters for mask and weapon upgrades, one for currency that also is higher damage ammo. 
Stealth is not quite great but is a viable option.
Gunplay is okay within your expectation of how weapon behaves in FPS genre.
Graphic wise, it has aged quite well in my opinion. Even from 2022 standard.

Within my playthrough, I have encountered a few problems:
- Some scripted segment have really small room for error. 
- Sometimes, game just drop you in a quite big area and leave you to solve puzzles or looking for next objective on your own. (You have compass that points you to next objective but that's it) Forcing you to trial and error, dying over and over again.

Overall it's a really good game with good storyline. 
I would totally recommend buying this alongside next 2 sequel in a bundle if you are interested.

If you're in the mood for a post-apocalyptic adventure that'll leave you on the edge of your seat, look no further than Metro 2033. This first-person shooter, set in the ruins of Moscow, will have you fighting for survival against all sorts of creepy crawlies and otherworldly creatures.

But don't let the monsters scare you off - the real thrill of Metro 2033 comes from its immersive atmosphere and rich storytelling. As you journey through the desolate subway tunnels, you'll encounter a cast of memorable characters and uncover the mystery behind the world's downfall.

One thing that really sets Metro 2033 apart is its unique blend of stealth and action gameplay. Whether you prefer to sneak around or go in guns blazing, there's a playstyle for everyone. And with a variety of weapons and upgrades at your disposal, the combat never gets stale.

But be warned - this game is not for the faint of heart. The intense action and heart-pounding moments will have you gripping your controller so tight, you might just break it.

All in all, Metro 2033 is a must-play for any fan of the post-apocalyptic genre. Just make sure you bring plenty of ammo and a sturdy flashlight - you never know what lurks in the shadows.

This game gets compared to STALKER and Fallout a lot, though I honestly don't think that's fair. The settings are superficially similar, but the main difference is the STALKER and Fallout games are both fun and immersive, with excellent writing, satisfying mechanics and worlds with so many hidden details you can't help but wander off the beaten path to discover them. This game doesn't do any of that. If you wanted the excruciatingly boring, tedious and confusing subway tunnels from Fallout 3 to be a whole game, this is the one for you. Take a ride on a ghost train through dozens of samey environments, backtrack pointlessly through identical metro stations, have the tension ruined by one-hit-kill cinematics. Oh and if you want to see the whole screen you're going to have to find and edit a hidden file in the game directory to manually change the FOV.

Three disclaimers: I got the game on a brief 100%-off sale, I've not read the Metro novels, nor did I play the pre-Redux or other Metro releases before this.

This game is both amazing and infuriating. For every time my jaw dropped when witnessing the level of detail put into the engine, I spent another cursing the save system or [u]absolute lack of direction or explanation of mechanics[/u]. You have to figure almost every mechanic out by getting stuck and looking up a guide, or dying and learning, "Well, guess I can't do that. Back to the last checkpoint."

Will I play the next game in the series? Absolutely. Will I tip the scales of this review into the positive? No. I was annoyed more than engaged.

As far as the Spartan/Survival goes, Spartan is basically an easier difficulty: you get more health, ammo,  filter duration, and a more accurate filter timer. However, [u]even in Spartan, this is not a standard FPS[/u]. Plenty of things will still insta-kill you, and ammo still needs conserved in some levels.

STALKER fans will appreciate the similar world and a number of the same devs. However, remember that this entry in the Metro series is very linear, with more emphasis on story, stealth and survival.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+Multiple gameplay difficulties
+You can replay levels if you missed something
+Having to watch for and disarm traps was nice
+Stealth mechanics are done pretty well
+The details in carrying Sasha were praiseworthy
+NPC pathing is semi-random
+The moment of choice was nicely done (avoiding spoilers there)

[h1]YMMV[/h1]
~Levels are largely linear
~Many levels have time limits
~Jumpscares
~Occasional quicktime events
~Game loves insta-killing you, even on easier difficulties
~Screw those clipping Demons
~Many environments are fascinating, but you can't actually explore much

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
-[u]Game explains almost no mechanics, and there are plenty[/u]
-Game frequently fails to explain objectives
-Needlessly complicated controls on KB&M
-Checkpoint save system (especially for stealth gameplay)
-Occasional unmarked points of no return
-NPCs frequently talk over one another
-Long, unskippable title screens (can be removed with file edits)
-"Next Page" diary key can't be changed, making it unusuable if 'F' bound elsewhere
-Enemies can sometimes see or hit you through walls/floors
-Takedown prompt doesn't always appear, ruining everything
-Occasional clipping issues resulting in death or spastic movement
-That final segment of trial and error platforming was incredibly annoying

[h1]Saving you my aggro:[/h1]
> MGR's act both as currency and alternate high-power ammo for rifles
> The blue light on the watch shows how visible you are
> The timer on the watch shows how long your current filter will last
> The lighter is needed to burn some spider webs
> The compass points to your next objective
> The objective journal is alt-fire of the compass
> Traps can be disarmed
> Some doors can be broken with your knife

I am a 43 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
Thank you <3

[b]//Motion-sickness alert!//  [/b]
i can play most fps games fine, with the right FOV, pivot, and responsiveness. but this game always has something slightly off that triggers the nausea. Usually if i can't fix it in the settings, i'd just refund the game.

HOWEVER, Metro 2033 is special to me. i bought the original on the Xbox360, and it was love at first play-through. The original Metro 2033 is a cult classic for a reason, its clunky, had weird controls, low budget acting, and the cutscenes are unskippable, on top of the motion-sickness. But back then, no other game made me feel the way this game felt, and that's enough for me to power through.

it has realism. Not realistic, because its not. Metro creates the feel of being fully immersed in the game. You have this mindset to stay alive, not because you die easily, but because just 'being' occupies your attention. This leads to some interesting gameplay, like forgetting to remove my gasmask when i dont need it and not turning my headlamp back on, and so i cant see wth im doing. Also:
[h1] You can shoot your money for maximum firepower!!1 [/h1]

Metro 2033 is the kind of game that you either "get it" or you don't. Slight spoilers follow: 
[spoiler]There's 2 endings, but you don't just choose 1 at the end (like the notorious Mass Effect 3 launch.) The game has a mechanic to sort of see how you play the game, and if you check enough boxes, the game gives you the option for the Good ending, otherwise you're stuck with the Canon ending. i'll remember this forever since i felt like i have to earn that ending, or in other words, the game checks to see if i understand enough to deserve the good end.[/spoiler]

Redux is essentially a remaster, mainly to match Metro Last Light's engine. You can change controls now, and the short levels of the original, which were engine limited, are combined into longer levels, so there's less interruption to the story for loading. im not sure if i remember correctly, but i think we couldn't takedown enemies before, which made the original hard as hell. Some players have noted that difficulty changes were made to Ranger mode that are not true to the original.

Overall a pretty positive "Redux" its just a shame it didn't really address any motion-sickness issues, or add windowed mode/borderless fullscreen etc. I wouldn't recommend Metro 2033 Redux to just anyone, but it's still a unique experience for the right player.

Before I begin my review, it has spoilers, so if you don't want to be spoiled, don't read this review.
I love this game, and I own it on Playstation, GOG, Humble Bundle, and steam.
I have played it on Windows, Linux, and PlayStation.
This review will be based around Linux/Windows, and then I will add stuff from the other gameplays into it.

Storyline: 5 out of 5
This game has a remarkable story, and as I understand it, these games are based on 2 Russian books called metro 2033 and Metro 2035. Metro Exodus is the only game that is not based on a book; if I recall right.
I like how you are following the main protagonist for the whole game series. The main protagonist Is the youngest and newest member. He unofficially became a Ranger when Hunter assigned him his first mission to get to Polis to find Miller.

Design: 4 out of 5
You can see and feel it a Russian game, but it works well, and since it's happening in Russia, that makes it so much better. I like how they make you feel afraid when you in the dark or when you have to sneak around and turn off the light to keep hitten. Also, they have an excellent light effect that makes the game even more emerged.

Mechanics: 4 out of 5
I like the mechanic I mostly play this game with a controller, even on pc, and rarely do I find an FPS game fun and good with a controller. The only other game I can remember is Halo.

Music and Voice Acting: 4 out of 5
The music is good even if i don't listen that much to it, but the voice acting is a triple A game worthed.
I love the voice acting in the first two games. I'm not too fond of the voice acting in Metro Exodus. It doesn't feel as smooth and natural as in these first two games, and it feels kind of force. All the jokes they make feel forced on you in Metro Exodus, and it makes the game brah.

System: 4 out of 5
The system is simple, and it works. It doesn't try to be somthing it's not, and it gives you a lot of options to customize your weapons the way you want them. I am a silencer kind of guy i want to be as silent as i can when i shoot and take people down without noise. i also like that you are paying with army grade bullets since they are hard to get your hands on, so they are worth a lot. It's also cool that you need to recharge your batteries and re-pump your deadly bb-gun. Or how the light is hurting the spiders. Thats a nice touch that make them deadly but at the same time give you a fighting chance to kill them.

Conclusion 5 out of 5
my overall Conclusion is this game even if it from 2014 is still one of the best game in 2020/21 i feel like too many shitty games is getting out and to many don't see the quality and don't mind playing shitty games and still rate them high, but this game deserves to be ranked high, and i want to see more games like this where people put their soul into the game and want to make a game that is worth playing and people love to come back to or love to own more copies of it. 

If you play this game on Linux, i would recommend the steam version. It's more optimize and runs better I was playing this game on Proton 5.13, and I have to say it was running better than on windows and loads on 0-3 sec. One time I had pushed X before the screen was even loaded. That how fast it can load, and that's on an M.2 SSD.

Metro 2033 Redux is an incredibly immersive and atmospheric first-person shooter video game developed by Ukrainian studio 4A Games and published by Deep Silver. It is a remastered and enhanced version of the original Metro 2033 which was released in 2010. Metro 2033 Redux takes place in the year 2033 after a devastating nuclear war has decimated the world and survivors have taken refuge in the underground metro stations of Moscow. The players take control of Artyom, a young man who is sent on a mission to save humanity from a mysterious and powerful force.

The game features a number of key elements which contribute to the overall atmosphere and make it a thrilling experience. Firstly, the game world is incredibly detailed and immersive, with plenty of places to explore. The underground metro stations are filled with interesting characters, secrets and dangers. You will come across a variety of different factions, some of which are friendly and some of which are hostile.

In addition to the detailed world, the game also features a variety of weapons, enemies and items to collect. All these elements combine to create an intense and thrilling experience. The game also features a variety of different levels with varying objectives, which keeps the game fresh and exciting.

The main focus of Metro 2033 Redux is the story and characters. The story is incredibly gripping and the characters are well-developed and memorable. The narrative is full of twists and turns, and there are plenty of moments that will keep you on the edge of your seat. The game also features a number of moral choices which can have an effect on the story and your relationships with other characters.

The game also features a variety of weapons, enemies and items to collect. It is an intense and thrilling experience that will keep you hooked for hours on end. If you are a fan of first-person shooters or post-apocalyptic games, then Metro 2033 Redux is definitely worth checking out.

[h1] Review from a Dad with limited time to game: [/h1]

[b] Is it worth your time? [/b]
Yes, this game isn't without it's flaws, but it's a hell of a fun ride with lots of unique moments, and a rich backstory based off the novels by the same name. Furthermore it's the first in the series out of three, which I highly recommend playing in order. 

[b] What are the pros? [/b]
Challenging but not impossible to play with a couple different difficulty options depending on your preference. Great gunplay - the firearms and other weapons feel impactful and snappy, and have different customization options. Ammo is scarce but not impossible to find depending on which gameplay style you choose (I chose "Spartan" meaning more available ammo) you have to consider each shot you take, but there's still room for some spray and pray. The story is immersive and draws you in, there are several "just one more level" moments, and as mentioned before the lore is well established due to the novels. Though I didn't, there are multiple playthrough options with different available endings if you enjoy replaying a game a few times to try it out.

[b] What are the cons? [/b]
This may be me personally but I HATE the checkpoint system, the fact that you can't quicksave is huge drawback for me - not a dealbreaker by any means but still annoying. I did notice that even at "Normal" difficulty the game is pretty challenging, this didn't bother me at all, but I'm listing it as a con because there are only two options for your playthrough - normal and hardcore; I think every game should have an easy option for someone who wants to play more for the story less for the challenge. Also, this may be me nitpicking a bit but the game utilizes a compass system to navigate, meaning you have to literally take it out to see which direction you need to go and holster your weapon in the process, I hated this but some people find it immersive, so take that one as more of a neutral less of a con depending on your style of play.

[b] TLDR [/b]
It's fun, story is great, gunplay is great, navigation and checkpoint system are not my my favorite, but it didn't ruin the experience. Pick it up on sale, you wont regret it.

This game is an accurate simulation of what life is like in the soviet union 100% sneeki breeki game.

In 2013 the world was devastated by an apocalyptic event, annihilating almost all mankind and turning the Earth's surface into a poisonous wasteland. A handful of survivors took refuge in the depths of the Moscow underground, and human civilization entered a new Dark Age.

The year is 2033. An entire generation has been born and raised underground, and their besieged Metro Station-Cities struggle for survival, with each other, and the mutant horrors that await outside. You are Artyom, born in the last days before the fire, but raised underground. Having never ventured beyond the city limits, one fateful event sparks a desperate mission to the heart of the Metro system, to warn the remnants of mankind of a terrible impending threat.

Your journey takes you from the forgotten catacombs beneath the subway to the desolate wastelands above, where your actions will determine the fate of mankind. But what if the real threat comes from within?
Product Overview
Metro 2033 Redux is the definitive version of the cult classic ‘Metro 2033’, rebuilt in the latest and greatest iteration of the 4A Engine for Next Gen. Fans of the original game will find the unique world of Metro transformed with incredible lighting, physics and dynamic weather effects. Newcomers will get the chance to experience one of the finest story-driven shooters of all time; an epic adventure combining gripping survival horror, exploration and tactical combat and stealth.

All the gameplay improvements and features from the acclaimed sequel ‘Metro: Last Light’ have been transferred to Metro 2033 Redux – superior AI, controls, animation, weapon handling and many more – to create a thrilling experience for newcomers and veterans alike. With two unique play-styles, and the legendary Ranger Mode included, Metro 2033 Redux offers hours of AAA gameplay for an incredible price.
Game Features
Immerse yourself in the Moscow Metro - witness one of the most atmospheric worlds in gaming brought to life with stunning next-gen visuals at 60FPSBrave the horrors of the Russian apocalypse - equip your gasmask and an arsenal of hand-made weaponry as you face the threat of deadly mutants, human foes, and the terrifying environment itself

Rebuilt and Remastered for next-gen - this is no mere "HD port." Metro 2033 has been rebuilt in the vastly improved Last Light engine and gameplay framework, to create the definitive version of the cult classic that fans and newcomers alike can enjoy

Two unique Play Styles : "Spartan" and "Survival" - approach the game as a slow-burn Survival Horror, or tackle it with the combat skills of a Spartan Ranger in these two unique modes

The legendary Ranger Mode returns - dare you play the fearsome Ranger Mode? No HUD, UI, deadlier combat and limited resources combine to create the ultimate immersive experience

Metro 2033 Redux is the first installment in the Metro Franchise.

[u]Story[/u]

After a short introduction to the world of Metro and what's to come, Metro 2033 starts off in the Exhibition, a Metro Station that Artyom (the game protagonist) lives in. After a short walk through the station, you meet up with Hunter, a Ranger who is a part of the Spartan Order, a group of elite battle hardened soldiers that roam the wasteland.

Slight spoilers for the purpose of explaining the start of the story:
[spoiler]Shortly after an attack, you find out there is a lot more to the problem at hand than originally thought. Afterwards you're tasked with finding a man named Miller, in the event that Hunter does not return. You then set out on a journey to find Colonel Miller.[/spoiler]

The story is very well written, and gives you an immersive experience that puts you right in the heart of Russia's Metro twenty years after the nuclear war. You get to experience first-hand what life in the Metro is like, and must do what you can to survive the harsh environments, avoiding both mutants and human enemies alike.

[u]Characters / Relationships[/u]

Every single character is unique and genuine in their personalities. The relationships between Artyom and the rest of the characters you meet along the way were all well-written and developed throughout the entirety of the game. Every person you come across on your journey serves a different purpose to help you get to where you're supposed to be. Miller plays an especially important role for Artyom, and reaching him is your goal throughout the first half of the game. Artyom bonds with each character on a different level, and some stick around longer than others. The rest of the Order who serve under Colonel Miller all have an incredible bond, and they act more like brethren than fellow soldiers. This is portrayed throughout the game and was very well developed.

[u]Gameplay / Mechanics[/u]

Being the first game in the franchise, it set the foundation for what we all came to love.

The gameplay is absolutely astonishing. You're put in the deep end of the gritty, dark metro, with little to no supplies. Survival is only possible if you scrounge for resources, such as ammo, medkits, filters, throwables and of course MGRs, which are military grade rounds. Not only are they used for that little bit of extra punch when attacking enemies, they're also the main currency of Metro 2033.

Throughout the world of Metro, there are locations in which Artyom can buy and trade several things. Ranging from weapons, medkits, throwables, filters and of course ammunition. (All of which are bought using MGRs, so searching for supplies is a must!)

The game also allows you to handle the majority of the levels using stealth. While you of course can't stealth levels which are against monsters, almost all levels which have humans in them can be finished using stealth.

[u]Graphics / General Environment[/u]

For the year this game came out, it is still absolutely stunning to look at. They really captured the dark, dingy and eerie atmosphere of the Metro tunnels, and gave you a small glimpse into the Russians' world of poverty and survival. The few times you're able to leave the Metro and explore the surface, you see it is desolate, and crawling with mutants created by the vast levels of radiation. The developers really paid attention to detail, for no two bodies you come across are the same. They went above and beyond to create individual and believable remains throughout the game, and nothing appeared to be copy-pasted. This added to the believability of the nuclear war, and just how powerful radiation can be.

Spoilers:
[spoiler]The D6 Bunker you are tasked with finding was mapped out phenomenally. The attention to details the developers paid attention to did not go unnoticed, for this bunker is one of a kind, and extremely realistic looking to what you'd expect of an actual underground bunker.[/spoiler]

[u]Enemies / Monsters[/u]

You come across a variety of enemies and monsters throughout the game. (Will mark for spoilers in case you don't want to know about them before playing).

[spoiler]This can range from Demons (mutated bats), to Watchmen (these appear to be giant rats, although they're more canine like in the sense they travel in packs). You will also come across shadow people, which are ghost-like silhouettes of those who have perished either on the surface or in the Metro. They add to the eerie and sad atmosphere of the overall game. Aside from mutants, you also come across bandits, Fascists, and Nazis that you must face in combat.[/spoiler]

[u]Missions / Side Quests[/u]

Metro 2033 follows a linear path, where you don't get any side quests to follow. You're given main missions that further progress the game. Playing the game at a slower pace can allow you to fit more dialog than if you played it to just finish the game.

[u]Game Modes / Difficulties[/u]

Each game mode is different from one another. In total the game has the following four modes: Easy, Normal, Hardcore and Ranger Hardcore which is also known as Stalker Mode.

I personally played through Hardcore and Ranger Hardcore most as I enjoy the franchise the most that way. The resources are scarcer while the enemies hit harder, but so do you! Stealth really shines on higher difficulties, but the loud approach isn't out of the equation as long as you use everything at your disposal. All difficulties are enjoyable to play through, and it is entirely possible to take a stealth approach, a loud approach, or a combination of both in every single game mode available, so be sure to read the in-game description and choose the one you prefer the most!

[u]Achievements / Replayability[/u]

Achievements in this game are absolutely fun to collect. If you're aiming to get all the achievements and 100% the game, you'll have to play through the game multiple times. The replayability due to that alone is great. Some achievements are based on stealth, not being seen, killing or knocking someone out, while some are based on the amount of people killed. They're specifically challenging to get on higher difficulties, but fun. You'll enjoy getting them no matter what difficulty you're on or how you play the game.

[u]Voice Acting / Sounds[/u]

The sound effects were done extremely well, especially when paired with the naturally eerie environment of the Metro. The voice acting was done phenomenally, and they had quite a few well known voice actors. (Steve Blum, Kirk Thorton, and Yuri Lowenthal, for example).

[u]Alternate Endings[/u]

There is one alternative ending for this game. Whether you get the original ending or the alternative one is entirely dependent on your choices throughout the game. Each choice has a severe impact on the overall outcome of the game, which adds to the immersion that you are essentially living out Artyom's life for him. While both endings are good, I personally prefer the original ending (which is the canonical ending).

[u]Conclusion[/u]

First installment, but should be in everyone's library. The game is absolutely spot on in every aspect. The developers care about the game, especially as it is based off the Metro 2033 book written by Dmitry Glukhovsky. I definitely recommend buying Metro 2033!

it good

This was my second try at this game because it starts off in such a brutal fashion, but I'm glad I stuck with it in the end. The graphics on this version are really great, and they really bring to life so many eerie and atmospheric environments. I followed advice and played with Russian audio and without the crosshair, and I think I'd recommend the same. That said, despite not speaking Russian, I'm not sure the voice acting was that good - it lacked a lot of intonation. Another minor flaw was the gunplay with rifles wasn't particularly satisfying and the human enemy AI was disappointing, not even reacting to dead bodies during stealth sequences. The campaign was a decent length, but very linear which might put some off, and there doesn't seem to be a lot of replay value here.

Eu queria muito gostar desse jogo, meu objetivo era zerar os 3, mas esse aqui não tem como. To ligado que ele fez história quando lançou e muita gente gosta mas eu acho essa gameplay dele horrível e sem querer ficar metendo muito pau, mas a história n me agrada muito também. A sonorização é bem triste, controles são travados, os combates são pouco impactante e frequentes demais e o jogo tem um costume desnecessário em ficar te zoando com coisas irritantes (tipo bater a cabeça na parte do trem). Eu to negativando pq essa review é sobre a minha opinião, mas eu acho que pre ser justo devo dizer que esse (até onde eu sei) é o primeiro game de renome dessa dev, ele tem seu charme e com as melhorias gráficas do redux, a atmosfera é bem boa. Não posso dizer que não vale a pena o teste, mas eu n gostei...
yes

An incredibly engrossing post-apocalyptic game. It that has a few bugs and non intuitive moments but those are easily forgiven in exchange for an immersive first person game with a great world to back it up. 

The Good
 - gameplay is solid
 - sound is great. Gunfire, sound effects, voiceovers 
 - characters feel fleshed out

The Not so Good
 - companion AI is wonky due to the game being released a while ago. enemies attack only you and companions are slow to aid at parts
 - the game doesn't hold your hand nor does it have modern day comforts like quest markers, quest pathing, or minimap. This led to some confusion at times but I felt it added to the charm. I can see where others would not enjoy that though.
 
All in all if you like the post apocalyptic, survival, resource management, sneaking around in the sewers finding ammo one bullet at a time then this is for you.

Metro 2033 Redux is a top-class first-person shooter/survival horror game, a breathless experience that's been almost flawlessly ported to Switch by 4A Games. Artyom's desperate, haunting voyage through the irradiated remains of Moscow is every bit as engaging today as it was when it first released back in 2010, and this Redux version benefits massively from overhauled AI, gameplay mechanics and visuals. In terms of first-person shooters or survival horror games on PC, this is one of the very best.

A valuable remake that makes the original Metro feel complete on PC.


10/10

My review system works with a 10 point score. 0 = bad and 10 = good.
I have 5 criteria on which I decide. Each can give 0 - 2 points.
Below that I will explain my decisions.

[h1] Total rating = 4/10 [/h1]

[b] 1. Gameplay + 1 [/b]
[b] 2. Graphics + 1 [/b]

I have to be honest. The first encounter I had with Metro was years ago, when I had no idea of the franchise and thought of Metro: Last Light as a standalone title. Well, as it turned out, it was the second of a series and while I was a little confused sometimes, it actually already explained to me what happened in this one. This might also be the reason, why it took me years to play the first one, and I have to say... it wasn't really necessary.
There is literally nothing in the story that is new or interesting if you have played the second part first. The pacing is very weird, with sometimes being too slow and other times too fast. To explain, you are constantly with new people who you just met. All they do is slow you down until they die far too early, so it's not even dramatic. Why? Because I just met those people! It feels like the game wants those deaths to have an impact on you, but I don't even remember their faces half the time.
Which brings me to the next part. Sure, it's an old game, I get that. But if your graphics are limited. Give the characters some special features, so I can recognize them. I think there are only 2 of the dozens of people I met that I could recognize immediately. Which sucks if they tell you to follow someone else...
Anyway, the game looks pretty good and detailed for its age if you forget about the faces (and the children). But there is so much focus on companions that it's still only one point on graphics for me.
There is a similar problem with the sound design. While the ambiance and music is absolutely superb, the voice acting is more mediocre. Which, again, sucks when meeting new characters is literally a thing every 5 minutes.
The game-play theoretically was fine. It just felt really clunky. For an old game, that's nothing special, but in this case, it was somewhat bothersome when the game wants you to fight big hordes of enemies. Most times, I felt like I'll just have to tank it while reloading.
In any case. Considering, Metro 2033 is over a decade old. It's not a bad game. It's just not really needed any more. Everything this game does is done better by Last Light and you don't even need the story part either. So if you want to play it you can, but I would recommend to just start with Metro: Last Light.
Whatever you do. Thanks for reading and I hope it helped :)

Billions of people died during the Last War, in which nuclear weapons were used. The only people who survived were the ones who sought shelter underground. In Moscow, Russia, a lot of people fled in to the metro stations. Due to the radiation on the surface, they had no choice but to make the metro their new home.

The game takes place 20 years after the Last War. You play as Artyom, a young man who lives in one of the stations, Exhibition (which is VDNKh station in real life). Life in the metro is hard. The war may be over, but underground new and old wars continue. Besides poverty, there are conflicting political ideologies, corruption, greed, irrational fear of one another and violence. Will humanity ever learn? On the surface the situation isn't much better. Due to the radiation, you cannot even go outside without a gas mask. On top of that, it is now swarming with dangerous, hungry mutants, with the latest threat being the Dark Ones...

Initially, this game attracted me, because I have traveled a bit through Russia myself and have seen and visited many of the locations in it. Whoever made use of the Moscow Metro knows that the stations are works of art; almost like mini-museums. Here in this game not so much. They are still impressive, but in a much darker and sadder way. Other things that appealed to me, after playing the game, are the subtle 'moral points' that you receive for 'doing the right thing' (although, admittedly, in this game that often means eavesdropping on random conversations between NPCs or simply exploring every nook and cranny) and this will even determine which ending you will get. I also really enjoyed Artyom's internal monologue between levels, as his way of thinking resonated with me.

However, I do have some critique as well. I play with an X-Box controller and it took me way too long to figure out all the buttons. I had to search for help online. It wasn't always clear to me where I needed to go either and on the surface that is a problem, since your gas mask runs out of air when you run out of filters. Sometimes I had to speed-run through a level and - as someone who plays like a turtle and likes to enjoy his surroundings - I did not enjoy that (although I am better now with managing my filters). Last but not least, I actually do have some mild critique concerning those 'moral points'... [spoiler]The 'good ending' isn't canon with the Metro series. The 'bad ending' is. So that basically means you have to sabotage your 'clean' playthrough in order not to be confused when you start [url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198067384854/recommended/287390/]Metro: Last Light[/url]).[/spoiler] Oh, and the English voice acting for little children is bad... really bad.

Overall, I recommend this exciting and atmospheric game, but compared to [url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198067384854/recommended/287390/]Metro: Last Light[/url] and [url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198067384854/recommended/412020/]Metro Exodus[/url], I do consider this the least in the series.

Fantastic game adapted from a fantastic book, Metro drips with lore and atmosphere and claustrophobia. The immersion in these games is simply perfect, from the way you interact with your equipment, wiping off your gas mask, charging your flashlight, and the like, to scratching on your lighter and burning cobwebs as mutated spiders scurry around in the darkness, and your breath steams up your gas mask. The gameplay might not be for everyone, but it most certainly was for me, and I love how unapologetically it sticks to its vision, which makes it stand out all the more. The plot is deep, sad, but tinged with hope, showcasing the sheer stubbornness of the human spirit, and does an incredible job of adapting the novel which is one of the best pieces of post-apocalyptic fiction I've read, and you can really see the passion the devs put into every inch of this game. Metro 2033 is simply amazing, a game where worldbuilding, immersion, atmosphere and writing all melt together into a superb, cohesive whole, and if that isn't worth your time, I really don't know what is.

Simply put, one of the best games I've ever played. To be honest, I don't even know why I love it so much, it's just so well made. The atmosphere, unusual weapons, the story, enemies, wonderful graphics, fantastic characters and many more. Yeah you could say, ahhh there are many other games that are better than this one, but METRO has something that makes you love it (all of them). I think Half Life is very similar franchise, because people who love it see more than just a good story, characters etc., those games have truly something more to it. The "feel". I've played a lot of games, not just on pc but also on xbox and playstation (all combined, more than 200), however none of them made me write a review or tell anyone to go and buy it immediately. This is my first and probably the last review and I'm glad that it's the METRO franchise that's getting the pleasure. If you can't choose between 2033, Last Light and Exodus, I can tell you that all of them are fantastic games and you should get them in the bundle, but if you just want to try it, I would go for the 2033, because it's the first chronologically. METRO Last Light has more guns, boss fights and is longer, but on the other hand, METRO 2033 is darker, which helps the atmosphere and the horror site of the game. Metro Exodus is something else completely, because it leaves the cramped spaces of the Moscow metro and decides to take the, nowadays, more popular route of the open world genre by being composed of a few semi open world areas. It still manages to keep the "feel" of the previous games, but I personaly just couldn't help but feel that something was off throughout the entirity of my playthrough. It has some nice ideas such as the new backpack feature or the weapon jamming, but I would honestly be happy to see METRO get back to the roots of the first two games. 

Well, I think that's it for this kinda review, which is more just saying how good the franchise is and not telling you the pros and cons, but that's exactly what I wanted to write. Thank you if you took your time and read this :)

Based on initially running the game natively in Linux I would not have recommended the game, as the graphics were janky, and neither the gamma slider nor graphics settings seemed to have any affect of the visual quality, and all this while making my gpu run full out.

Forcing compatibilty and using proton suddenly the graphics were good, the gamma slider changed darkness, and my gpu was running easier. I was also able to remap keys to my mouse now too. I did have an initial issue that after the switch I lost my saves/progress, and the internet wasn't much help however worked out myself that I just needed to copy my saves from steamapps/common/Metro 2033 Redux/[numeric string]/ to steamapps/compat/286690/pfx/drive_c/users/steamuser/Documents/4A Games/Metro 2033/[numeric string]/

A truly fantastic look at how Immersive FPS games should be done.  From it's first moments you will be blown away by just how much attention to detail there is when interacting with the world and viewing it through your characters perspective.  

FPS games that take full advantage of their perspective to immerse the player are few and far between and it's a shame as it's one of the genre's biggest advantages.  Some standouts like the Stalker Franchise really drive the point home, going almost for a simulation feel.  It just so happens that the Metro series was developed by part of the team behind Stalker, and it plays like it.  2033 is a great first entry to the series and basically gives us a taste of what a linear Stalker game could be. Despite losing a lot of what makes Stalker great, it doesn't hurt the experience, it is equally as enthralling in it's own way.  I like to think that Metro is to Stalker as Rage is to Fallout 3+, or as Arx Fatalis is to Elder Scrolls if you like.

Metro 2033 is an extremely tightly crafted linear FPS that has the feel of an Immersive Sim in some respects, and a survival horror game in others, which is an awesome combination.

I appreciate the effort that went into remaking this game in a different engine (it's the same engine as Metro: last light, if I understood it correctly), and the developers used that opportunity to improve many aspects of the game. The diversified characters would be a good example that immediately caught my eye. The old Metro 2033 had a lot of recycled human models, which made it feel a bit unrealistic and sterile. 

However, the moment I started the game, I missed Artyoms old voice. His whiny, despair filled voice was so much more fitting to the setting of the game imo. And I feel similar about the new soundtrack. I get the impression the developers tried to focus more on western audiences instead of the source material, because the overall vibe of the game now reminds me more of other titles like Resident Evil or Silent Hill. Not that this is a bad development, I just think it takes away from what made this game unique and immersive.

One major flaw I have to point out tough is that this game struggles with UWQHD monitors, meaning is stretches and distorts the picture depending on where I look at. If for example a human model stands right infront of me, it gets squished and looks almost a bit like a twig. If I view the same model from the edge of my monitor tough, it has the proper proportions again. So far I found no way to fix this issue, and only Metro 2033 redux has it, the other games in the series run fine.

Edit: the distortion and stretching on my monitor disappeared after some time, altough I cannot pinpoint a particular action or event that cleared the issue. It just appeared to have fixed itself when I started the game one day. 

Overall, I do not regret getting this game a second time (it was on sale), and I can recommend it to any Metro/Stalker fan.

I hate to give this a thumbs down, but the game has some serious issues that I never see brought up in the reviews.

The stealth. I've heard you can not kill a single person in this game. That's not my experience. I can't figure out stealth in this game. Enemies from a distance can see you more easily than the ones I'm doing circles around at times. By doing circles, I mean that literally. I duck around and circle them praying the Knock Out prompt will appear. It rarely does. Time to kill people again.

Hitting shift when I press W as I want to run often brings up the Steam overlay. This happens in no other games I've played, but is a lot of fun in combat. LOTS.

The lack of instruction in this game is a joke. Seven hours in before I found on Google how to get to your journal. There isn't even a key bind option for this (if IDK what key something is, I go to the controls in options.) After that, I finally figured out how to charge your flashlight, as they don't tell you this. Inventory? Yep. Another 8 hours as the controls don't tell you to hold Tab down for a few seconds. I was pressing it, as one would assume. They also don't tell you that your map isn't a compass, but a wayfinder. The first few times I tried it, North(ish) was coincidentally the direction I needed to go. An e-manual would've been nice. I don't believe anyone should ever need to go online to find the basic instructions of a game. 

The game crashes. A lot. Of the hundreds of hours I've gamed this year, this is the only one I've actually lost saves on.

The story is pretty good, but unfortunately it's not done well. There wasn't enough about the Dark Ones to fully flesh them out. Side characters were ok. This is minor, as they're trying to condense a book into a short game.

Oh....The Librarians. Stand your ground, maintain eyesight, and move slowly away if approached. Half the time they just attacked for no reason. Funny though, they did no damage. It was more of a nuisance trying to get around them though.

There are positives to this game that every reviewer on here has gone on about. I just wanted to list some of the problems that are often appearing, yet not talked about. It's just another poorly made game that the devs have no intention of fixing. This, along with no instructions have been staples of declining quality in games that's not slowing down.

It's certainly not a bad game, but it's not a great one either. Immersion is impossible when you can't stop critically thinking, due to the bugs. This was every experience with stealth. I wouldn't pay more than $10 for it.

I dont know why I waited so long to play this game because its absolutely fantastic. It may be slightly on the short side but thats to be expected for what it is. That being a linear but tense and atmospheric experience. My favourite levels were the above ground ones where it felt even more tense due to a time restraint on filters for your gas mask. I had to restart one level and be more strategic because I didnt have enough filters to see out the end of the level. Some people might be annoyed by this as Ive seen it mentioned but I enjoyed the challenge. There were a couple of bugs and crashes to desktop on both this and Last Light, moreso in the latter, which is a direct continuation of this game. I bought these games super cheap and they were worth every penny.

I had some questions about the difficulty options as there are many, so what I did was do my inital playthrough on Spartan Hardcore, and subsequent on Survival Ranger Hardcore, which was a fantastic experience knowing the layout of the levels and controls. I did the exact same with Last Light. Two playthroughs are required for completion if you are that way inclined and starting the game on Ranger Hardcore would guarantee some unnecessary deaths and frustrations due to not knowing where items are placed in the menus and certain moments in the game where its necessary to mash the interact button, without the prompts on normal or hardcore mode it would be impossible to know when playing on Ranger mode.

It took me about 75 hours to complete both games including the DLC on Last Light but I like to take my time and enjoy the experience and soak up the atmosphere. Im currently halway through the first book which is also fantastic and the game holds through to the story in large part.

Anyways, thats my 2c. Enjoy this game and dont put it off for so long like I did. Im gonna take a break and read the rest of the books before diving into Exodus. I really am looking forward to that.

I am a 46 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 14 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, started playing . I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son . This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I don't usually make reviews but I'll start because I use them all the time.
To preface I've never played the original metro 2033 so I can't compare the two but I had a great time with this game. The gameplay can either be fast with lots of gunfire and pipe bombs or slow and methodical with throwing knives and silent unconventional weapons, hell you get an achievement for killing every person on a level and another achievement for not killing anyone on the same level, made the gameplay a different experience the second time around. The gameplay can have some real tension too, certain enemies on certain levels can just be terrifying, whether it's darting around trying to find the little creatures sprinting everywhere through holes in the wall or being chased by the gorilla-esque librarians that take shotgun shell after shotgun shell. The weapon choices are pretty preem too, except the bastrd gun, it's awful but everything else is pretty cool and can offer some difference in how you approach a fight and each with their own level of upgrades or modifications, not as much as I would like but last light and exodus improve on this.
Speaking of the other metro games I should mention the story. It's pretty alright, maybe one of the weaker parts of the game, I haven't read the books the story is based off of but it can be a little repetitive but ultimately worth it as gameplay and story fit almost seamlessly, like iced tea and lemonade or authority and corruption. I won't spoil any of the story but it's definitely interesting at times and by the end it's actually thought provoking, it's worth it for the gameplay if nothing else but more importantly it sets up the sequel: Metro Last Light, which builds on the story and gameplay in much more interesting ways. All in all, a great pick for a long weekend and worth it if you find it on sale with the others, worth it on it's own too but last light and exodus are big improvements. Solid 8/10, read more reviews and watch a video if you're still unsure.

Also, if you have time be sure to check out the novel as it is marvellous.

This is an awesome game.
Some weird hitboxes here and there, transparent stairs, bulletproof curtains, you know, the usual.
But still... AWESOME game.
I tend to take that stuff seriously and judge harshly for them, but here I just couldn't help myself but laugh it off.
Those flaws pale in comparison to the track record of this series

The world feels so alive, with the setting respected and maintained expertly in all visual and gameplay aspects.
The direction you look matters, NPCs will react to you naturally, and their dialog hits that exact line of relevance to you as a player and believability.
No two gun shops have the same dialog, everyone has their style and circumstances.
Immersion is not something you have to worry about here, at all.
Ranger mode is incredibly interesting to struggle in, ammo management is a must, and hitting heads and timing shots are essential to survive, let alone having spare ammo at the end.
Stealth is simple but sharp, one mistake can quickly turn a flawless run around into a disaster.

One small problem I have with this game is the chain of companions you go through.
While making a semblance of sense in the story, felt really contrived and called upon all the luck in the knows universe.

The writing is incredible and holds up a solid image, unafraid to reach into the important questions, the questions this game is all about.

Your choices MATTER.
Your actions MATTER.
Even the ones not presented neatly with a 'good' and 'bad' option.


What makes you human?
Why is your life worth more than the people at the end of your muzzle?


note that both games suffer from rare game breaking bugs and save errors that force full reloads and/or other fun save trickery to resolve.
if you notice anything odd, look it up and hope you can still salvage the last 5 hours of gameplay...

I love the gunplay these Metro games have, all weapons feel fantastic. There is weight to the combat, it feels amazing to shoot people and monsters. Decent story. I had fun even on my 3rd playthrough for the 100%.

The game is kind of realistic, except for those armored blokes who can take like 5 headshots and 1-2 grenades under their feet and still survive. I fucking hate these in all shooters. If it is some kind of monster or some unknown creature being that resilient, ok you can justify that, but a regular ass human eating 5 headshots, multiple grenades, there is no armor that can withstand that, not even 1 headshot, let alone 5. And the grenade? Yeah no, especially not in this setting... it boils my blood every time devs do this.

The other thing I don't really like is the stealth, it is great that there is the option to do it but imho it doesn't work (at least for me). I have yet to play a game with decent stealth, not even in games dedicated to it. The AI have a weird hivemind, they don't see you at point blank ranges at times, other times they wallhack you across the map.

This game saved my life.

I am 65.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

My dislikes are : 
1. No extensive UI : You don't know how much health you have, where your next objective is, how much oxygen you got.
2. There's no way we can read what NPCs told us afterwards. If you missed the conversation, then you can never know what was the hint or objective given by NPC. Lack of manual save sometimes put us in weird situation, For example - I was on the surface where oxygen is really crucial. I didn't knew I was running out of oxygen (no UI) and checkpoint was saved. Shortly after that, I was stuck in a loop where "reload last checkpoint" gave me only 30 seconds of OXYGEN to survive. (Had to restart the game to make it right)

Absolutely love this series. You know it has to be good if players can despise sewer levels and a dev/pub makes a game based solely around it (basically)!

From level design to graphics and story / characters this game has it all! I really enjoy scrounging what I can and having that survival feeling. Music fits perfectly and the game flows just as it feel it would. You really have to give credit where it is due. 

The only thing I truly hope is worked on is the sound of Artium, or whoever may be the MC of the game, walking around. I get what they were going for, but it just doesn't sound right to me. Its a weird nit pick but honestly, it truly is the only thing that sticks out and I find myself calling out. This should go without saying, but don't let this stop you from enjoying one of the greats. Seriously, I really think this series stands as a gaming giant. A series to get others into gaming as a hobby. 

Although Metro does give off a slower burn kind of game, it throws you in right from the jump, then slows for a second to set up the story. You may run your two hours up before you know it. Not that I think you'll refund, but something to keep in mind.

Even after a full 8 years, the Redux of Metro 2033 still holds up beautifully to this day. Of course, the redux doesn't have the same gritty and mute feel and aesthetic as the original release, and I have my fair share of nitpicks with the game in terms of it's aesthetics, the story, its gameplay, and the atmosphere of each area you journey through, remains alive and enthralling. 

I'd suggest giving this game a try, even if you have played the original release, just to relive this game and the memories it gave you. But for any newcomers who come across this while browsing the steam pages, this is a game that will test your wits, make you think and approach situations differently, and provide a great experience for those wanting something more out of an FPS.
