Artyom my beloved

A decent stealth action game with superb atmosphere, which is what I'm going to talk about instead of the story because the story is only one part.

One thing I love about the Metro games is that each station has tons of personality to it. It's not limited to depressing, woe-is-me sadness porn, although there is plenty of that, it also shows people trying to live and find happiness among the dark. Puppet shows for kids, brothels, salesmen showing off their wares, old photos of the surface pre-nuclear war lining the walls, these are the things you're protecting when you plunge into the terror waiting metres outside the walls - human or otherwise. All the human villains have the sympathetic side to them of being piss-terrified of dying in a desperate struggle for survival.

You occasionally go to the surface, which is also really fucking cool. Firstly it's nuclear winter, not nuclear fallout, so the aesthetic is different. The mechanics like gas mask canisters, wiping the visor, the creatures that have adapted to the surface better than you, it all makes you feel like you're absolutely 100% out of your fucking depth, like you really don't belong on the surface anymore. 

But also, the Fallout series and games like it have wrong a lot out of a nuclear apocalypse in the US, but there's something very alien about exploring Moscow - complete with some faithful recreations of popular locations, like the Library, or some boring old suburbs. It was inhabited by people seen to be the "villains" of the Cold War (really they're just people born on one side instead of the other), driven by the same kind of national pride that fuelled the West. And now here we are, walking among the ruins, seeing it from the perspective of someone who mourns the loss of it just like we would a non-Eastern Bloc country. There's no us and them, there's just us. It's a weird and unique feeling when you play through it for the first time. And, the enemies in the Library are terrifying and awesome.

There are also subtle supernatural elements in the metro. The thing that stands out to me is the contrast between highly industrial, cooperate, metropolitan environments and weird supernatural stuff. Inexplicable phenomena happening within a perfectly, mathematically planned subway. It's is very engaging, although I must say that, the main story notwithstanding, the game (and Last Light, too) doesn't really seem interested in explaining or even hinting at why and how all of this is happening. The mystery and ideas alone might be enough to satisfy you, but I view it the same way as a JO sesh of edging for an hour while looking for good material and then just giving up and not finishing. The lack of payoff retroactively dampens everything beforehand.

However, there's a lot about the stealth that annoys me. Firstly, a lot of rooms have a single very video gamey solution to them, in that it literally has a very clear winding path of shadow to follow in order to stay hidden from enemies. The core of good stealth gameplay is using the tools the game gives you to manipulate the environment and behaviour of enemies. seeing rooms so obviously laid out to skip that step kind of ruins my immersion. No self-respecting murderous gang would leave their defences so open. 

As for the tools with which you manipulate your environment, I would have liked there to be more. There's the classic throwing objects to attract attention to where you aren't, stealth takedowns (thankfully not pre-animated), but nothing stands out as the game's equivalent of Metal Gear Solid's cardboard box, say. There are pneumatic weapons for silent takedowns that spice things up in raw combat, but a), an AK with a silencer does the same job, is easier to get ammo for and easier to use in more situations (no pumping to reload, etc.) and b), I think stealth is far more interesting when you don't actually massacre everyone. Call me a big old stick-in-the-mud, but human life is valuable, especially in the apocalypse. The player-character being both underpowered because they don't give in to the power-hungry violence of other factions and also because they're just better at it fits a lot more into the vibe the story is going for. Also, it's fun to imagine enemies who have realised they've been stealth'd jumping up and down in frustration afterwards. They can't do that if they're all on the ground whistling through the holes in their heads.

Also, since you're underground most of the time, the visibility isn't great. Grey and black straps and jackets against grey and black concrete, that sort of thing. Floodlights/flashlights in stealth areas are often blinding, too, which makes it hard to make out where exactly an enemy's head is - and consequently whether they'll die with a single lovetap or call all of their friends because you shot their shoulder. Shooting them out also alerts everyone, fair enough, but that means that it's annoyingly hard either way. There are night vision ACOG sights, but they're not particularly pretty. You can only change them out at stations, so there's no way of knowing if you're going to be viewing the next fun action setpiece through an ugly, potentially blinding green haze if the area is well lit (since that's how night vision works) or spraying from the hip the whole time. I'll pass on both counts, thanks.

Generally, the game needs more discipline around communicating enemy paths and actions and locations.  The gold standard for this, as always, are the Thief games. The guard's footsteps are loud because they're armed and don't care about hiding. The rooms are well lit. The floor types change the amount of noise you make (a rug, wood, hard floors) and you can tell which is which by sight and sound. Knowing all those factors and working around them should be where the challenge originates. A decent chunk of my progression in stealth areas was trial and error until I knew enough about it beforehand to get through. Not all of it, it's mostly functional, but it's there.

The atmosphere and setting, I think, are definitely worth the price of admission. Actually, after writing all this out I wanna replay it, so I'm gonna go do that. Bye.

Overall – Metro 2033 may have been a fantastic game upon release…. But playing it over a decade later, it hasn’t aged well. The game feels incredibly clunky, it has a ton of game-breaking bugs…still…the game was fortunately pretty short and hopefully the series improves with each release. 🖥️ System Specs
AMD Ryzen 9 5950X | NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3090 | 32GB RAM | 2560 x 1440 165Hz
Full of Energy and Thrill !
Big juicer. PagMan

The Gameplay:
The shooting is solid, headshots matter with all enemies and those knife kills.. oh god. Feels good to play especially since you feel like you are managing a tactical suit without absurd menus.

The Story:
I love the depressing/scary take on post apocalypse compared to the goofy antics of Fallout. There are funny moments but it doesn't feel out of place.

The Visuals:
A big revamp from the original 2033 which looked literally dry by comparison. If it isn't explicitly stated this is on a remake level of upgrade.

The Sound:
The guns sound crisp, the voice acting is on point, the music is perfectly somber and it helps set it's mood very well.


The Experience:
Great story based game. Some quality of life things like skippable scenes would be nice. Also a windowed fullscreen would do wonders as alt tabbing causes it to crash, otherwise excellent game.

5/10

It's an alright game. The atmosphere is good, the gunplay is mediocre, and the graphics hold up enough. 

But... the characters are all boring and expendable, graphics tend to be quality mismatched and flat, gun accuracy and impact aren't the best, the game has a tendency to not teach things like recharging battery, lighting is frankly pretty bad, maps and story can be sometimes hard to navigate and I kept not knowing what I was supposed to be doing, this has an odd amount of magical content that just doesnt fit in, and the pacing my god, talk about a fucking slog, there isn't enough content or story to back this game up so most of the time it's a walking/horde simulator.

Idk, would I recommend it? Sure, it's not horrible, but I wouldn't recommend it unless you have a lot of patience and aren't looking for anything engaging.

I really enjoyed this game, albeit in the same way as I enjoy Children of Men. I have heard it criticized as a series of sub stories touched on but unexplored, the narrator dragged away after a glimpse, and I would argue that that is the point, it is an odyssey and a cross-section of the world. 

Gameplay is good, though it felt simultaneously too easy and overwhelming (I mow through enemies with ease and then get a pack of nosalisis that I feel can't be addressed cleanly by even a skilled player, less white-knuckling it and more farceacle dancing about) but that is nitpicky. Librarians terrified me, even after repeated runs, and the fear lasted well past the library, so there is that.

All told, a pretty good game.

I've never played the original Metro 2033, so my opinion here is based on my first experience of the game.

The word I would use to call this game is "disappointing". It's linear beyond belief and most of the game is scripted as all balls. Although the game is atmospheric, its certainly not organic. So many of the encounters are scripted, thus making the game insultingly predictable and immersion breaking.

First is scripted moments. There will be many moment in which enemies will be invincible so they can perform scripted actions, ie. jump on you and making you perform a QTE. There is one such moment at the beginning in which an enemy will jump at you and can only be killed through a QTE. You can unload as many shotgun shells as you want, it will not die unless you press E. Funnily enough, pressing E and your character melees the enemy off. Why is it funny? E is the "use button", they made you press the "use" button instead of your actual "melee" button.
Sometimes, the game will just spawn enemies if you find a secret. I cleared an entire building of enemies with loud shotgun fire, absolutely no hostiles left. Found a secret room, only to come out of it and find 3 enemies conveniently standing outside the door.

If like me, you want to have the most immersive experience by playing Survival Ranger difficulty, just don't. It's very clear the game was never designed to be played that way and was just nailed onto it to bait people into playing it, or at least, require you to have knowledge of a game you haven't played yet. Here's a few reasons why.

1. There will be a point in the game where your path will be blocked by spider webs, during which you'll have to burn it with your lighter. Does the game ever tell you you have a lighter? No. Does the game ever indicate it's something you can do? No. You know who will tell you all that? Your old friend Google.

2. Flashlight and Nightvisions are powered by your battery charger. Since you'll be in dark tunnels, you need the light. The battery charger is offhandedly mentioned at the beginning and never brought up again. How to use it? How it works? Never tells you any of that. You know who teaches it to you? Google does.

3. Limited weapons and ammo. What's the problem with that you ask? Firstly, the game likes to lock you in arenas and fight wave after wave of enemies. With how limited the ammo is and how tanky the enemies are, even if you saved up every bullet you can, you'll still find yourself running out before the fighting is even finished. So I found myself running in circles kiting the mobs until some scripted set piece stopped the infinitely re-spawning enemies.

In short, good setting, terrible everything else. This makes me wonder if the game I got was the same as everyone else's.

Still well worth my time in 2022 !

I've spent a considerable amount of time on both the Original game and this one, and I have to say while this is nowhere as bad as most recent 'remakes' (Or even remakes of it's time (2014)), it definitely lacks the magic and atmosphere that Metro 2033 spent so much time making.
And that's one of my biggest complains with this game, while the Original Metro 2033 was gritty, dark and an overreaching sense of 'Hopelessness', while the remake completely lacks said atmosphere and qualities.
The gameplay's just Metro Last Light + A few extra weapons and that's about it, so there isn't exactly much to write home about when it comes to it.
And as for the new designs and textures...I would have to say yet again Metro 2033's enemy designs (Especially the Librarians.) And environmental designs were much much more atmospheric and downright creepy and unsettling than the Redux's, which is a shame considering how well it was captured in the original.
All in all, a very good remake that sadly can't live up to it's original counterpart's creepiness and atmosphere but perhaps outmatches it in every other way.

The best atmospheric fps game tied with Stalker. The story is faithful to the novel with a few subtle changes and certain gameplay moments have been recreated from the novel with extreme accuracy and detail, the most notable being the library section. You will know when you get there. The survival action gameplay is enjoyable; you're constantly looking out for ammo and mask filters in every corner. Combat is tense and challenging against both humans and mutants. Recommended to play on Ranger/Ranger Hardcore difficulty which increases damage taken as well as damage done for both player and enemies, reduced ammo and filters which forces exploration and careful planning before attacking and partially/completely disables the UI making for the most immersive experience.

[b]Metro is a journey, first and foremost.[/b]

It features shooting, exploration, and scavenging, but ultimately it is a linear story where you are introduced to a terrifying yet mysterious post-apocalyptic Moscow, filled with mutants and monsters, but also enigmatic beings like anomalies or "the shadows". Also, it has a great variety of difficulty settings, so you can suit the game to you preferred way of enjoying shooters, be it sneaky survivor or Rambo, which is great in my opinion.

Metro is one of the few "campaign only" games that I've replayed about 2-3 times each already (both 2033 and Last Light). There's just... something to it, that every now and then I want to go play it all over again. To relive that dark and unnerving Metro experience, without any "crafting, survival, or day-night cycle" bullshit, just you, your weapon, few bullets, and whatever lurks in those dark tunnels as you advance forward.

Godspeed, Artyom. We all are going to need it down there.

[spoiler]On the bad side, the karma god/bad endings are a little bullshit, so don't stress too much about getting either.[/spolier]

A hair-raising treatise on survival. Based on the novel by Dmitry Glukhovsky, the Metro universe provides disquieting insight into the possibilities of a post-nuclear world. Each station the player visits is a vignette of an attempt at governance that displays the success, failures, and excesses of different world views of mankind. As a game, the player will have close shaves in claustrophobic combat characterized by low resources and innovative solutions. This game is a must-play for the survival horror player and lovers of the Call of Pripyat franchise. 

The binary endings are made available through seemingly insignificant choices and exploration. Both ultimately provide the player with a tableau of the outcomes of attempting to understand an enemy. The player can examine the effects of both preemptive destruction and the risk of showing mercy.

My first time truly getting into a Metro game, I've tried them before but hadn't played them enough to really gain an opinion on it, maybe an hour or so of gameplay at most but this time I played through the entire thing start to finish.

All in all, I enjoyed it. It's an FPS set in the wasteland-post apocalypse setting, with the entire shabang that being radiation, cheap handmade guns as weaponry, and various mutants taking up most of the enemy roster. I think what sets this game apart from others like Fallout or Stalker though is that it's very atmospheric and immersive, much more so than the other two franchises I just mentioned.

Metro is very slow in terms of its combat, you don't get a ton of bullets most of the time and generally there's not a lot of enemies that you're fighting at one given time, save for certain events. There's also things you need to micromanage like your gas mask air supply and flashlight charge. You even have to wipe the blood or grime off your gas mask when it gets dirty, it's pretty cool.

I didn't think the story was that good, but it got the job done. Essentially you're a guy trying to defend his home Metro station from these strange monsters called "The Dark Ones" which threaten to destroy it. The game revolves around finding a way to wipe them out and dealing with the harsh world at the same time, and personally although the story itself didn't amaze me I really did like the world this game has. I like the monsters and the characters, and genuinely wanted to see where humanity was gonna go next dealing with the apocalypse. The game is also gorgeous so it's really easy to just get sucked in and explore everything you can.

It's hard for me to think of any bad things with this game, I suppose it would have been cool if the game was slightly less linear, maybe something similar to how Resident Evil does with it's level design and being able to backtrack to certain areas and unlock new things using items you've gained from progressing the main story but I'm just nitpicking. 

It's a solid recommend, it didn't wow me or anything but it's a good game and I enjoyed it

[h1] Metro 2033 Redux review [/h1]

TL:DR 
Buy this game if you like:
-FPS games
-survival horror elements
-Post Apocalyptic

Don't buy this game if you dislike/hate
-Linear gameplay
-Horror of any kind
-FPS


Based on the novel of the same name Metro 2033 was originally released in 2010 Redux was released in 2014 and offers a remake of Metro 2033 using features from the game's sequel.

[b] Story Summery [/b]

Set in post-apocalyptic Moscow Russia, the surface of Russia is dangerous and highly radioactive the surviving Humans have retreated underground to Russia's vast metro system. 

20 years have passed since the world was plunged in to chaos by nuclear war, remaining humans try to make a living in repurposed metro stations deep underground far from the dangers of the surface. 

As events unfold a new threat emerges.

Your home station of VDNKh is attacked by strange never seen before creatures, You play as Artyom a relatively young and naive metro survivor, VDNKh is once again attacked by mutant creatures that been encountered before, as attacks get more common Artyom decides that going to a central station to get help is a must, his also given a task of alerting a friend's commander shall he not return.

As Artyom ventures to the hostile surface it becomes clear that mutants are not the only threat, as Humans still lurk in their past of warring against each other.

Eventually Artyom reaches his goal, but the threat of those unkown creatures still lurk and a critical decision must be made.


[b] Gameplay Overview [/b]

Metro 2033 redux is a FPS game with horror and stealth elements, mostly a linear game levels encourage minor exploration in finding equipment and collectables.

Combat is to be expected from an FPS game Artyom has a decent array of weapons to use ranging from grenades, throwing knives, to guns in general.

As its a post-apocalyptic game you won't see Guns that you're used to or are easily recognizable instead most weapons are made from spare parts found in the metro our on the surface, (And some can be quite silly looking) During certain levels the player can choose to trade in his/her's current weapon for a better one or upgrade the existing one (Upgrade system is limited don't expect to change every part of your weapons)

Majority of the game takes place underground in or around metro stations, but there are a few Surface levels, Players can approach human enemies either through stealth or traditional FPS gun blazing glory.

Mostly on surface levels and some underground areas the use of a Gas mask is needed to prevent a horrible and painful death from the unbreatheable air.

Through out the game there's a hidden moral point system that can be gain through different ways, good points are usually awarded if one pays attention to events or not thinking with their guns, you lose points if you do things in said events that are deemed bad (E.g shooting a wounded soldier that poses no threat)

depending on the amount of deeds you've done (or not) it'll affect the game's ending.


[b] My Personal Experience [/b]

Personally I've enjoyed my time with the rather gloomy plot and setting, there are some moments in the game that can really make a seasoned or new player jump out of their chair, as for the gameplay it self its enjoyable sneaking around quietly in levels that have humans and picking them off one by one never gets old, the survival features and the use of the gas masks is a nice reminder that Metro 2033 isn't a mindless shooter.

The only main issue I had with this game was that the shooting controls feel a bit clunky as I'm playing with a controller aiming and shooting can feel a bit slow sometimes even with max sensitivity settings, however upon switching to keyboard and mouse it feels better.

Sadly with this style of FPS games it usually has little to no replay value I've played it once a few years ago and haven't touched it until today, it is still a good game to kill some time.

At $20 its an affordable price that will give you a unique experience.

Rating: 7.5/10

Great game. This is my second playthrough of it. While it does have a lot of scripted events, the game oozes with ambience and story. Recommend it fully to those looking for a good post apocalyptic experience.

I had read the book and played Exodus before this one and Last Light, so I might be a bit biased here. 

Genrally speaking, Metro 2033 is a good game. Worth the money only on big sale, in my opinion. 
Graphics are okay, nothing too good or too bad, with only few worse moments, where looking at characters would give you a heart-attack. 

Story, comparing to book, was very, very rushed and it shows - there's not much depth into the characters, characters like Bourbon or Khan dissapear before you even have a chance to talk with them properly. It's a huge disadvantage. It's been cut to fit short gameplay (under one day, if you're not going for achievements). The changes in story are also major. [Those are spoilers from the book Metro 2033, so if you haven't read it, please skip this part of review, the fact changes were major is enough for you to know]. [spoiler] VDNKh has completely change, it looks nothing as described in the books. Same goes for Polis, the deal with Librarians and Military doesn't exist, or at least is not mentioned at all. Danila is a completely different person (which is not that bad itself, just not who I expected him to be). Characters acting out of character were also a big wtf moment, especially with our dear Miller. There are more, but those are the ones that I remembered clearly. [/spoiler]

Gameplay - I don't mind it, let's say it like that. I was playing on Survival, and let me tell you one thing: you'll never have enough filters. I would refill them up to 20 minutes (that's the max), and somehow run out of it 5 minutes later. I'm not sure if it's not a bug, 'cause it only happened after two levels. But still, filters are scarce and that's no joke. It got to the point where I had to restar chapter to find extra filters - which got annoying at some point. You can get them only twice in shop, which is not a lot, considering how much time you're spending on surface. Finding it anywhere else is a miracle sometimes, mostly you're getting showered with ammo (always had too much of it). 

Combat itself is not the best one - sometimes option to knock/kill opponents was not showing up, had to either throw knife or shoot at them. Both humans and mutants (especially Librarians) are very sensitive to any form of noise. Type of: you yawn, and they start shooting at you. Plus, even if it was showing me, that enemy can't see me (light off), I'd still get noticed and killed - yet another bug. Librarians somehow would almost always know where I'm heading or bugging in the walls (restarted three times 'cause of that). At some levels you'd have to fight hoards of mutants, which was pain in the ass - case: you blink, you dead. But that's not a complaint, rather a notice for any player. 

Equipment: There's plenty of medkits, so there's no worry about those at all. Night vision has too much contrast, my head started to hurt after I was using it for a longer period of time (but that's on me only, I suppose). Shooting is okay. Compas sucks tho, got lost a lot of times because it was showing me weird directions that were not obvious, and ended up wasting lots of time. Guns and modifications are good, same with bombs. 

The bugs I've encountered: disappearing filters, Librarians getting stuck in the wall, sometimes HUD not showing up. 

I'd especially recommend this game to those, who had never read book, like I did, 'cause I'm slightly disappointed. I had fun, true, but it's missing the sparkle from the book. If I didn't read it before, I think the game would be fun - story is full of action. And fans of Metro Universum, of course! But mind you guy what I wrote here, so you don't get your hopes to high.

I thought this game was a good start to the series.

The story is pretty abstract and uncertain at first, I didn't realize what the ultimate goal was until I was about to finish the game. The game kinda switches up on you, which I didn't really like.
That's about where the negatives end though.

Despite it being 8 years old, it doesn't feel dated; the graphics are great and the environments are dense and vibrant, while still maintaining a sense of unease. The gunplay is pretty fluid and I loved the customization options for each gun; finding a loadout that worked for me was one of my favourite parts. I played on hardcore and it wasn't too bad overall, I probably could've gotten away with one of the harder modes. At least I have an excuse to replay at some point!

The Metro as a setting is a great choice; I loved how the game used it as not only a locale but also how the team used it to comment on human nature and the inhabitants' choices. The karma system makes sense for this type of game. It prioritizes the stealth aspect of the game, and gives an incentive to explore and discover things about the people and places you meet. 

While I think it's the weakest of the series, it's still quite good in its own right and you should play it.

Metro 2033 Redux is a grimdark, gearpunk FPS with a heavy emphasis on atmosphere and exploration. In it, you explore the nature of the Dark Ones, a foreign and mysterious group of questionable intent as you navigate the vast expanse of the metro, an underground Soviet subway system that refugees from the surface retreated to after an apparent World War III.
As the title suggests, the graphics also have a new coat of paint with this rendition, which especially shine on the surface portions of the game. While I've not yet played the original version of the game to compare, I can safely assume that this is one of the major success points of the redux.

To speak on the game’s triumphs more generally, I would say that Metro 2033 succeeds in three main aspects. As previously stated, the graphics (along with the music/ambience) allow the player to really buy into the grimy world of the metro while still keeping the game nice to look at. It also has a suitable selection of weapons, equipment, and pathways to meet your every need in taking on the natural and supernatural foes you encounter. Made even further better by its adherence to the makeshift aesthetic, such as can be seen in the Tihar, a pneumatic hand-pump air gun made from spare parts around the metro. Additionally, the equipment rationing and scavenge mechanics, like the gas mask filters in particular, are fun ways to add resource management in a way that makes sense while adding to the difficulty.

Of course, the story is no slouch either. Its expeditionary-like structure and journal entries work surprisingly well in adding to the tone and immersion, as well as providing ideal accommodations for any playstyle, be it stealth missions, hunker down defenses, or run-and-gun ops. Though most of the time it is up to you how you handle the situation. Conversely, the game’s weakest point, and only real problems are the somewhat frequent glitches and bugs. While I didn’t suffer any outright crashes, I did have to restart the game at a certain point because I was unable to progress. Most of the time though they can be avoided or ignored pretty easily, so there’s that at least. All in all, I would definitely say give it a shot, it’s a fun shooter with a lot to admire.

one of the best survival games i've played

Sometimes you can find riches just outside of your comfort zone, a small leap of faith away. For me, that leap of faith was playing a game described as survival horror - Metro 2033. The 11 hours I spent playing this game is some of the most memorable time I have spent playing games in recent years.

The gameplay mechanics were simple yet nuanced - pumping your airguns, charging your nightvision, easy weapon upgrading.

The world was brilliant, teeming with details and polish, from citizens quarreling drunkenly as you pass a bar to enemies warming their hands by a barrel fire and sharing memories of their families.

The music and sound design was perfectly crafted to make your hair stand on end in the depths of a mushroom-clouded sewer, or inspire thoughts of heroism after your friends survive an onslaught of enemies at the door of a safe zone.

The combat was a little tough at times, considering how much movement the enemies do and how scarce ammo can be, but it really hit that sweet spot of every fight feeling like a struggle without becoming unwinnable.

I have a terrible time playing horror, so for me this game was about as suspenseful and terrifying as I can take. And thankfully I took the chance, because I think everyone should be able to experience Metro 2033 Redux.

mastapiece

Like many, I expected something along the lines of STALKER. Metro 2033, however, is a linear shooter, instead of semi-open world like STALKER. This is not the games' fault, therefore it doesn't affect my rating.
What does affect my rating, is that this graphically and atmospherically great game turned fighting mutants into a chore. They often just rush you mindlessly, while being pretty tanky. There are several scripted sequences where you have to defend against waves of mutants and these are easily the worst parts of the game. The other ones are where you are forced to follow a person who is essentially a tour guide a'la CoD. Oh, and the ones where you are on rails. Literally. Unfortunately, these are prevalent in the first half of the game, but it gets better eventually.
Which are the best ones? Once again, I'm going to parrot many reviewers here: the encounters with humans. Once you get the night vision goggles, you can Splinter Cell those levels by destroying all sources of light and headshotting everyone without much retaliation, if done properly. It's awesome and it feels very empowering. The example is the Front Line mission: a rather big and open level with lots of human targets. Too bad the level is followed by another rail shooter section.

There is other stuff I don't like e.g. some mechanics are just not explained at all like the flashlight charging or lighter burning cobwebs (which is required to progress through one of the earlier missions). Some of the voice acting is absolutely terrible. The library section is too long and the creatures do not always work as advertised. The game has a crappy morality system that affects the ending: you know, you should totally spare those psychotic Nazis and Commies bro, otherwise you're a bad person.

In short: it's at its best when it allows you to approach situations as you see fit, it's at its worst when it's a postapo Call of Duty. It's a good game, but overrated in my opinion.

As someone who almost exclusively plays action-focused FPS games and personally dislikes the powerlessness of some survival-horror games (e.g., Alien Isolation), I found the horror in Metro 2033 Redux to be an excellent mix of survival and action with a compelling story. The unsettling and bleak atmosphere of the game is remarkable. The enemy types are quite fresh and creative, especially the "Librarian" (though they overuse the Nosalis imo). The weapon sound design and weapon upgrade system are not bad for the year this game came out, but they definitely show their age. Nevertheless, this is overall a solid game. I look forward to playing the next installments.

Not a bad game, but also definitely not a perfect one either.

It's aged pretty badly, to be honest. The graphics might've been revamped to more modern standards, and the difference in comparison with the original is outstanding.

But everything else isn't. The shooting feels very clunky (a lot of times shots are poorly traced and don't hit correctly and sometimes normal enemies are just sponges that resist way too much), annoying bugs (like picked up diaries not being registered from level to level) are common and, worst of all, the AI is awful. You can exploit with relative ease the stupidity of human enemies when it comes to stealth sections, but when it comes to shooting they have pinpoint accuracy from extreme distances and even when you're completlely in the dark. Most of the game is a bit luckluster in my opinion. Don't get me wrong, I love the atmosphere and design. Every piece of scenario in this game feels unique and purposefully placed, every diary you read and every backdrop conversation you hear, it all sums up to build a very rich and horrifying world with a rather dark and complex plot that's told incredibly well thanks to a high degree of nuances and moral dilemmas. Sadly, all of it is somewhat ruined at times by the mechanics.

I still recommend it because it's not a bad game, just very rusty (which is obviously an age thing, since the original was made in 2010 and it was A4's first game). Just, don't try to play at higher difficulties, maybe Normal Ranger at most. It can get very annoying and frustrating at certain parts.

A great game gives an overall great experience.  The story line is great although it is overall a linear story.  It reminds me of the Bioshock series for the overall atmosphere and play style. 

Achievements are interesting and most of them can be acquired by replaying chapters.  Two play through is required for Survivor mode and Spartan mode each.  Some of the achievements requires a particular play style which add some replay value for certain chapters. 

At times the game can crash to desktop but still can reload the latest checkpoint with no issue.  It happens to me around 3-4 times in two play through and therefore is not an issue to me.

The atmosphere, immersion, and unique mechanics in Metro 2033 Redux are all backed by an incredible story.

An atmospheric first person stealth/shooter which retells the story of Metro 2033 novel.

The game belongs to the "quirky but good" group of games -- some of its design, such as monster combat, is flawed, but you still can't put it down and have to keep going to learn "what comes next". 

Sneaking through hostile bases without raising an alarm, or trying to avoid killing anyone, is definitely suspenseful and thrilling. Basically, when you're going against humans, the game is great; when you are _required_ to fight monsters, it can get annoying.

Exploration and handling of radiation and gas masks are both very cool.

You really do feel like Artyom.

This game is not that BAD, the game SHOULD be great, I mean it has quite a great story behind it and graphics are 10/10 considering it's a 2014 title... BUT... It doesn't take too long to realize there is something missing, when I read those bad reviews I thought they were talking about graphic performance at most, but HELL NO... you can feel there is something missing from the first encounters with enemies, some of them just stay there staring at you or your partner while he reloads, some prompts simply won't show up and some minor glitches but nothing serious. At first I thought this thing with idling enemies was a difficulty setting issue, that I would simply need to increase the difficulty but no, the only settings you will find are: Survival (Easy) and Spartan (Way Easier), of course there are also some other settings but these mostly affect how you manage your inventory, and for a game that is actually very lineal, divided by chapters and considering that even in Survival there are plenty of resources, this feature didn't seem to be much of a difference to me... the game is good if you want a plain shooter with nice graphics but that's pretty much it... I find Half Life more interesting than this. I only gave this a chance because I searched for older games and this title was ranked in better positions than other games that I used to love, but honestly I feel cheated.

After a lot of thought, I have to slightly edge towards Not Recommended. I feel like this game had a ton of potential for being incredibly deep and immersive, it swung, and it didn't quite hit it.

Note: I played on Survival Hardcore.

+ If Metro has a reputation for anything, it's visuals and atmosphere. The game looks great, the environments are full of detail. The surface is desolate and hostile, the sun is harsh, and the wind is strong. The metro is dirty, claustrophobic, and oppressive, and the desperation is palpable. Your gas mask gets smudged, and is damp from condensation. Many of the guns look cobbled together and worn, especially when you start putting on attachments. All the little details are there. Although I haven't read the books, you can tell 4A tried to make the world of the novel come to life and it shows.
+ The music! Especially during tense scenes, it's very fitting.
+ The survival, scavenging nature of the game is excellent. There were moments where I had a dozen bullets to my name, running around dark tunnels, finally running across a body with a few bullets on it that could sustain me for a bit longer. I was on my last filter for my gask mask, running around looking for a crate somewhere, and finally stumbled upon an extra minute of reprieve from suffocation. (I will note there was one time where I suffocated during an in-engine cutscene and I had to redo the preceding fight, that kind of pissed me off, but I can admit that maybe I made a mistake earlier in the level.)
+ The difficulty was done right in my opinion. I have some caveats to this that I'll address later, but I never felt like it was too hard. If I died repeatedly, it was because I had been too trigger happy earlier, or picked the wrong guns, and I was facing the consequences for my actions. Still frustrating, but when that happened, I was annoyed with myself, not the game.

Sounds glowing so far, but that's where the positive ends unfortunately.
On the topic of atmosphere and immersion:
= The metro stations are alive and rich, full of people having conversations that you can listen in on, and so many little details that make them almost real. But...there's kind of nothing to do. Although there are a handful of exceptions, the only meaningful things to do are to buy guns and ammo, find the person you need to talk to, and then leave. So, while the stations looked alive, that didn't quite translate into gameplay.
= Voice acting is hit or miss. Some of the characters are convincing, other times the pacing of their speech (i.e. lack of pauses) is a bit jarring. There's also some weird gaps in between NPC actions, where nobody says anything for like 10-15 seconds. It threw off the pacing for me.
- On the topic of voice acting: Artyom has a voice actor! Artyom has a voice! [i]He talks during every loading screen![/i] Yet, for some reason, in gameplay, he's a Mysterious Silent Protagonist, and never says a word. Characters notice this and mention how silent he is. Characters ask him questions, and he just doesn't respond, or other people respond for him. Sure, same deal in Half-Life, but in Half-Life, Gordon [b]never[/b] talks, so it's just a bit of a weird decision here IMO.
- There's so little character and story depth, and this is [b]the most tragic fault of this game in my opinion.[/b] I beat the game and I have no idea who Artyom actually was, or most anybody for that matter. There's a war, but hardly any detail about it. (Only [spoiler]Khan[/spoiler] has some depth.)

The AI is mediocre.
- Being targeted by nosalises is fine; being targeted by nosalises who are being shot at by my comrades and who run clear past them towards me is immersion-breaking.
- Early in the game I had a demon circle me for a long time and never attack because I was under a four foot wide section of cover. It was intended behavior I guess, but immersion-breaking.
- Similarly, with a late-game enemy, one of your companions explains how they behave: [spoiler]If you look at them, they won't attack. Don't shoot them, and don't turn your back on them, and you'll be fine. Since you're reading the spoiler, it's Librarians.[/spoiler] Except, [spoiler]without provoking it, or even moving an inch, just sitting in the dark, I had one slowly walk up to me, bellow at me, and kill me.[/spoiler] Not a big deal, honestly, but it's not what the game told me to expect.
- The friendly AI is pretty stupid and has terrible aim. I had exited the game at the beginning of a combat section, and upon continuing, a nosalis charged us, but nobody shot at it until it was attempting to murder me. In a later section of the game (I'll be vague to avoid spoilers), traveling with somebody, I watched him shoot a whole stream of bullets at an enemy a couple feet from him and miss all of them.
- Tying in with AI, let's talk about stealth. Metro really wants to be stealth game but it doesn't execute it well. Stealth works simply: if you're in the dark you're hidden, and if you're in light you're visible. But this means that even in bright darkness an enemy won't see you when you're essentially in plain sight (from experience). Other times I walked right past and behind and enemy because his headlamp was facing away from me. The game has pacifist stealth achievements, and I didn't seriously attempt them because I felt like they required cheesing really stupid stealth mechanics.

The game is a bit clunky.
= There's a lot of what you might call forced camera motion, where the game takes control of you for a sequence. Although this isn't strictly a bad thing, it happens CONSTANTLY in this game and it felt a bit excessive to the point of being immersion-breaking.
= Sprinting doesn't feel great.
= [spoiler]There's a level where you carry a child on your back for part of it.[/spoiler] This screws up your aim by adding a bit of lag to your mouse movement. I realize that's the intent, but to me it just added clunk.
- There's a sequence where you use a turret and the controls for it are absolutely infuriating. You have to aim left and right with A and D, and aim up and down with the mouse. This might not sound too bad but in practice I really hated it. I even tried messing with enabling and disabling look inversion, nothing helped. It's just unnecessarily clunky.

A couple thoughts on combat:
= One very viable strategy against a wave of enemies is to backpedal in circles with the revolver. It feels a bit silly.
= The bastard is introduced to you as a shitty gun, but fully modded, it's almost too good against humans. It one-shots unhelmeted soldiers and two-shots basic helmeted ones. Its first bullet is perfectly accurate, too, so it's like a 30-round sniper rifle.

Some quick nitpicks:
- Now, I don't need a game to hold my hand, but any good game should make sure the player is familiar with any unique controls or mechanics in some way. I missed that there is a compass that points you to your target destination, and that's arguably my fault, that's fine. But, the fact that there's a detailed weapon inventory menu was never mentioned in normal gameplay. Only 7 hours in(!) did I notice when looking through the controls menu.
- You walk much faster than other people, yet are expected to walk alongside them. Your speed is slowed down at some points in the game, like in friendly stations, but not at others. The key issue is it's inconsistent, and hence annoying.

It's also just a bit buggy.
- The depth of field effect affects the reticle of your scope, and your laser sight's beam. Not a big deal but it looks weird.
- It crashed twice in my playthrough, one time requiring me to log out of the account / restart my computer because I couldn't see task manager.
- The night vision binoculars are completely broken.
- At one point a demon grabbed me while I was under cover and basically across the room from it.
- Near the end of the game I had a watchman spawn inside me of and instakill me because I ran into the room too early.

5/10

Once I was boy. Then Metro 2033 happened. Now I am man that drinks vodka and enjoys AK47s. 

Metro 2033 is more a survival thriller than a shooter and you will realise this very quickly once mutants absorb most of your ammo. Avoidance is usually the more prudent choice where possible but you will have to resort to violence on a regular basis. Whether it's mutants or your fellow man in need of a "negotiation" don't forget to wipe blood off your mask, change your filter before you run out of air, charge your flashlight with a dynamo so you can see what you're doing, avoid traps lying on the ground and navigate the area via your compass. All of this happens, in game, without the interference of menus. Metro 2033 goes to great lengths to offer a diegetic experience and keep you in the world, which is great, because there is an amazing attention to detail. Before long you will be wrapped up in the Metro's captivating atmosphere. 

Topside, every detail works to tell you the story of those that didn't make it to safety and of what has been lost. Below, In the repurposed metro stations, whether it's eavesdropping on a quarrelsome couple, kids asking their parents about what the sky looks like or men ferrying provisions for transportation, there's always something happening to emphasise that the struggle to survive continues. The end result is that you very much understand the situation of the survivors and can empathise with their actions, even in their more callous moments. Artyom Is a great "almost silent" protagonist. What I appreciate most about him is that we are spared from his inner voice. It's all saved for the loading screen in diary format. So while I am aware of his drives, motivations and fears I don't have to listen to him comment on how dark the room is or if the door on the left is the correct door because it has the red handle. The supporting cast are fairly good but honestly, aside from Bourbon, they mostly blend in and facilitate the story rather than command it. Speaking of the story, there is a karma system but it's not entirely obvious what leads to the good ending and what leads to the bad one. Just try you best to be good I guess. I like this, I can understand that others might have gripes with it... but stuff ya! I like it. 

Unfortunately, Metro2033 does have it's problems. The most annoying is probably the sound of AK 47s. I was hoping with redux that they had rerecorded the guns sounds but sadly this is not the case and it can be a bit jarring hearing the same audio file played for each shot.
While there was always the option of stealth, it's not very well defined. Sometimes enemies can look at you from 5m away and not see you and sometimes you get spotted by someone 2 floors above you in a seemingly arbitrary way. I know that Metro goes to great lengths to be diegetic and that's mostly a pro but when it comes to stealth it feels a bit hit or miss. 

Sometimes it wasn't clear what you were supposed to do because you as the player have no idea that the objective is "Walk to this spot to trigger a scripted event. and it gets even worse when said scripted event is triggered by an NPC partner that walks at the speed of drying paint while you are on your last 30 seconds of air time. 

Gun to my head, and it's definitely an AK, I'd give this a 

7/10

[code] Metro 2033 Redux is an incredibly atmospheric experience that’s marred by technical problems and gameplay issues[/code]

I’ll have to start this review a warning right off the bat: [i]Metro 2033 Redux[/i] only narrowly dodged a “not recommended” status here. In fact, it’s only thanks to me being really fond of single-player FPS campaigns in general that [i]Metro 2033 Redux[/i] escaped its non-recommendation. Because, as I’ll point out in the following, there certainly is enough wrong with this game to warrant second thoughts about playing it.

Anyways, let’s get over the basics first. [i]Metro 2033 Redux[/i] is based on the Metro books by Dmitri Alexejewitsch Gluchowski. The original [i]Metro 2033[/i] game released in 2010 and received an updated release called [i]Metro 2033 Redux[/i] in 2014 – promising a bunch of technical improvements (graphics, AI, combat). That’s the version I’m discussing here of course, as the original [i]Metro 2033[/i] isn’t even sold on Steam anymore (although you might still own it, as it was given away for free shortly before it got delisted).

It's not happening often that we got videogames based on (modern) books but considering the unique setting of the [i]Metro[/i] universe, it’s not surprising: After an atomic war in 2013, the people of Moscow kept on surviving by moving deep underground – to the titular Metro tunnels. Dealing with scarce supplies, mutants, bandits and more, life in the Metro is as miserable as you might imagine. And it is here, set in 2033, where the story of protagonist Artyom starts.

The greatest strength of [i]Metro 2033 Redux[/i] is, with no doubt, bringing the setting of the books to life. Be it strolling through the run down but crowded Metro stations, exploring dark and creepy tunnels or hastily moving through the desolated, radioactive surface that used to be Moscow - [i]Metro 2033 Redux[/i] nails the atmosphere. The game is dark, it’s claustrophobic, it’s creepy and I’m all here for it.

I also have to mention how the gameplay is accommodating its setting: Before starting the campaign, [i]Metro 2033 Redux[/i] allows you to choose between different modes (Survivor, Spartan, Ranger), matching the experience you want to have: a focus on survival or combat (I picked survival)? Though it does seem weird that the Ranger Hardcore mode with disabled UI also disables the quick time event-prompts – ah well. I also liked the idea of military grade bullets serving as both, a currency in the game or as well, bullets. And manually wiping your gas mask from blood during combat is also a nice touch.

In general, the gameplay of [i]Metro 2033 Redux[/i] is what you expect from a FPS with a focus on survival: You’ll explore a level, picking up as much ammo, medkits, gas mask filters, etc. as you can – until you get into a fight where you’ll deplete your resources. Rinse and repeat, with some cutscenes, quick time events or turret sections in between. The gunplay’s fine and while I never completely ran out of ammo, I never felt like I could just mindlessly use up my resources. Weapons can be upgraded as well, which is nice, except for me reaching max upgrades with my three weapons pretty soon - which is kind of underwhelming.

To summarize so far: the setting and atmosphere is fantastic, the gameplay what you expect (= fine). Except I’ll now have to talk about the more frustrating aspects of [i]Metro 2033 Redux[/i], which quickly turns “gameplay = fine” into something else.

Let’s start of by some minor irritations: Artyom, the protagonist, never speaks in-game. Not only does this make some scenes incredibly awkward, but it’s also even weirder because he actually got a voice in-game: During all loading screens between levels, he reads an excerpt from his diary. So why isn’t he allowed to talk during gameplay? Because the typical answer to “are you okay, Artyom?” is tightly gripping a railcar pole? Come on.

More minor irritations concern enemy behavior or AI. As “improved AI” was a selling point for the [i]Redux[/i] version, I was quite surprised by how bad it behaved sometimes. It got stuck, it kept on repeating the same actions (ducking, standing, ducking, standing, duck-) or it kept ignoring the gunfire of multiple NPCs and instead charged at me, the player, who was not shooting and also far away.

Even more irritating is how enemies react to stealth approaches. Yes, [i]Metro 2033 Redux[/i] allows for good old “crouch and slowly move” FPS stealth – including assassinations from behind and throwing knives. What the game can’t decide on, however, is when to detect the player and when not. Sometimes I remained hidden by sneaking in front of enemies even though I was in plain sight. Sometimes I was detected while doing nothing but crouching in an entirely separate & dark room. These inconsistencies made me quickly disregard stealth as a valuable tactic and I just went for straight-up gunfights as long as the enemy presence was manageable.

An unexpected frustrations turned out to be checkpoints. As I played on the “hard” difficulty, I did see my fair share of deaths of course. What I didn’t expected to see is just how far the checkpoints are apart at times. Especially chapter 4 of the game made me go through multiple, spread out enemy sections before granting me a checkpoint. To keep this review spoiler-free, I won’t go into details here - but going through huge chunks of the level over and over because the AI glitched out again in the end is definitely not fun.

And speaking of “definitely not fun”, let’s talk about the technical issues of [i]Metro 2033 Redux[/i]. Some of them can’t be helped: NPCs for example, have aged noticeably. While the environments still hold up quite well, the NPC faces do remind you that you’re still playing a videogame after all. But again, the [i]Redux[/i] version released in 2014. I also had issues using Surround sound, which basically muted NPCs dialogue if I wasn’t directly looking at them. I was also unable to get the game to run in full-screen mode at first and had to apply some technical workarounds.

The most frustrating part of [i]Metro 2033 Redux[/i], however, was a game-breaking bug I ran into. Near the end of a long chapter, my NPC companion glitched out, which in turn made it impossible to continue as they were supposed to open a gate. Even reloading checkpoints didn’t help – I googled and found out this bug has been plaguing the game for a long time now. Only solution – restarting the entire chapter (!). That’s definitely not something I want to see in a so-called [i]Redux[/i] version of game and apparently, according to Google, it’s not even the only one.

Concluding, [i]Metro 2033 Redux[/i] is an extremely atmospheric game with okay gameplay to go along with it. However, multiple issues regarding AI, stealth, checkpoints and technical bugs really drag down the experience. I don’t regret playing [i]Metro 2033 Redux[/i] but there were certainly a few times where I considering just dropping the game entirely. This is wishful thinking, but a Redux [i]Redux[/i] version is what this game really needs for its strengths to shine.

One of the best FPS game series ever to exist in my opinion. Never gets repetitive, always keeps you on edge, wondering what's going to happen next. This game in particular in the series will always hold a dear place in my heart as this was my second playthrough, the first time being many years ago when I was a kid. This game may have released what seems like ages ago but still holds up today as a FPS survival.

The good:
Compelling narrative.
A tense, immersive environment
Good voice acting
Excellent graphics (for the era).
I beat it in just under 9 hours, and that's exactly how much game I wanted.

The meh:
Being the silent protagonist was kind of goofy. I would have preferred to have a voice.
The ammo/money system is unique, but I wanted a bit more to buy and a little more incentive to explore.
I honestly did not like the timed filter system when using the gas mask. It ups the tension, but it doesn't give you time to appreciate the environments.
It's a sausagefest. I would have enjoyed seeing some female Rangers or at least minor NPCs.
It's a great, lore-rich sci-fi world, but it does seem to wear its Stalker and Half-Life influences a bit brazenly.

The bad:
Some of the outdoor levels don't provide you with enough guidance. If you're going to make an on-rails shooter, don't tax my patience too much. Especially with my oxygen constantly running low outside. That one level trying to get around the hotel was annoying AF.

The verdict:
It's a classic, and if you like adventure FPS games like the new Wolfenstein and Tomb Raider games, you owe it to yourself to play. Can't wait to play the sequels.

Overall, really fun game with a great story!

[h2]Metro 2033 Redux Review[/h2]

[h1][b]Storyline: [/b][/h1]
The game is set 20 years after a nuclear holocaust that takes place in Russia. Moscow has devolved into a ruined wasteland populated by bloodthirsty mutants and the toxic air has rendered the terrain uninhabitable. The Metro tunnels are the only remaining option for the survivors. Since new creatures known as the Dark Ones have the capacity to influence people's minds, you, Artyom, are determined to eliminate the threat to humanity. Will you be able to save your fellow survivors or will their already dismal life come to an end? Play the game to find out!

The game's story, in my opinion, is quite interesting and compelling. The game's entire tone is dark, and the story is pretty fitting. The game lasts approximately 8-9 hours.

[h1][b]🎮Gameplay:[/b][/h1]
The Metro series is well known for its premise and the concept of 'searching your surroundings' for ammo and basic survival item. I mean, the game is set in a world where creatures have taken control of the surface, so collecting every bullet you find while traversing the Metro's terrifying tunnels is crucial for your survival. When vital survival equipment is scarce, mankind will naturally battle one another. As a result, you come across both humans and animals who are ready to kill you at first sight. The gameplay is filled with stealth, combat, and horror. There is no such thing as a safe spot; any bloodthirsty mutant could attack you at any time, or you could just perish from the toxic gas owing to a lack of filters.

[b]Combat: [/b]
Humans will always find a way to kill each other, even if weaponry is limited. So, there is diverse gear available for both playstyles, such as throwing knives for a stealth approach and explosives for a guns-blazing approach. Of course, there are numerous weapons to pick from in the game, all of which may be fully customized. I know that going guns-blazing is much more fun than sneaking through the enemies, however, there are two endings in the game, so your actions throughout the game will determine which one you’ll get. So, think twice before you kill someone!

[b]Environment: [/b]
The game is designed to depict a world where creatures rule and everything created by humans is in ruins. But does it actually showcase what it intends to show to the players? The answer is yes! It truly feels like you're battling for your life in a world littered with the bodies of unfortunate individuals and ruined structures, as well as human stations populated by melancholy people who frequently narrate stories about the surface. Just wait until you play the "Depository" mission. It's the game's scariest mission, and you'll find out why if you play it.

[b]AI and Difficulty: [/b] 
As a huge fan of the series, I completed the game on three difficulties. In every difficulty, the mutant AI is nearly identical; the only variable is the amount of damage you incur on higher difficulties. The behavior of human enemies, on the other hand, is noticeably different. On higher levels, they'll readily recognize you, making completing the game discreetly a misery. On higher levels, even the most basic HUD features and hints are missing, and the worst part is that you can't see how much ammo you have in your current clip. So, if this is your first time playing the game, stick to the Normal or Hardcore difficulties and avoid the Ranger modes!

[h1][b]📷Graphics:[/b][/h1]
The game looks decent if you can manage to run it on max settings, but if you have a low rig, then the game will look a bit outdated. But trust me, the amount of fun you’ll have while playing the game is surely worth the sacrifice. For those who can run it at max settings, there will undoubtedly be many screenshot-worthy moments as you explore the destroyed Metro tunnels. I did face some visual bugs while playing the game, but they were minor bugs and can be overlooked. The only bothersome bug worth mentioning is that you can get stuck in certain areas and have to restart the game from the latest checkpoint in order to progress. It's a pain, but I've only had it twice.

[h1][b]📝Main Pros and Cons:[/b][/h1]
[b]Pros-[/b]
[list]
    [*]Engaging story.
    [*]Easy to learn gameplay mechanics.
    [*]Can run on almost all rigs. 
    [*]The post-apocalyptic environment provides a truly new experience.
    [*]The horror element is implemented perfectly into the game. 
[/list]

[b]Cons-[/b]
[list]
    [*]Some visual bugs are present. 
    [*]No multiplayer modes present.
    [*]The graphics are a bit outdated.
[/list]

[h1][b]🏷️Tips to new players:[/b][/h1] 
Don't rush through the game and take your time exploring the area. If you try to finish it quickly, you will run out of ammo and the game will become unplayable. Also, for human enemies, use assault rifles, and keep a shotgun on hand for mutants, as shotguns are far more effective against them.

[h1][b]😇Honest Rating:[/b][/h1]
If you're seeking for a horror-themed first-person shooter, don't wait any longer and purchase the game. Although twenty dollars for a single-player game is a bit excessive, I would strongly advise purchasing it during a sale.

A very interesting but polarizing game. Not for everyone, and certainly not for me.

For those who have never heard of this saga, Metro 2033 is first person [i]horror[/i] shooter (more on that later) with some optional stealth sections, one interesting mechanic, and a pretty engaging post-apocalyptic setting. The story is based on a series of Russian novels of the same name, and also the novels that inspired the STALKER series. The game also draws some inspiration from the STALKER series, but besides some similarities more attributable to the plot and setting, Metro 2033 doesn't borrow too much from those games. The Redux version of this game brings better graphics and some changes to the game (which I can't review because I played the original very little).

Let's get the good out of the way. The plot is compelling, particularly when it comes to the endings, but not without its flaws. The music does it's job, but nothing remarkable. The gameplay is good for a horror game, meaning that even if you're good at the shooting aspect, the game won't be easy, and the experience is very tense, owing to the general ambience of the levels and their design, particularly the lightning (or lack thereof), sound design, and mechanics such as the gas mask that requires changing the filter every five miutes.

What's not to like? Well... Much like STALKER, certain things feel a bit janky.
Again, the game works well as a horror game, but not as well as a shooter. I started playing the game in Spartan mode (less emphasis on survival, more emphasis on shooting) and on the Hardcore difficulty, but I switched to Normal difficulty towards the end because I felt that the game was downright unfair. In both Metro and STALKER you can go down extremely quickly due to a poorly-planned gunfight or even environmental hazards. [b] In STALKER however, you had quicksaves. [/b] 

If you play this, do yourself a favour, ignore the advice when adjunting the gamma, and don't lower it too much. That way you'll be able to avoid [b] some [/b] of the instant death traps. The game will occasionally kill you without warning anyway (a wall falls in front of you around the library level). What does that add to a shooter? Play, fight, loot, die, notice and remember the death trap at that specific location, repeat, die to a trap two steps after the first one, repeat. It does add to the horror element, as it is okay for those kinds of games to feel a bit hostile, but here, they're just infuriating.

The combat is meh. You fight against monsters, which often feel like bullet sponges, and you fight humans. There aren't many fights against humans, which is a shame (although it has to do with the plot, so it makes sense), and the gunfighting isn't that special either, though I liked some of the stealth sections, at least the ones that allow you to pick out your enemies silently. Half of weapons available are good: the pistol, the shotguns, and the assault rifles. Pneumatic weaponry sucks IMO. It doesn't feel much more powerful than the regular weapons, but instead much clunkier. There is some weapon costumization, which is nice, and the original mechanic unique to this game is that you literally pay with bullets (of a premium kind, of better quality than your standard ammo).

By the way, I thought the tutorial dialogue sucked, since it usually told me information way before it was useful. If you want to take out your gas mask, long press G. If you need to pump a pneumatic gun, long press R. If you find yourself googling "Metro 2033 stuck" and it auto-completes with "in train", bring out your ligher with "M" and move towards the cobwebs.

The graphics? The game does look realistic, but you can't tell anything apart from anything. The world is just different shades of black (indoors), white (outdoors) and a sea of gray, with ocassional splashes of muddied green, rustied red and boring brown. Looking back at the original, while it looks less immersive, you can see the weapons, ammo pickups and traps quite clearly. Again, if you're into horror shooters, and moving your mouse like crazy to find pickups like it's a point-and-click adventure game, it won't be as bad, but if you're invested with the game mechanics, well, good luck.

What about the plot? Well, I won't spoil anything, but the endings are interesting. The game sends a very clear message, one even I could see, even though I am no Jacob Geller, nor even smart. The execution is very flawed though, absolutely ridden with clichés: the silent hero-protagonist that miraculously survives while everyone else around him dies, the "I hope I don't get caught" + "Oh no I got caught!" moment, the people who are willing to put their lives on the line for a complete stranger, and specially, the "oh no, I'm about to be shot!" played out very slowly while some people take their sweet time rescuing the protagonist. In a few ways you could say that it follows the trend of silent-hero protagonist, of which Half-Life's Gordon Freeman is the prime example. It's not necessarily that the formula is bad, but it's not great, and it won't do you any favours if its not well made. The voice acting in the English version doesn't help either, but switching to Russian makes it all a bit more credble, and it's nice that you can keep the text in English.

One important note on the plot (again, no spoilers): there are two endings. The "good" one can be very hard to get on a blind run, depeding on what sort of player you are. If you don't do stealth sections slowly, listening to every line of NPC dialogue to the very end, you don't try to be a pacifist in certain sections, and you don't find every nook and cranny in every room (see the graphics paragraph for why that would be hard), well, you don't get as many "moral points". It is not common knowledge if many are awarded on every event, or even how many are needed to be able to trigger (heh) the good ending, but let's just say that the guides on how to earn those (and not lose them) are a bit of a head-ache. Just a heads-up.

Was it fun? No, not really. Was the story interesting? Yes, but I found myself remember that it was a story due to the acting and the clichés of the plot. Was it frustrating? At (many) times, absolutely infuriating. Do I want to jump straight into the sequel right after finishing this one? Eh, maybe later. Would I listen to the soundtrack? Not really, but that's common for horror games. Would I recommend Metro 2033? I guess, maybe, but depending on what type of player you are, know what you're getting into.

Having always heard good things about the Metro series, I decided to begin my journey with the series. Metro 2033 shows a great foundation for the series, but unfortunately, it doesn't evolve much higher from that. The atmosphere that 2033 is able to pull off is amazing, and the graphical fidelity of the game is outstanding at points. Everything else just feels a tad clunky. The shooting is satisfying enough but not amazing, the movement can be a bit janky, knowing where to go can get confusing at times and the amount of stuff you need to worry about (battery charge, gas mask and filter, pneumatic pressure, lighting cobwebs) is a bit overbearing. There is a charm with these Ukrainian games that shines through in both Metro and Stalker, and I am looking forward to Last Light as I've heard it vastly improves upon the base 2033 establishes.

Also having multiple endings locked behind stupid ass "morality" points that are practically never introduced is stupid lol

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he created an "invite only" game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

[b]The greatest strength of Metro 2033 Redux is the oppressive and very intense atmosphere.[/b]
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2807313023[/url]
20 years after the apocalyptic cataclysm that wiped out all life on the surface, the remaining survivors retreated to Moscow's underground.
In the widely distributed network of the metro, a new culture of life emerged from bandits, communists, fascists, mutants and mysterious creatures, which are only called the "black ones".
These are shadow creatures that have recently made their way into the metro and have the ability to rob people of their minds.
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2807314704[/url]
Protagonist Artjom, who doesn't know what it looks like on the surface, has to say goodbye to his home, or rather his small plot, to warn another metro station about exactly these shadow creatures.
Artjom, who is immune to the attacks of the shadow creatures for initially unclear reasons, is therefore predestined for this mission. Step by step you explore the provisional camps that were built and converted in the metro.

The optical staging, which is accompanied by a very good background noise, ensures an exciting atmosphere that stretches over the entire game. Even if it sounds relatively boring that you struggle through the dark and boring metro most of the time, it's still really exciting and varied in parts and the well-placed shock and horror elements unfold their full effect.

From time to time Artjom ends up on the surface of the destroyed Moscow, which unfortunately cannot really be explored freely. The walking routes are relatively predetermined by "barricades" and the mood built up in the dark subway is quickly lost on the surface.

Unfortunately, there are already one or two things to complain about in the game.
Apart from the fights with human opponents and stupid hordes of mutants, which always somehow feel the same, the liveliness that I would have wished for, falls by the wayside, despite the great scenery and the many survivors, and everything seems totally lifeless.

[b]Is the game worth buying? 

Despite the flaws, yes, definitely, because it's still an intense story-driven shooter that's worth experiencing. [/b]

I wasn't initially excited to play this game because it seemed to be too serious and intense. The atmosphere is dark and scary, especially at the Ghosts level. The game's field of view was too close for me, so I had to set it farther to make it less nauseating. Aim assist was also annoying so I had to turn it off because sometimes it would shoot anything besides your target. Both options weren't available in-game so I had to edit the game's config file manually.

The game has a good amount of weapon varieties. My go-to weapons would be anything that didn't have an absurd recoil. The enemy varieties, on the other hand, were mostly the same on most mission. The two most common ones were human enemies and the mutant, Nosalis. There are other mutants in the game, but they were only shown on a few occasions. Playing stealthily would be best until the last few stages of the game (at around the Church level).

The game is relatively simple and mostly the same because of how linear it is. I was able to finish my second playthrough relatively faster than my first one because I already knew what I was doing. I was skipping most loot and collectibles so that I could get my two final achievements which had something to do with the ending and what game mode you were playing (Survival or Spartan).

Overall, this game was an amazing experience. Even though the non-playable characters' faces are lifeless, the story is captivating enough to get your attention. I would recommend this to anyone who likes story-driven shooter games.

Psychological, addictive and horrifying are the words I would use to describe this game. Metro 2033 is one of the best shooters I have ever played, one that isn't afraid to challenge the player in battle or leave them lost and wandering. With great shooting mechanics and different survival tools such as your charger and gas mask, you are taken through the dark, depressing and hellish landscape of post-apocalyptic Russia as Artyom. A young man from before the war who does not break when pitted against the abominations of the new world, doing what he can to fight for his people in a grey, exploded to rubble Moscow when they call on him for help. 
The gameplay makes for an enthralling FPS, leaving you without a dull moment with nothing to do and always punishing you for leaving a stone unturned or losing concentration. However, what I would compliment it most on is the fact that it takes its story more seriously than a series like Fallout, 2033 doesn't shy away from the supernatural or alien elements that made F1 an amazing story. Reality itself is unstable in these forsaken lands, and you get a sense that you can never know what is true and what is a trick of the mind. 
With the subway system sealed off from the unbreathable atmosphere inhabited by mutants, only those ready for a fight for the death may venture outside. Resources are scarce, tensions are high between the neighboring stations and to top it all, a new and mysterious supernatural race has started to weak havoc on the people of Metro. How will humanity survive, is the war truly the cause of all these strange phenomena? Only the most seasoned stalker will find the secrets for themselves.

First of all, I am a fan of the books as well as the metro games.

Since the original Metro 2033 was taken off Steam I did not have any chance to complete the archievments for obvious reasons (DLC). Thats also why I bought this game in sale (got it on 100% now). Furthermore there was no reason named for those actions by Deep Silver.

Imo the redux version is not worth a play compared to the original one. I dont even know why they made this redux version. The graphics are slightley better but its not really worth mentioning. I experienced more game breaking bugs than in the original one (e.g getting dropped by a demon in a car and beeing stuck there / baited by retrieving ammo into a path where you cant get out of - stuck as well (happend in the dead city) and so on).
The game sometimes just crashes for no reason. If you tap out of the game/your screen and back in again sometimes the screen is zoomed in and its not fixable but with a restart.
Also some stuff was changed or did not happen in the original (e.g. the weapons on the bed of the blacksmith were missing / the library entrance was different / the spiders / D6 was just not scary at all and overall there have been a lot of missed opportunities to really improve this game in a remastered version.

I will remove this review if you put the original metro back up again (including dlcs). Just make it free so everyone can enjoy the start of the metro games journey.

If you think about buying this game - wait for a sale.
